From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Tue Jun  1 03:31:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Ned Flanders)
Date: Tue Jun  1 03:31:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Neat idea on blocking sites...
Message-ID: <40BC585F.1070803@robinson-west.com>

The following URL describes it, or at least it did tonight...

http://www.planetmars.co.za/forums/index.php?s=769e240650eb5cad9b8dbadfe19f06da&showtopic=13195&st=0&#entry159345

It says to put:

     127.0.0.1    badsitename

in /etc/hosts.


It's not a dns solution.


I want to be able to block access to certain sites using
something other than iptables rules.  Using iptables rules,
I get an ip list that goes stale very rapidly.  With enough
entries, it takes a long time to resolve all of the  hostnames
that I list.


I want to be able to say only these sites, or, alternatively, any
site but these.  I've read about tuns and taps, ipsec, PPTP,
and ssl tunnels.  I wonder if a tun can be used in site name
filtering as well as encryption?  I want to filter the URL a
user types into their web browser.  I don't want to force
anyone to configure proxy settings or in general use a proxy.  
Some sites break when accessed through a proxy.


If I extract the destination ip out of an http TCP connection
request, I figure a user space program can resolve it and check
a list.  Maybe a bad site list should be in the local DNS
to avoid resolving blocked site names.  I don't know if I can
figure out what URL is being requested via a tun.


In dns can I simply do:

127.0.0.1    A    badsitename1
      .
      .
      .
127.0.0.1   A    badsitenamen ?

Or is there a better way to do the latter?


An ip address can be typed into a web browser.
An example of this is:     

http://192.168.1.112

         or

         192.168.1.112.

Any ip address does not have to be looked up in
order for the browser to connect.  Is there a simple
clean fix for this problem?
 

Another content filtering method is to use a database
of blocked sites on the web and install special software,
or activate special browser settings.  This seems like a
silly approach since only Windows solutions googling
around have shown up so far.  The potential advantage
of using a third party database is that someone else will
know of a site you would block before you run into it.

On Tue, 1 Jun 2004, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> This has become a problem since I re-built my home network and added a
> printer sharing box.  When I print from Mozilla I see only the Default
> System Printer (or some such -- I'm sitting are work right now.) I find
> nothing in the near-line documentation on adding more printers to Mozilla.

Rod,

  When I press ctrl-p in mozilla and select 'printer' as the destination, I
see a dialog box with a 'properties' widget to the right of the widget with
'PostScript/default' as the printer name. In the 'properties' dialog box I
can change the printer command string from the default (lpr -P laser5_ps) to
use the color printer (lpr -P color). Most of the time the default is what
we want.

Rich

Sounds like fun.  We had to deal with that at the OSDL.  Luckily, senior
management was willing to move beyond their comfort zone. 
Otherwise, things would've been, erm, suboptimal.

Their report on the process:
http://osdl.org/projects/cmptblclndrng/results/
Note the requirements.  It was surprising what features needed to be
fully supported, such as delegation and busy/free.

A broad summary report:
http://www.linuxmafia.com/faq/Apps/scheduling.html
...which also cites:
http://open-systems.ufl.edu/projects/calendar/software.html

> Dear All:

> Not only does cdrecord -scanbus looks different (the scsi/tar/lun ID is

Make sure you are not using ide-scsi emulation.  I suggest you try using 
k3b as a front end.  It does a good job of determining the environment and 
"doing the right thing".

ide-scsi is no longer supported in the 2.6.x kernels.  (At least not so 
that it would be usable.)

address specified in ServerName and well as entries for the other IP
addresses.  Connections to the other IP addresses and domain names work as
they should, but connections to the IP address in the ServerName parameter
seem to ignore the VirtualHost entry and instead use the first VirtualHost
entry in the httpd.conf instead.  So I fixed it by moving the VirtualHost
entries around so the first is a default dir.
Strange.

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Wed Jun  2 15:39:02 2004
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Wed Jun  2 15:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Apache question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406021323140.8445@neon.netpro.to>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406021306300.8445@neon.netpro.to>
    <78574cf804060213185ff5e386@mail.gmail.com>
    <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406021323140.8445@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <3981.134.244.174.76.1086216432.squirrel@134.244.174.76>

>
> This box has multiple IP addresses...  I've got the ServerName
> parameter
> set to one IP address.  Then I have the NameVirtualHost parameter
> using
> the same IP address.  Then I created VirtualHost entries for the IP
> address specified in ServerName and well as entries for the other IP
> addresses.  Connections to the other IP addresses and domain names
> work as
> they should, but connections to the IP address in the ServerName
> parameter
> seem to ignore the VirtualHost entry and instead use the first
> VirtualHost
> entry in the httpd.conf instead.  So I fixed it by moving the
> VirtualHost
> entries around so the first is a default dir.
> Strange.
> ~M

Matt,

You fixed it correctly.  You have to place the listing of VirturalName
Host in order of the one with the IP you want to default to when the
Domain name is not given.  Thus you need all these settings for two
IPs or more.

IP 1 : 10.0.0.1  (Allow it to answer request)
IP 2 : 10.0.0.3

Listen 10.0.0.1:80
Listen 10.0.0.3:80

NameVirtualHost 10.0.0.1:80 (allow for a Virtual Host)
NameVirtualHost 10.0.0.3:80

<VirtualHost 10.0.0.1:80>
ServerName domain-one.com
ServerAlias www.domain-one.com
DocumentRoot /usr/domain-one.com
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost 10.0.0.1:80>
ServerName domain-two.com
ServerAlias www.domain-two.com
DocumentRoot /usr/domain-two.com
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost 10.0.0.3:80>
ServerName domain-three.com
ServerAlias www.domain-three.com
DocumentRoot /usr/domain-three.com
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost 10.0.0.3:80>
ServerName domain-four.com
ServerAlias www.domain-four.com
DocumentRoot /usr/domain-four.com
</VirtualHost>

What this will do is that if Apache doesn't find an address to the
first request for the domain in the VirutalHost and it is not
mentioned in the ServerName then it will resolve the IP and use the
first hit.  This will mean that 10.0.0.1:80 will go to domain-one.com
and 10.0.0.3:80 will go to domain-three.com.

I have this setup on an Apache 2.x system and works great when I want
to go to my IP.  Or need too.

Josh

References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406021536030.8953@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <1606.216.99.218.67.1086217379.squirrel@216.99.218.67>

> I have a Linux router with two interfaces (running Arno's IPTables
> script).  The external interface has 3 IP addresses assigned to it,
> using the devices eth0, eth0:0, and eth0:1.
>
> When I make outgoing connections I end up using the IP assigned to
> eth0:0.
> Any ideas why it wouldn't use the IP for eth0?  Is there a way to
> change
> this behavior?
>
> I don't see anything referencing the eth0:0 IP address when I list the
> iptables rules and there's nothing I could find under /proc.
>
> I'd like to force all outgoing connections to always use a particular

Not sure if this will solve it but you should be able to set an
iptables line as:

/sbin/iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -s $LOCALNET -d \! $LOCALNET -j
SNAT --to-source $ME

LOCALNET = 10.0.0.0/24
ME = External IP you want to mask from.

Then all computers in the 24 block of 10.0.0.0 will NAT to the correct
IP.  Or should.  Then again I could be all wrong.  It works for me but
I have only one external IP on that box that I NAT but I do specify
the IP.

Josh

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Jun  2 16:26:05 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Apache question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406021323140.8445@neon.netpro.to>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406021306300.8445@neon.netpro.to> <78574cf804060213185ff5e386@mail.gmail.com> <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406021323140.8445@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <200406021625.21139.athlonrob@axpr.net>

On Wednesday 02 June 2004 01:41 pm, Matt Alexander wrote:

> This box has multiple IP addresses...  I've got the ServerName parameter
> set to one IP address.  Then I have the NameVirtualHost parameter using
> the same IP address.  Then I created VirtualHost entries for the IP
> address specified in ServerName and well as entries for the other IP
> addresses.  Connections to the other IP addresses and domain names work as
> they should, but connections to the IP address in the ServerName parameter
> seem to ignore the VirtualHost entry and instead use the first VirtualHost
> entry in the httpd.conf instead.  So I fixed it by moving the VirtualHost
> entries around so the first is a default dir.

AFAIK, Apache assumes if the request is aimed at the IP address Apache thinks 
is "the" IP address, it considers it as directed at no domains at all, so it 
feeds it the first VirtualHost, which is your default VirtualHost.

Rob



From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jun  2 16:35:03 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Apache question

 <200406021625.21139.athlonrob@axpr.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0406021633370.2234@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 2 Jun 2004, AthlonRob wrote:
> AFAIK, Apache assumes if the request is aimed at the IP address Apache
> thinks is "the" IP address, it considers it as directed at no domains at
> all, so it feeds it the first VirtualHost, which is your default
> VirtualHost.

Actually, it shouldn't feed it to ANY virtual hosts.  The default host
settings should be the ones outside any VirtualHost directive.

References: <BAY9-F203yIEe23eUCS0003750c@hotmail.com>

On Wed, 2004-06-02 at 09:49, Vincent Yau wrote:
> cdrecord: No such file or directory. Cannot open '/dev/sg*'. Cannot open 
> SCSI driver.

I might be missing something here, but I'll take a stab at it.

Looks like the device file isn't there. If you're using devfs (or maybe
udev), that means your driver isn't loaded. Do you have all the right
modules loaded?

If you're just using regular device files, then run your MAKEDEV script
(if you have it) and make sure /dev/sg* appears. On my Debian system,
it's /dev/MAKEDEV, which is a symlink to /sbin/MAKEDEV.

Evan

The 4k stack comes from a custom patch to the Fedora 2.6.5-1.358 kernel. 
  It was included in the stock 2.6.6 kernel as a config option.  It 
supposed to be possible to rebuild the kernel from the patched 
kernel-source package without that config option.

On Wed, 2004-06-02 at 09:49, Vincent Yau wrote:
> Dear All:
> 
> I just upgraded to 2.6.6 kernel after upgraded to Fedora RC2.
> I just tried to burn a CD.  It was working fine before and I did not remove 
> or add
> any hardware.
> Not only does cdrecord -scanbus looks different (the scsi/tar/lun ID is 
> different),
> but cdrecord spits out an error message.
> 
> Anyone has any clue why I am getting an error?  -scanbus as well as
> actual cd burning output is below.  Thanks for any tip.
> 
The 2.6.* kernel doesn't need SCSI emulation to burn CD's using ATAPI
devices.  All you need to do is specify the device by name, instead of
by SCSI numbers.

[snip]

> scsibus: -2 target: -2 lun: -2
> Warning: Using badly designed ATAPI via /dev/hd* interface.
> Linux sg driver version: 3.5.27
> Using libscg version 'schily-0.8'.
> cdrecord: Warning: using inofficial libscg transport code version (schily - 
> Red Hat-scsi-linux-sg.c-1.80-RH '@(#)scsi-linux-sg.c 1.80 04/03/08 Copyright 
> 1997 J. Schilling').
> scsibus1:
>         1,0,0   100) 'SAMSUNG ' 'CD-ROM SC-148C  ' 'B105' Removable CD-ROM
>         1,1,0   101) 'SAMSUNG ' 'CDRW/DVD SM-348B' 'T503' Removable CD-ROM
>         1,2,0   102) *
>         1,3,0   103) *
>         1,4,0   104) *
>         1,5,0   105) *
>         1,6,0   106) *
>         1,7,0   107) *
> [root at var0289 image]#
> [root at var0289 image]#
> [root at var0289 image]# cdrecord -v -eject speed=32 dev=1,1,0 
> LiveCD-9.1-01.iso

It looks like you have your burner as slave on the secondary IDE bus, so
try:

cdrecord -scanbus -dev=/dev/hdd

and:

cdrecord -v -eject speed=32 dev=/dev/hdd LiveCD-9.1-01.iso

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Jun  3 09:18:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] More than one printer from Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406011146070.2459@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

Well I've made some progress.  I now have in Mozilla both my network 
printers and a couple of converters -- ps and pdf.

Took installing Xprint (rpmbuild --rebuild xprint...src.rpm) and tarballs 
are available plue a deb package.

Rebuilding Mozilla with xprint enabled -- Redhat/Fedora disable it by 
default.

Finally tweaking the /etc/init.d/xprint that comes with the xprint package 
to be compatible with chkconfig.


Now I'm hunting/building the definition files for my printers.  The format 
used by xprint is not PPD.

Thanks to all that responded for the ideas to solve the problem.

From keith at ahapala.net  Thu Jun  3 10:43:02 2004
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Thu Jun  3 10:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MS / Open-Source article
Message-ID: <20040603175655.GC9967@ahapala.net>

Wow, great article. 

Warning: It's long

http://www.seattleweekly.com/features/0422/040602_news_microsoft.php

In the last two paragraphs the author talks about passion (and the
lack thereof for MS products). This strikes home with me recently on
my Debian laptop. Gnome 2.6 is on its way into the Debian unstable and
the other day after an update, I was excited to see an animated
cursor. I was happy to see that the arrow just got a little orb molded
into it with dots circling in it. I like the feedback and am glad it
doesn't interrupt the pointing end of the cursor, nor does it display
a detached pulsating icon like KDE used to. My first reaction to the
KDE animation (and this is two years ago or so) was to try and shake
that thing off my cursor. It's those little incremental improvements
rather than a Advertising firm media blitz of social engineering to
make you buy something new.

It's all about passion, about being part of a community, sharing in
successes. Sometimes when I relate a cool tool to a Windows guru
friend of mine, he replies "Just like Windows". He just doesn't get
that community side of it. It's like watching your pro team win a
championship versus you being in a recreational league and being on
the winning team.

Keith

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jun  3 11:23:01 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Jun  3 11:23:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] nForce2 Memory Woes
In-Reply-To: <393-58004@sneakemail.com>
References: <393-58004@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <1714-47765@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 26 May 2004, Steve Bonds 1s7k8uhcd001-at-sneakemail.com |PDX
Linux| wrote:

> I figure I have some options:
>   1) Reduce the memory bus frequency so it works
>   2) Try the expensive HyperX "matched" RAM
>   3) Try Crucial's CAS 3 RAM (vs 2.5 on Kingston's, maybe slower timings
>      help?)

I took option "2" and it seems to have worked, and was less expensive than
I initially thought it would be.  The only bad part of this solution is it
effectively locks me in to 1GB total system memory, since my chances of
finding a 1G module that would "match" my 2 512MB modules are pretty slim.

Also, to answer Rob's questions that got lost in the shuffle:

> DOES reducing the memory bus frequency solve the problem?

Yes.  This works flawlessly, but I didn't get the 400MHz chipset and
400MHz CPU just to run at 333MHz.  ;-)

> DOES slowing down the timings solve the problem?

No, in fact this seems to make things worse-- however I suspect that the
magic I-know-what-I'm-doing override to enable them in my BIOS also turned
on something else that broke it.  I didn't follow up to find out exactly
what this may have been since I wanted everything to work at full speed.

  -- Steve

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Thu Jun  3 16:57:02 2004
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu Jun  3 16:57:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] A bit confused about 2.6 kernel and X drivers
In-Reply-To: <87r7swdygm.fsf@ursine.ca>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406031009530.2902-100000@www.fnordora.org> <200406031558.34902.athlonrob@axpr.net> <87r7swdygm.fsf@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <200406031655.57691.athlonrob@axpr.net>

On Thursday 03 June 2004 04:16 pm, Paul Johnson wrote:
> AthlonRob <athlonrob at axpr.net> writes:
> > Legally, they'd find themselves fighting a lot of lawsuites, I fear,
> > if they opened their driver code up.
>
> So what?  They should be thinking about their customers first, from
> there the revenue will follow.

The issue as it was explained on the LKML a while back, is this:

In our Patent-happy world, it is virtually impossible to create any computer 
hardware that doesn't step on some patent somebody has somewhere, especially 
if you're designing something as complex as a graphics card.  It simply isn't 
feasible to make sure your hardware violates no patents out there already.

If they released the source code to their drivers, everybody would begin 
inspecting it for evidence of violations.  Regardless of whether or not there 
are any violations, they're going to be sued.  As the only people to win in a 
lawsuite are the lawyers and consultants, that would cause nVidia to lose 
money even if they won the suites.  Guess who will foot that bill?

We, the consumers, will foot that bill.

So, look at it from nVidia's point of view.  Right now, they aren't losing a 
significant number of customers because of their closed-source driver model.  
What happens if they open their drivers?  They get sued.  They have to raise 
prices.  They lose more customers than they gain.  How does this make good 
business sense?

Rob

If I make a db_access class, with you know, queries, return values, connections to the db server, etc.
And I make a "tasks" class with deadlines, tasks, id numbers, etc, what is the approved way to have tasks use the database. Should make a base class that includes the db stuff, and then extend it for various other classes, should I instance that db class when I instance the other classes 

i mean this:
class Foo(){
  var bar;
  function Foo(){
   $this->bar = new db_class;
 }
}

These ways seem fairly weighty to swing around when I instance code, and it seems like I'd have a lot of extra connections to the database.

Any suggestions/best practivces?

From danh at fork.com  Fri Jun  4 11:36:02 2004

Date: Fri Jun  4 11:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] PHP OOP Programming question
In-Reply-To: <060420040347.3159.40BFF0E000081E3400000C5722007358349B029A08020E03040709@comcast.net>

On Fri, 4 Jun 2004 gilmanhunt at comcast.net wrote:

> If I make a db_access class, with you know, queries, return values,
> connections to the db server, etc. And I make a "tasks" class with
> deadlines, tasks, id numbers, etc, what is the approved way to have
> tasks use the database. Should make a base class that includes the db
> stuff, and then extend it for various other classes, should I instance
> that db class when I instance the other classes

Have you looked at PEAR? It's designed to be "a framework and distribution
system for reusable PHP components." More to the point, it has a
standardized database interface. Theoretically, you could code an
application to use one DMBS and later switch to another without a lot of
effort. I say "theoretically", because I have not done it yet myself. :)

Dan





From gepr at tempusdictum.com  Fri Jun  4 12:01:02 2004
From: gepr at tempusdictum.com (gepr at tempusdictum.com)
Date: Fri Jun  4 12:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] PHP OOP Programming question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0406041129500.4293-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
References: <060420040347.3159.40BFF0E000081E3400000C5722007358349B029A08020E03040709@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.21.0406041129500.4293-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
Message-ID: <16576.47332.125942.532647@eris.dischordia.net>

Dan Haskell writes:
 > 
 > On Fri, 4 Jun 2004 gilmanhunt at comcast.net wrote:
 > 
 > > deadlines, tasks, id numbers, etc, what is the approved way to have
 > > tasks use the database. Should make a base class that includes the db
 > 
 > Have you looked at PEAR? It's designed to be "a framework and distribution
 > system for reusable PHP components." More to the point, it has a
 > standardized database interface. Theoretically, you could code an
 > application to use one DMBS and later switch to another without a lot of
 > effort. I say "theoretically", because I have not done it yet myself. :)

This is good advice.  I have two things to add:

1) There is no "approved" way of using "safe" scripting environments
   like PHP (and it's ilk).  Those tools were created for (and are
   best for) relatively small jobs where you're trying to optimize 
   between so-so programmers, high throughput, and rapid development.

   So, this implies that the real answer is:  do whatever works.

2) If you're stuck in a position where you have to use a lightweight
   tool like PHP to do heavy lifting, then, by _any_ means necessary,
   jump on some bandwagon with a community of developers and use a
   set of tools that can be debugged, used, and criticized by as
   large a number of people as possible.

   E.g. the only reason perl [cough] even _works_ is because there are
   so many people _involved_ in it.

And I'll throw in a piece of opinionated trash, too: If you want to
learn OOP, start with smalltalk ... or, maybe, Sather or Self.  Don't
pollute your thinking with garbage like Java, C++, PHP, Perl6, etc.
If, however, those obscure languages are not interesting and you
aren't inclined towards purity, pick something reasonable like Python.

--

M: 971.219.3846                               http://www.tempusdictum.com

> chunk of code to make that binary stuff work.
>

All I know, is that the video cards I have used over the years, have all
been supported by X, no kernel modules have been needed.  But of course
I'm not a l337 gamer.  I do not believe that patents are the real reason
that Nvida refuses to provide the information needed for drivers to be
written, unless they really are violating somebodies valid patent.  I
think they a just paranoid and afraid that is anybody actually saw their
design they would laugh.  I see it all the time companies are so
convinced that they have some magic jewel of a technique that gives them
a leg up on everybody else, and they are almost always wrong.  In every
case, it would be easier to implement the functionality from scratch,
based on public knowledge, that it would be to aquire the magic jewels.

> application to use one DMBS and later switch to another without a lot of
> effort. I say "theoretically", because I have not done it yet myself. :)

On Friday 04 June 2004 01:12 pm, Michael Robinson wrote:

> Who is working to convince companies that there's an advantage to producing
> publicly designed hardware?  What research has been done on this approach
> to demonstrate that a given company won't go bankrupt or fail to produce a
> superior product?  It's fun to poke at companies that keep secrets, but do
> companies have any other option?  Proprietary hardware wouldn't be such a
> big problem if there was proprietary hardware designed to work with Linux
> and X.

I think it's hard to make money on a product if the design is public in the 
same sense OSS software is public.  There would likely be a lot of 
innovation, I think, but the only thing a company could do would be 
manufacturing the hardware...

It might be neat, but I think it would be a mess.

There was some discussion on the LKML a while back about what it would take to 
get a group of hardware and software engineers together to design a video 
card for Linux that would do as good a job as ATi and nVidia do... it was 
deduced they likely *could* do it, but one of the lower end cards would cost 
upwards of 3-4 times the cost of the current ATi and nVidia cards (which are, 
BTW, not very inexpensive).

Rob



From ehem at m5p.com  Fri Jun  4 15:11:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] A bit confused about 2.6 kernel and X drivers

> From: Brian Beattie <beattie at beattie-home.net>
> 
> Why is this not a problem for ATI?  I don't buy it for one second.

That would be an excellent argument; except it is a problem for ATi.
There is an open source driver for ATi's cards, however, as with the open
source nVidia driver, the open source ATi driver is *strictly* 2D, none
of the 3D capabilities. If you want to make use of the 3D capabilities,
you must go for a binary-only module.


> From: Brian Beattie <beattie at beattie-home.net>
> On Fri, 2004-06-04 at 11:26, AthlonRob wrote:
> > On Friday 04 June 2004 08:08 am, Brian Beattie wrote:
> > > Why is this not a problem for ATI?  I don't buy it for one second.
> > I haven't looked at ATi cards for quite some time... but when last I did,=
> > their drivers worked similarly to nVidia's... a chunk of binary-only and =
> > chunk of code to make that binary stuff work.
> > Are their drivers fully opensource now?
> 
> All I know, is that the video cards I have used over the years, have all
> been supported by X, no kernel modules have been needed.  But of course
> I'm not a l337 gamer.  I do not believe that patents are the real reason
> that Nvida refuses to provide the information needed for drivers to be
> written, unless they really are violating somebodies valid patent.  I
> think they a just paranoid and afraid that is anybody actually saw their
> design they would laugh.  I see it all the time companies are so
> convinced that they have some magic jewel of a technique that gives them
> a leg up on everybody else, and they are almost always wrong.  In every
> case, it would be easier to implement the functionality from scratch,
> based on public knowledge, that it would be to aquire the magic jewels.

No commentary on whether the patents are valid (non-obvious and
non-trivial).

They provide enough information for a 2D driver (well not exactly, they
wrote the 2D driver and have no problem with that being open source).
Just nVidia does not provide information on utilizing the 3D capabilites,
but then again no one else does either. If open source is the critical
factor for you, the driver is "nv"; no problems with 4K stacks, no evil
closed source; but you sacrifice the (software 3D works, but is hideously
slow in comparison with hardware).

Looking at the companies involved, it does seem likely they've got those
magic jewels. They're large enough to hire very smart people, and create
very fast and efficient hardware and software.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Fri Jun  4 15:14:02 2004
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Jun  4 15:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Slackware-9.1 network connection problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406041420410.28568@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406041420410.28568@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200406041513.00300.athlonrob@axpr.net>

On Friday 04 June 2004 02:31 pm, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Since the last clinic -- the one devoted to WiFi -- I've not been able to
> get eth0 working. It used to be there when the system booted. Now the
> "network is unreachable" and both 'netstat -rn' and 'route' show loopback
> but no eth0. /etc/hosts is fine (I had to rebuild it after re-running
> 'netconfig'). The static IP address, netmask and default gateway are all in
> /etc/rc.d/rc.inet1.conf under eth0. I checked the cable for fully-seated
> plugs on both ends; they are. I even moved the cable from one port on a
> switch to another port on a different switch.

If you're using a static IP, Slackware essentially just runs ifconfig and 
route for you...

Can you manually run the appropriate ifconfig and route commands and see what 
happens?  Something like:

# ifconfig eth0 192.168.1.15 netmask 255.255.255.0
# route add default gw 192.168.1.1

...then test your connectivity.

What does the output from ifconfig and route -n look like?  On ifconfig look 
for bytes tx and rx, the IP address, and the netmask.  Under route -n, look 
at the default gateway (0.0.0.0) and what interface it is assigned to.  If 
you're playing with your wireless connection, check iwconfig for an access 
point and signal strength.

Rob

Sorry, closed source means people's computers often don't work and they 
don't know
why.  You can't prevent someone else from growing an apple for example, 
but this does
not mean that having an orchard is nonprofitable.  The problem is 
clearly patent law,
noone should be able to sue someone else for using a common idea.  I 
also feel that
the outsourcing of valuable jobs by companies importing or exporting 
goods needs
to be limited.  We should not let any company this country does business 
with outsource
more than 30% of it's well paid jobs.  If all coding does end up in 
India, I hope
Al-Queda doesn't catch on and send operatives there to work.  No matter 
where you are
in the world, you have a right to be a coder, janitor, farmer, etc. 
 Countries should compete,
they shouldn't outsource instead.

These very smart people do things in ways the not-so-smart world doesn't 
understand.
What happens when those people die?  

What if I patented say, some popular mailing list software?  Would this 
mean that everyone
who has a mailing list using that software has to pay me to keep it? 
 What judge would
render such a misguided verdict?  Is there any legal approach to rein in 
patent law abuse
so that open source hardware becomes possible again?  The Commodore 64 
was open
design.  If you hand Joe blow the schematics to a complex video card he 
can't profit
from them as easily as someone who knows what they are.  Joe blow will 
also need
a billion dollars or more if he wants to build a factory and start 
producing them himself.  
One of the reasons Microsoft has been declared a monopoly is that noone 
can get a
proprietary system up to the same level economically before Microsoft 
partially or
completely owns that system.  Microsoft classically either buys you out 
or sues you
out.  Perhaps it's about time that the judges who make this possible 
felt our pain.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jun  4 17:45:03 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Jun  4 17:45:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] A bit confused about 2.6 kernel and X drivers
In-Reply-To: <200406041508.07095.athlonrob@axpr.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406031009530.2902-100000@www.fnordora.org>
 <1086375949.878.18.camel@kokopelli> <40C0D7AB.5060700@robinson-west.com>
 <200406041508.07095.athlonrob@axpr.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0406041736360.2234@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 4 Jun 2004, AthlonRob wrote:
> I think it's hard to make money on a product if the design is public in
> the same sense OSS software is public.

Yeah, could you imagine manufacturing something that isn't patented and
expecting to turn a profit?  Like, say you wanted to make dining tables or
sewing needles or clipboards or something and you didn't have a patent
that gave you exclusive control over the technology, what would you do?
You couldn't possibly stay in business making things without a state
monopoly.

Oh, wait...

[Yes, this IS a trickier issue than that.  The fact appears to be that
free markets cannot innovate AND benefit the public.]

> There would likely be a lot of innovation, I think, but the only thing a
> company could do would be manufacturing the hardware...

There wouldn't be innovation because there wouldn't be a profit to justify
the R&D.  You either would have to keep your research results a secret
(and, therefore, not open source your drivers to hide your precious
secrets) or publish your research results and have the wealthiest folks in
your sphere of manufacture (or extremely wealthy people outside of your
industry) beat you in the marketplace.

(The answer, of course, is to remove the means by which wealth is
accumulated and thus redefine "the marketplace".)

> It might be neat, but I think it would be a mess.

No doubt.  Welcome to the death throes of market capitalism (which might
actually be the greatest victory of market capitalism and the death throes
of civilization).

J.

With  true capitalism there's competition.  The computer hardware 
industry isn't
a competitive one.  This is suggested by the idea that only a few very 
smart people
can build 3D video cards.  In a competitive sector, there would be more 
than just
a few really smart people.  I hope we're not in the not so smart crowd, 
guess we'll
have to ask Rob about that.  Either we have to be smart or make do with poor
Linux support for today's fanciest video hardware.  I don't see an 
alternative
where this thread doesn't appear to be on track to finding one.

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Sat Jun  5 10:02:01 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Sat Jun  5 10:02:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Quoting multiline system() commands in Perl
In-Reply-To: <409964FF.4060507@robinson-west.com>
References: <409964FF.4060507@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1086454976.6025.12.camel@timmy>

On Wed, 2004-05-05 at 15:04, Michael Robinson wrote:
> I have a long system command I write this way in a perl script.
> 
> `/sbin/iptables ...`
> 
> I want to write this over multiple lines so that my script is more readable.

If you need the output (but AFAICT, there never is any from iptables),
you can do this:

$command = '/sbin/iptables ....' .
' .... ' .
' .... ';

$output = `$command`;

If you don't need the output, this is probably preferable:

system('/sbin/iptables ... ' .
' .... ' .
' .... ');

This really boils down to how to quote multiline strings. When using the
string in system() or backticks, the newlines are interpreted as command
separators, so you have to get rid of them:

$command = '/sbin/iptables ...
...
...';

$command =~ s/\n/ /g;

You can also write it like this (which doesn't appear to work with
backticks):

$command = '/sbin/iptables ... \
... \
...';

I hope one of these works for you.

Evan

PS: Your date is messed up.

Interesting find. I'm left wondering how complete the drivers are. It

modern cards can do vertex transformation in hardware, I'm unsure whether
that is supported. Certainly that is well understood and not encumbered
by patents, however all the interesting features of modern cards are
affected.

Depends on the wireless switches - If they are just a switch, then it 
would not matter - but if the are providing NAT or DHCP (wireless 
router) then it does. Realistically though you really should put the 
wireless switch of a seperate leg of the firewall.

me it use (and abuse) his wireless network.  Now he has an old p75 as a 
firewall and a lot more security.

begin electrogrammati illius Rich Shepard
>   I just finished installing qpopper on my server/workstation. This was a
> recommeded replacement for the default pop3 server that wasn't providing
> mail to my fiancee's machines running (now) mozilla-mail.
> 
>   Is there any test I can run from here to see if it's working? How about a
> diagnostic protocol if it's _not_ working?

Sure, you can test by telnetting to the pop server at its port
(default 110): issue the initial telnet command, as below, and when
it replies type in the "USER" and "PASS" and "LIST" commands like
in the below example; if working it will let you login and display
any msgs. on the server.

you at client$ telnet server 110
Trying 192.168.1.2...
Connected to pop3.foo.bar.
Escape character is '^]'.
+OK Solid POP3 server ready
USER myusername
+OK username accepted
PASS mypass 
+OK authentication successful
LIST
+OK scan listing follows

<SNIP>

> TIA,
> 
> Rich

-jm

If you get memory on E-Bay where the seller says it's good, or that it's 
so much, and a number of the
modules turn out to be bad, is it best to complain to them directly via 
email or is posting
negative feedback called for?

A lot of these items are so cheap.  The shipping is so high that sending 
them back isn't really a good
option.  How can they know to refund you if there's no way for the goods 
to be inspected by them,
because it's too costly to send them back?

With E-Bay's feedback system, it looks like someone could easily post 
feedback for the wrong item.
Due to the fact that feedback is irretractible, a negative statement is 
awfully strong.  Thanks to the
buyer apparently risking a lower score from negative feedback, It seems 
that fraud is encouraged
because complaints cost the buyer points.  

I've been trying to add memory to my Linux servers.  Looking for 30 pin 
4 meg simms and 168
pin PC100/133 256 meg DIMM's, it's hard to find these locally at a good 
price.  If I wasn't being
shipped goods from New York, etc., I could return them.  With $6-$12 
shipping fees, I don't
want to do that with  low cost items.

Subject: [PLUG] Mail access from laptop on the LAN

  I've made a discovery with the inability of my fiancee to access mail from
her laptop by turning on 'telnet' at the server. When the MUA tries to
connect to 'mail.appl-ecosys.com', the connection is attempted to the
external IP address. And, I have port 110 shut on the firewall.

  Is there a way to configure a MUA to look on a local host? I've tried
telling it to use just the host name and the non-world-readable, class C IP
address but without success. Or, is there a user-transparent way to ssh in
to the network and access mail that way?

  I realize now why there's no problem from the networked workstation: that
has /var/spool/mail nfs-exported and mounted. D'oh! So, unless told
otherwise, I believe I've identified the problem. However, I've no idea how
to solve this one. FWIW, I don't have this problem on my notebook because
when I'm away from the office I ssh into the network then read mail on the
server, not locally on the portable.

TIA,

Rich

I think I have a bag (probably ~50 sticks) of 30 pin ram somewhere. If you
want it, I'll look for it.

Contact the bidder, at least give them a chance to redeem themselves. You
can always post negative feedback and let ebay know that the items were
broken, etc, if the seller is an ass. (Probably get your money back too)
You have a limited amount of time to file a fraud claim.

I suppose running memtest86 would be a good idea, just to have some evidence
that the ram is bad. I'm assuming it is being detected, etc. There were too
many damn problems with ram compatibility years ago (fuck dell).

USPS ships priority in their 1 rate envelope for $3.50 nationwide, you can
fit a _lot_ of stuff in one of those envelopes with a lot of padding. I've
managed to fit nics wrapped in 2 layers of the big bubble wrap into one of
them.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Mon Jun  7 16:36:02 2004
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Mon Jun  7 16:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Mail access from laptop on the LAN
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406071605320.23482@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406071605320.23482@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040607233551.GD10381@rauhaus.org>

* Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> [040607 16:13]:
>   I've made a discovery with the inability of my fiancee to access mail from
> her laptop by turning on 'telnet' at the server. When the MUA tries to
> connect to 'mail.appl-ecosys.com', the connection is attempted to the
> external IP address. And, I have port 110 shut on the firewall.

If you are running your own dns server, you could use bind's "views"
feature to have queries for mail.appl-ecosys.com that come from
internal lan hosts answered with the internal, private address for your
mail host.

You'll need to do some reading up on how to do it, but your named.conf
would go something like this:

view "internal" {
	match-clients { 192.168.1.0/24; };
	...other options...

	zone "appl-ecosys.com" {
		type master;
		file "/var/named/db.appl-ecosys.internal";
	};

view "external" {
	match-clients { any; };
	...other options...

	zone "appl-ecosys.com" {
		type master;
		file "/var/named/db.appl-ecosys.external";
	};

--Stafford

From Rob.Anderson at nike.com  Mon Jun  7 16:47:02 2004
From: Rob.Anderson at nike.com (Anderson, Rob (Global Trade))
Date: Mon Jun  7 16:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for opinions on E-Bay disputes...
Message-ID: <200406072345.i57Njg7i026307@barrierb241.nike.com>

> With E-Bay's feedback system, it looks like someone could easily post 
> feedback for the wrong item.

Feedback must be related to an auction, so this is unlikely.

> Due to the fact that feedback is irretractible, a negative 
> statement is 
> awfully strong.  Thanks to the
> buyer apparently risking a lower score from negative 
> feedback, It seems 
> that fraud is encouraged
> because complaints cost the buyer points.  

I think you should at least give the seller the chance to make the situation right. I don't think that buyers will not leave negative feedback when it is due, for fear of retaliatory negative feedback from the seller. Sure it happens, but when I am reviewing feedback for a person and I see a negative, I will drill down and look at the feedback of the person who left the negative feedback, to determine if it was retaliatory or not. I have had several bad experiences, where I have left negative feedback and the seller has not retaliated with negative feedback. I have also had several potentially bad experiences, where I have contacted the seller and they have corrected the situation and ultimately received positive feedback for following through and not blowing me off after getting paid.

-Rob A

Even if local root is not compromised, if your name server is
compromised, your identity can be hijacked. Just think if paypal.com
is diverted to some site that sniffs your password information and
then snags all your money.

BIND's track record is miserable. tinydns's track record is perfect
(and backed by a money guarantee).

* Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> [040607 17:56]:
> On Mon, 7 Jun 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> 
>   Whoa! Halt! Cease! Desist! And cut it out, guys. My question has to do
> with getting my fiancee's mail to her laptop when connected to the local
> LAN. Let's not head off down a side path into oblivion of the original
> question.

Seconded. I also would be surprised if tinydns didn't offer something
similar to bind's views option.

Another option, and this may have been mentioned already, would be to
modify your firewall rules to allow pop connections from your internal
lan to your external interface address.

Depending on what the order of operations is, i.e. nat first then check
rules, or check rules then nat, you might need something like "allow tcp
source_ip $external_nat_address destination_ip $external_nat_address
port pop3".

--Stafford

Rich,

On Mon, 2004-06-07 at 17:12, Rich Shepard wrote:

> server address with the same dot-quad number, attempts to fetch mail from

Is the client or the server displaying this message?  The log file on
the server should give you a lot more information, unless the qpopper
daemon isn't running at all. 
> 
>   Any ideas where I look to see just what's closing the connection? I think
> I can safely assume we're no longer trying to connect to the external IP
> address 'cause outgoing mail (tested by sending me a message by her) seems
> to be working.

You really should try to telnet from the laptop to the pop3 port on the
server.  This is a very good reality check.  I have set up several LAN's
where the pop3 server (qpopper) is accessed by ip address rather than
host name and they have always worked (still are as a matter of fact).

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

Message-ID: <86zn7dg8od.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   Allow me to correct this: I've gone at least part of the way
Rich> through the GUIDE.pdf's configuration section. I assume that I
Rich> want stand-alone mode rather than Internet mode; if so, do I
Rich> enable entries in either or both of /etc/inetd.conf and
Rich> /etc/services?

/etc/services is just an association table (names to numbers), like
/etc/hosts.  If there is a pop3 entry in /etc/inetd.conf then you
won't see a running daemon in your process list unless someone is
actively connected to the pop server.  The inetd "superserver" daemon
will launch the program speicifed by /etc/inetd.conf for you when
someone tries to connect to that port.

Daemon mode is better if you are trying to debug the server program
because you have more control over how it starts, can attach a
debugger to the process, etc.  But otherwise, in your situation it
doesn't make that much difference which you use.

From guy1656 at ados.com  Wed Jun  9 00:49:02 2004
From: guy1656 at ados.com (GLL)
Date: Wed Jun  9 00:49:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Confusion about scsi standards...
In-Reply-To: <40C65A06.3040406@robinson-west.com>
References: <40C65A06.3040406@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <200406090056.50075.guy1656@ados.com>


Does the scsi cable have a TERMINATOR on it?
Depending on your configuration, an SE/LVD terminator may be necessary.
Most SE/LVD terminators out nowadays run up to U320 speeds.

The problem is if you include an SE device into the bus. Then the whole bus 
has to drop out of hyperspace (LVD mode) and play in 80-ohm single end mode.

Consider it like a Hi-IQ club party or a high shop-talk party, and along comes 
Gomer and Harriette. It's impolite not to include them in conversation, but 
now no one's talking about Sekigahara, Degas, Dali, Bohr, Hofstader, what's 
in /bin,  Bronowski, etc - everyone has to drop down to talking about sports, 
the weather, and how the kids are doing.

- GLL

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Wed Jun  9 01:25:03 2004
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Wed Jun  9 01:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] What is causing a "Device not ready" error message.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406071224570.2937@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0406082146300.30326-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Mon, 7 Jun 2004, David Mandel wrote:

>
> My system has been working great, until ....
>
> I have been playing around with usb thumbdrives, usb cammeras, music CDs,
> and I have been removing and adding hard drives.
>
> This shouldn't be a problem, except SuSE 9.0 trys to automate things
> (a bit like Microsoft does) and this can lead to problems.
> At the moment, my /var/log/messages file is getting lots of
> messages like:
>
>     Jun  7 12:09:13 sco302 kernel: Device not ready.  Make sure there is a  disc in the drive.
>     Jun  7 12:09:44 sco302 last message repeated 12 times
[13 more examples snipped]
>
> Unfortunately, nothing seems to give me a straight forward
> indication of what drive is causing the problem.
>
> Anyone have a quick idea of what might be wrong?
>
Dave, have you checked the /etc/fstab file? It may have been that when
you mounted a USB device (or one of those other objects) that somehow
SuSE decided to help you by adding an entry to the fstab. (I know that
adding a SCSI device requires using the mount command.)

If that's clean, look to see what has changed lately in the /etc directory.
On my antique RH box, Linux keeps track of what gets mounted where in the
/etc/mtab file -- which I determined by running ``ls -lt /etc".

And if someone else hasn't offered the right answer by the time you
read this, I guess the solution is hiding somewhere in the man page
for mount -- or a related command.

Geoff

From ehem at m5p.com  Wed Jun  9 11:30:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Wed Jun  9 11:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Confusion about scsi standards...
In-Reply-To: <20040609134208.30347.38364.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200406091828.i59ISpcv000326@m5p.com>

> From: Michael Robinson <plug_0 at robinson-west.com>
> 
> I'm looking into why I'm getting IO errors with my scsi drives.  
> Thinking it's a bad cable, I now wonder if I need a newer card
> that is more recent on the LVD/se standards?  The drives are Compaq 
> MODEL MA3043LP.  The label says Wide Ultra 2 scsi. 

These drives new? Do the drive labels say "LVD" or differential?

If not most likely those are non-differential 40MB/s drives.

> Looking this up on google, I'm a bit surprised to run into the 29160 
> adaptec controller.  It supposedly operates at 160,
> twice the 2940U2W's 80 speed.  What happens if I plug a drive meant for 
> ultra 2 wide 160 into an ultra 2 wide 80
> controller?  Does the drive merely run slower?  These 68 pin LVD cables, 
> what the difference between an Ultra 320
> one versus an Ultra 160 one, etc.?  can I buy a cable for a newer scsi 
> card that's 68 pin and use it on an older one?

They all use LVD, and the same cables. The difference is simply how fast
they can transfer data. Devices on the bus that can't handle the higher
speeds will force the bus to operate at slower speeds, but otherwise
_that_ won't cause any problems.

What will cause problems is that it sounds like you've got
non-differential drives, and a differential controller. This won't work,
10/20MB/s and first generation 40MB/s SCSI were non-differential, but
later 40MB/s and all 80MB/s drives and controllers operate strictly with
differential signalling. Unfortunatly both 40MB/s non-differential and
the differential hardware use 68-pin cables. If this is the case you
don't need a more recent controller, but an older one (actually I've got
such a controller, but I don't have the right drives; sorry on
motherboard, so I can't hand it off).

From raanders at acm.org  Wed Jun  9 11:56:03 2004
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed Jun  9 11:56:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Confusion about scsi standards...
In-Reply-To: <200406091828.i59ISpcv000326@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0406091148300.13908-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Wed, 9 Jun 2004, Elliott Mitchell wrote:

> What will cause problems is that it sounds like you've got
> non-differential drives, and a differential controller. This won't work,
> 10/20MB/s and first generation 40MB/s SCSI were non-differential, but
> later 40MB/s and all 80MB/s drives and controllers operate strictly with
> differential signalling. Unfortunatly both 40MB/s non-differential and
> the differential hardware use 68-pin cables. If this is the case you
> don't need a more recent controller, but an older one (actually I've got
> such a controller, but I don't have the right drives; sorry on
> motherboard, so I can't hand it off).

If it is a 29160 SCSI host adapter then there are three buses and I
believe you can use upto two of them at once.  On my 29160 I have LVD 160 
and LVD 320 hard drives on the LVD HP68-pin bus (?) and a tape and CD-R on 
the 50-pin SCSI/Wide SCSI bus.  The hard drives run at 160 tops and the 
tape and CD-R at 5 and 10.
   This is the reason I bought a 29160 (based on a recommendation from 
this list :-).


Rod
-- 
    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"

From aaron at bavariati.org  Wed Jun  9 16:27:02 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Wed Jun  9 16:27:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Converting old laptop to portable monitor and keyboard
In-Reply-To: <1086751902.23231.10.camel@timmy>
References: <1086751902.23231.10.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040609232618.GA14263@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Jun 08, 2004 at 08:31:42PM -0700, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> I have a very old machine here (Thinkpad 760L, type 9547, model U0A)

Cool, P-90 with 8MB standard and a 640x480 color display.
I was just thinking of making a Compaq Aero 4/25 run Linux.

> Is this even remotely possible? I don't care if it's extremely
> difficult, just as long as it's possible. This is just a project, so I'm
> not interested in things I could buy.

It is remotely possible.  And I mean *remotely*.  After figuring out the
protocol, you'd need to program a microcontroller to read the keyboard
and spit out PS/2 keycodes, then build another, high-powered
microcontroller with several hundred KB of RAM (framebuffer) and three
high-speed A/D converters to digitize the analog VGA signal and convert
it to the appropriate commands for the display.

This is, in fact, a FAQ that has been around since laptops were new.
I'd have said to STFW, but it was fun coming up with a serious answer.

> To test that the screen and keyboard are working correctly, I want to
> get into the BIOS of the laptop itself. What's the key combination for
> that?

Hold down F1 while turning the machine on.

Good luck,
  Aaron

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jun  9 23:51:02 2004

Date: Wed Jun  9 23:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Apache access control question
Message-ID: <20040610065038.EB36B8F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

I'm confused about access control under Apache (2.0).  What determines the
default access control?  For example, if I have an entry in httpd.conf
like the following, what sets the access control for /var/www/icons?

Alias /icons/ "/var/www/icons/"

<Directory "/var/www/icons">
    Options Indexes MultiViews
    AllowOverride None
</Directory>


Ultimately what I would like to do is allow access to all of my web stuff
from 127.0.0.1 and 192.168.1.0/24 via http, and allow access to
selected directories from anywhere via https with basic auth.  I've
seen examples of this, but they would be easier to follow if I understood
how access control picks up its defaults, as well as whether there
is any scoping or inheritance of permissions.  Note that I'm not
planning to use htaccess files.

thanks,
galen

> default access control?  For example, if I have an entry in httpd.conf
> like the following, what sets the access control for /var/www/icons?
> 
> Alias /icons/ "/var/www/icons/"
> 
> <Directory "/var/www/icons">
>     Options Indexes MultiViews
>     AllowOverride None
> </Directory>

You have no auth or access control directives here, so /var/www/icons
will inherit the directives from higher-level directories. If you don't
have any such directives in your httpd.conf at all, then AFAIK the
defaults are to allow access from anywhere.

> Ultimately what I would like to do is allow access to all of my web stuff
> from 127.0.0.1 and 192.168.1.0/24 via http, and allow access to
> selected directories from anywhere via https with basic auth.  I've
> seen examples of this, but they would be easier to follow if I understood
> how access control picks up its defaults, as well as whether there
> is any scoping or inheritance of permissions.  Note that I'm not
> planning to use htaccess files.

This document is probably what you want:

http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/howto/auth.html

Off the top of my head, something like this would do what you want:

<VirtualHost *:80>
 DocumentRoot /var/www/docroot
 
 <Location />
  Order deny,allow
  Deny from all
  Allow from 127.0.0.1 192.168.1.0/24 
  # You can replace this stuff with iptables rules like these:
  # iptables -I INPUT -s 127.0.0.1 -j ACCEPT
  # iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -s ! 192.168.1.0/24 -j DROP
  # This will be more secure.
 </Location>

</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *:443> # for https
 DocumentRoot /var/www/public

 # Set up aliases here for other directories
 
 <Location />
  # Put AuthType and Require directives here
 </Location>

</VirtualHost>

Hope this works (I'm accustomed to Apache 1.3).

Evan

From allyn at well.com  Thu Jun 10 09:38:02 2004
From: allyn at well.com (Mark Allyn)
Date: Thu Jun 10 09:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] DHCP, DNS and Hostname
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F54HIRGOq7HNnV000cc490@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F54HIRGOq7HNnV000cc490@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.58.0406100933450.7693@well.com>

I think this is what you are looking for:

There is an entry in the dhcpd.conf file:
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
get-lease-hostname

    Directs dhcpd to provide a hostname to each client that is assigned a
dynamic address. Further, the hostname is to be obtained from DNS. This
parameter is a Boolean. If it is set to false, which is the default, the
client receives an address but no hostname. Looking up the hostname for
every possible dynamic address adds substantial time to the startup. Set
this to "false". Only set this to true if the server handles a very small
number of dynamic addresses.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

You should be able to set this boolean to true, along with setting
up DNS with pre-assigned host names for each DHCP issued IP address.

Something like these entries in the dns files might work:

$GENERATE 50-254 dhcp-$.devel A 192.168.4.$
(in the forward dns file)

and

$GENERATE 50-254 $ PTR dhcp-$.devel.fglan.
(in the reverse dns file)


I hope this helps

Mark Allyn

From allyn at well.com  Thu Jun 10 10:53:01 2004
From: allyn at well.com (Mark Allyn)
Date: Thu Jun 10 10:53:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] DHCP, DNS and Hostname
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F219PdgOVYjw8V00038610@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F219PdgOVYjw8V00038610@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.58.0406101013020.9945@well.com>

I think that some of the newer versions of dhcp and dns allows for dynamic
updating of DNS.

This has to be properly set up by those who have access to your DHCP and
DNS servers.

This required entries in the dhcpd.conf file on the dhcp server as
well as the zone file on the DNS server. Here is a very rough outline
for what you (or your admin) needs to do:

Get version 3 of the dhcp server if it is not allready installed.

do a:
dnssec-keygen -a HMAC-MD5 -b 128 -n USER DHCP_UPDATER
get a public/private key pair

Then put something like this in the dhcpd configuration file:

key DHCP_UPDATER {
  algorithm hmac-md5;
  secret pRP5FapFoJ95JEL06sv4PQ==;
};

zone allyn.com. {
  primary ns.allyn.com;
  key DHCP_UPDATER;
}

zone 17.127.10.in-addr.arpa. {
  primary ns.allyn.com;
  key DHCP_UPDATER;
}


Then put something like this in your dns (bind) config or zone files

key DHCP_UPDATER {
  algorithm hmac-md5;
  secret pRP5FapFoJ95JEL06sv4PQ==;
};

zone "allyn.com" {
	type master;
	file "allyn.com.db";
	allow-update { key DHCP_UPDATER; };
};

zone "17.10.10.in-addr.arpa" {
	type master;
	file "10.10.17.db";
	allow-update { key DHCP_UPDATER; };
};


Finally, you must ensure that the client (the pc) is configured to ask
that the dynamic DNS to use its name. That part I don't know how to do,
but it would be best to go to the OS's vendor's web site.

Truly

Mark Allyn

From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Jun 10 13:11:02 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu Jun 10 13:11:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] DHCP, DNS and Hostname
Message-ID: <200406102010.i5AKAkBu002748@citrine.spiritone.com>

Vincent Yau <v_yau3 at hotmail.com> wrote :

> Hello:
> 
> I am having some problems with DHCP and hostname and DNS...
> Appreciate if someone can offer some tips...
> 
> One of my boxes at work is running Linux and I am obtaining my IP from DHCP.
> It is my understanding that DHCP will also assign my box a hostname
> based what sysadmin set in the DNS record to associate with the given IP
> to a hostname.
> Last week, I upgraded to Fedora RC2 and for some odd
> reasons, my hostname is gone and I am given a generic one.
> Since then, I have had emails with the sysadmin abotu this problem.
> He claims that hostname is set in our company's DNS by picking
> up from what I set in my own box.  So effectively, I can pick whatever
> name I like and it will be my hostname and it will populate with the DNS 
> record.
> I found that puzzling but did it anyway.  And of course, nothing happen.
> I am still the generic hostname even though I have changed
> it everywhere (/etc/sysconfig/network ; /etc/hosts)
> 
> I am still unable to resolve my original hostname.  I keep telling the
> sysadmin that I think the name is dropped from the central DNS record
> somehow...
> 
> My question is, does DHCP really picks up hostname from client boxes
> when it assigns leases and set that in the company-wide DNS server?
> 
> --Vincent
> 

In file /etc/sysconfig/network put a line like this:

   DHCP_HOSTNAME=myhostname

This name will be reported to the DHCP server when you
get your IP address.

Older versions of Red Hat sent the HOSTNAME value but this
caused some problems. So this separate variable was created
so that you could control your DHCP host name separately
from your regular name.

You can also set DHCP_HOSTNAME in your each of your
interface files /etc/sysconfig/networks-scripts/ifcfg-*.
That way you can have a different DHCP host name for
each interface.

Terry

From alan at clueserver.org  Thu Jun 10 15:30:02 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Thu Jun 10 15:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Tying into the last question
In-Reply-To: <40C8DE34.1040700@mphpress.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406101425430.17592-100000@www.fnordora.org>

On Thu, 10 Jun 2004, Michael P. Hopcroft wrote:

>     I just realized there were several other pieces of equipment that go 
> into a computer that a custom-builder might not neccesarily know are 
> Linux-compatible.
>     IIs there a specific resource one can turn to that tracks the Linux 
> compatibility of various components, from printers to video cards to 
> sound cards to hard drives?

There used to be on SuSE's web site. I don't know if it is there anymore.

Avoid SiS chipsets on motherboards.  (Especially for AGP.) Everything else 
seems to work (That I know of.)

ATI video card are OK as long as you get an Radeon 8500 or better.  nVIDIA 
has drivers for most/all of its product line, but ATI does not.  (As I 
found buying an ATI Radeon 7000.  There are free drivers, but they do not 
do hardware acceleration wit the motherboard I have.)  If you just need 2d 
video, go with Matrox.  They have very fast video cards for 2d 
performance.

All the sound cards i have tried have worked, with the exception of a 
cmedia card.  That one is now supported by Fedora code 2.

Printers it is best to look at the gimp-print site and check what is 
supported.  Avoid anything that is a "windows printer".  (Goes the same 
for "winmodems".)

Hard drives are not an issue.  The only issue is size and the mherboard.  
Anything new should support LBA48.  (Larger than about 120 gigs.) SCSI 
drives are uncommon.  I have only seen one problem with scsi and that was 
actually a problem with a specific controller.  (Intel 440glx 
motherboard.)

The best thing to do is research what your customers need and narrow 
things down to boards that will meet those requirements.  The harder part 
is going to be finding motherboards that will not break within the first 
six months.

>From: Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
>Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
>To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
>Subject: Re: [PLUG] DHCP, DNS and Hostname
>Date: Thu, 10 Jun 2004 13:10:46 PDT
>
>Vincent Yau <v_yau3 at hotmail.com> wrote :
>
> > Hello:
> >
> > I am having some problems with DHCP and hostname and DNS...
> > Appreciate if someone can offer some tips...
> >
> > One of my boxes at work is running Linux and I am obtaining my IP from 
>DHCP.
> > It is my understanding that DHCP will also assign my box a hostname
> > based what sysadmin set in the DNS record to associate with the given IP
> > to a hostname.
> > Last week, I upgraded to Fedora RC2 and for some odd
> > reasons, my hostname is gone and I am given a generic one.
> > Since then, I have had emails with the sysadmin abotu this problem.
> > He claims that hostname is set in our company's DNS by picking
> > up from what I set in my own box.  So effectively, I can pick whatever
> > name I like and it will be my hostname and it will populate with the DNS
> > record.
> > I found that puzzling but did it anyway.  And of course, nothing happen.
> > I am still the generic hostname even though I have changed
> > it everywhere (/etc/sysconfig/network ; /etc/hosts)
> >
> > I am still unable to resolve my original hostname.  I keep telling the
> > sysadmin that I think the name is dropped from the central DNS record
> > somehow...
> >
> > My question is, does DHCP really picks up hostname from client boxes
> > when it assigns leases and set that in the company-wide DNS server?
> >
> > --Vincent
> >
>
>In file /etc/sysconfig/network put a line like this:
>
>    DHCP_HOSTNAME=myhostname
>
>This name will be reported to the DHCP server when you
>get your IP address.
>
>Older versions of Red Hat sent the HOSTNAME value but this
>caused some problems. So this separate variable was created
>so that you could control your DHCP host name separately
>from your regular name.
>
>You can also set DHCP_HOSTNAME in your each of your
>interface files /etc/sysconfig/networks-scripts/ifcfg-*.
>That way you can have a different DHCP host name for
>each interface.
>
>Terry
>
>
>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jun 10 16:12:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Jun 10 16:12:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for RH 7.3 RPM for POP3 server
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406101535030.1605-100000@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406101535030.1605-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406101606520.14699@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 10 Jun 2004, B. Thoen wrote:

> Can someone tell me the name of the RH 7.3 RPM that contains a pop3
> server? I just set up a new server, but pop3 wasn't included in the
> install and some old notes I have refer to imap-4.5-4.i386.rpm, but there
> is no rpm beginning with "imap" on my distribution disks. I did have it on
> my old 7.2 system (which got fried 2 days ago.)

Bill,

  Go to the Qualcomm Web site and grab a copy of qpopper-4.0.5 as a pop3
server. It's better than the default that came with RH 7.3. pop3 is good
when you (and any other users who get mail through your server) use a local
access and want to remove messages from the server after they've been read.

  IMAP is better for users who want to read messages from either local or
remote logins and on different hosts. The messages remain on the server so
they're available from a different host at a different time.

Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> On Thu, 10 Jun 2004, B. Thoen wrote:
> 
> > Can someone tell me the name of the RH 7.3 RPM that contains a pop3
> > server? I just set up a new server, but pop3 wasn't included in the
> > install and some old notes I have refer to imap-4.5-4.i386.rpm, but there
> > is no rpm beginning with "imap" on my distribution disks. I did have it on
> > my old 7.2 system (which got fried 2 days ago.)
> 
> Bill,
> 
>   Go to the Qualcomm Web site and grab a copy of qpopper-4.0.5 as a pop3
> server. It's better than the default that came with RH 7.3. pop3 is good
> when you (and any other users who get mail through your server) use a local
> access and want to remove messages from the server after they've been read.
> 
>   IMAP is better for users who want to read messages from either local or
> remote logins and on different hosts. The messages remain on the server so
> they're available from a different host at a different time.
>

> It was my understanding (from other Unix flavors)
> that when I want to add new stuff to be started at boot time,
> I put in a script in /etc/init.d and then symlink
> from /etc/rc<level>.d/
> 
> I just did, and symlink from /etc/rc3.d, /etc/rc2.d and /etc/rc4.d
> And then to verify, I typed
> 
>     /etc/rc 3
> 
> and my stuff did get started.
> So just did a reboot but none of my stuff was started...
> 
> Did I miss a step?  Why is it that I ran /etc/rc and the stuff was started
> but not when I power reboot the box?

I don't run Fedora, so I can't give you a direct answer. Check out
/etc/inittab to see what runlevel you're in and what init scripts it
runs when it boots. man inittab for more info.

> could download it, but downloading the entire directory simultaneously,

No, an ISO; like I said before, is a disk image. You're right, downloading 
directories would be a major hassle.
Grab one from here: http://unix.schluting.com/knoppix/

I'd recommend: http://unix.schluting.com/knoppix/KNOPPIX_V3.4-2004-05-04-EN.iso

Burn it to a CD (using nero, choose "burn image") then boot it. You don't have 
to install anything... once you're done using it, just remove it from your CD 
drive and boot windows again.

On Thu, 2004-06-10 at 16:08, Vincent Yau wrote:
> Hello:
> 
> I am running Fedora RC2 2.6.6 kernel.
> It was my understanding (from other Unix flavors)
> that when I want to add new stuff to be started at boot time,
> I put in a script in /etc/init.d and then symlink
> from /etc/rc<level>.d/
> 
> I just did, and symlink from /etc/rc3.d, /etc/rc2.d and /etc/rc4.d
> And then to verify, I typed
> 
>     /etc/rc 3
> 
> and my stuff did get started.

>

> but not when I power reboot the box?

On Red Hat/Fedora, you can save yourself the pain of manually managing
those symlinks with the 'chkconfig' command.  Are you booting into a
graphical login?  If so that's runlevel 5, which you didn't mention
making a link for.

Wil

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Jun 10 18:48:02 2004
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu Jun 10 18:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] rc startup script question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406101803300.15086@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0406101836410.23556-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Thu, 10 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Thu, 10 Jun 2004, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> 
> > > I just did, and symlink from /etc/rc3.d, /etc/rc2.d and /etc/rc4.d And
> > > then to verify, I typed

Did you name them with a 'S'nn at the beginning?  Most SystemV 
configurations (which Redhat and friends are) require/use the capital S 
for start and capital K for killing the script.


>   There's also 'chkconfig' on Red Hat-type systems. It will let you
> designate what services to run during which run levels. Very handy tool.

This requires (?) some special entry's (sp) at the top of the file (look
at some of the other files in /etc/init.d).  There is a semi-GUI 
interface to chkconfig system called 'ntsysv'.  This will show you what 
startup scripts Fedora knows of.

And if this sounds knowledgeable don't be fooled.  :-) I'm shooting from
the hip on some of this.  It has been a long time since I got into this
deeply.


Rod

From chris at maybe.net  Thu Jun 10 19:18:01 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Thu Jun 10 19:18:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] sony warrany
In-Reply-To: <18BC44CA28C2@loraksus.org>
References: <18BC44CA28C2@loraksus.org>
Message-ID: <20040611021708.GK2314@maybe.net>

On Thu, Jun 10, 2004 at 06:00:08PM -0700, Karol Kulaga wrote:
> God I hate damn tech support.

Here's how it actually works: Big company contracts out their tech
support to a company like Stream or Cyberrep. But they reward on the
basis of number of calls handled. So it is in Stream/Cyberrep's best
interest to handle as many calls as possible. So they train their
employees to meet a so-called "Average Handle Time" per call.[1] If you
miss your AHT, you're fired. Oddly, they still have a strong culture
of "you do a good job of helping people" (and humans want to do that
anyways) or you're fired.

It's *almost* worse than working at McDonald's for the poor people at
the bottom. Unfortunately, the environment drives some people to
develop "tricks" and "techniques" for ditching callers as fast as
possible. Most techs do try to be helpful, but the system actually
encourages them to abuse you.

[1] Actually, "train" is a strong word here. They don't actually give
their employees any skills to meet AHT -- they just throw the techs in
the deep end (often without even much of any practical training for
the product they're supposed to represent[2]) and assume the constant
flow of new bodies from turnover will keep the business running.

[2] It's not uncommon for a new hire to receive a week (or less) of
training. Even if they've never actually used computers before in
their life.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0406110527040.1325@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 10 Jun 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> On Thu, Jun 10, 2004 at 06:00:08PM -0700, Karol Kulaga wrote:
> > Hey, I just spoke with a sony csr and apparently they do not
> > Honor their warranty on products purchased for less than 75% of
> > MSRP.
> >
> > What the fuck? Has anyone else run into this or is this some
> > BS that I am being fed?
>
> That doesn't even make any sense -- Sony's already received their money
> from your retailer. It's the retailer that took it in the shorts selling
> it to you, eh?

It does if they're trying to fight gray-market goods.  Sony sells the same
products for less in poorer countries than it does in wealtheir countries.
The price set is determined more by "what the market will bear" than by
the actual cost of production and distribution.  It's not uncommon to see
discount stores selling goods purchased in another nation and shipped to
the US for resale for a hefty profit that are still well below MSRP.  Sony
(and other multinationals) do whatever they can to discourage this
behavior (going so far as to sue resellers for trademark infringement, if
you can believe that).

Anyway, I wouldn't be surprised if they DID have such a policy, but
covered it up and helped Karol anyway because of the fuss being made.

J.

Either of these could be the issue.

The Comcast folks have said publicly that they will start to block 
packets destined for port 25 on other machines if they think the 
machine in question is being used to send spam. Since Comcast's cable 
network is the source of huge amounts of spam, that's not a bad thing.

Also, some RBLs are pretty aggressive about labling Comcast networks 
as untrustworthy. As Rich himself told me one day, some of my messages 
had been marked as spam because they originate on a comcast.net 
network, even though I relay all outbound mail through 
smtp.comcast.net.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jun 11 06:58:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Jun 11 06:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast Bouncing Outbound Mail
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406110631260.19157@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406101955530.15927@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <200406102101.19639.ac7xc-lnx@wvi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406110601310.4336@pecos.madboa.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406110631260.19157@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406110645400.4336@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 11 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>  The problem does not originate at my end: the packets never make it 
> this far. Nothing is rejected by postfix, procmail or spamassassin. 
> They are blocked by a comcast MTA somewhere near the point of 
> origin.

OK. So you've got a remote (Joisey :-) correspondent on a Comcast 
network. When she sends you messages, most of them get returned saying 
there's a problem with the remote address (or something like that; I 
deleted the original problem description).

A few possibilities come to mind, some more likely than others:

1. The Comcast admins in Joisey have screwed up their local network.

2. Your correspondent has got some spyware or adware on her machine
    that is sending spam, and Comcast is blocking mail from her host.

3. The Comcast mail server used by your correspondent doesn't like to
    deliver directly to 216.99.x.x; maybe that's been identified as a
    dialup line or something like that.

4. Your remote correspondent is hand-addressing some of the messages
    in question and is misspelling your e-mail address.

Since my mail seems to get through to you, my hunch is that the 
Comcast network is probably configured correctly -- though I don't 
know if there are internal variations. Comcast bought most of its 
subsidiary networks, and there could still be struggles to get it 
configured consistently.

I'd be interested to see the entire SMTP error message returned by her 
mail server.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jun 11 07:48:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Jun 11 07:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: New Laptop
In-Reply-To: <20040610224002.3724.64872.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040610224002.3724.64872.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040611144719.GA26383@gate.kl-ic.com>

Marv wrote:
> I need a med priced laptop  $2500 range.
> Need to dual boot  deb/xp

1) Laptops are borrowed from factory service, not owned.  The laptop
may need service once a year.  Look for a company that does very rapid
repair, with no backtalk.  Good (formerly great):  IBM .  Very bad:
Dell.  HP/Compaq might be OK, very Linux conscious, no direct
experience.  No opinions beyond that.  Get the three year service
contract, subract that ($400?) from your starting price.

2) Internal/External Wifi:  built-in is supposedly convenient, but
it is very hard to specify chipset that way.  Atheros, Prism-2 good,
Cisco OK.  Everything else is poorly supported.  You get a lot more
options with a PCMCIA card - which can be moved around, sold, etc.

3) Dual boot:  Note recent issues with 2.6 Kernel and XP, described in
http://www.ces.clemson.edu/linux/fc2.html and elsewhere. 

4) If you travel a lot, or are otherwise more than a couple of hours
away from a charger, get a Valence N-Charge external battery for about
$300.

5) Extra chargers, or at least extra charger power cords, are a good
idea unless you like crawling around plugging and unplugging things.

You will find that, starting with a budget of $2500, you will be down
to $1500 by the time you pay for all the goodies that make laptop life
worth living.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun 11 12:30:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Jun 11 12:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast Bouncing Outbound Mail
In-Reply-To: <20040611184249.GP2314@maybe.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406101955530.15927@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <200406102101.19639.ac7xc-lnx@wvi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406110601310.4336@pecos.madboa.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406110631260.19157@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <20040611184249.GP2314@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406111223140.20855@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 11 Jun 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:

> Actually, if you're like me, your MTA is generating bounces for failed
> spam deliveries of a much higher volume.

Chris,

  Ah! You got me there; I forgot all about that.

> I find that we're generating 400-500 messages a DAY, at least, just trying
> to be RFC-compliant in the face of the tides of spam. It is soooooo
> tempting to turn off bounces sometimes.

  I am slowly modifying my postfix UCE rules to discard rather than reject.
When I discovered that I could route the junk to /dev/nul I started using
that option. I save the bandwidth of the rejection message and most of those
go to either spoofed addresses or to providers who don't seem to care.

  For the past several years I've been very dilligent about reporting spam
and doing my bit to keep the 'Net flowing. However, it's like pushing water
uphill and I know that my tiny contribution makes no difference in the
volume being transported. Ergo, discard rather than reject.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>
