On Fri, 2004-06-11 at 15:18, Aaron Ten Clay wrote:

> Actually, I believe PPP and IP are completely seperate protocols. I have
> used PPP without any IP at all in the past. (IPX only)
> 
> So it would be correct to say that the DHCP exchange takes place after the
> PPP session has been established.

No.  Yes, they are separable; PPP can negotiate network addresses  for
IPX, AppleTalk and probably other stuff too.  But no, it does not use
DHCP; it happens within PPP. See 'NCP' in the RFC:
http://www.zvon.org/tmRFC/RFC1661/Output/index.html

Wil

Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

On Thursday 10 June 2004 15:43, you hammered the keyboard to write:

<snip>

> P.P.S. What is the best way for someone who does not have a Linux
> machine to obtain multiple copies of the proper Linux distributionfor
> distribution to customers of a computer-building business?" Is it
> possible to download the install files of a Linux distribution without
> interfering with an existing OS?

<snip>

You are volunteering at Free Geek.  Their Thrift Store offers most Linux 
Disto's on CD for $2 per disk.  That is $6 - $8 per distro, and as a 
volunteer, you get a 50% discount.  What could be an easier way to get them?  
If you want to make your own copies you can do it with Linux or Windows, you 
just need a burner and software.  If you find cd-record in Linux too 
intimidating, you can install Linux Mandrake 10 or Fedora Core 2, which have 
the nice GUI K3B burner, where you can just click on the "copy cd" Icon.  On 
Windows, you can use EZ CD Creator, Nero, NTI, others, to copy CD's, it does 
not matter that they are Linux CD's you are copying on Windows.

If you need a computer with RedHat 9.0, or Fedora Core 2 preloaded, the store 
at Free Geek has about one or two computers available each week, priced 
around $80 (thats $40 to volunteers after discount).  Usually PIII 500 -550 
class, with 256M RAM, and the Disks come with them.

Rick Konold

As far as gaming goes, I've played Warcraft II using the XP Home that 
came with it.  I already hate XP.  McAffee that came with XP demanded to
be registered and put an annyoing window in my face I couldn't get rid 
of.  The moment it saw a network connection, XP assumed it could get to
the net.  Talk about a dumb assumption.   I've tried freeciv under 
Linux.  I have sound in Redhat and gentoo, though I've noticed mixer 
problems
in gentoo and occasional loss of sound with gnome saying that the card 
is busy or something.

I don't know if you can get bios and hardware design specs for Dell 
laptops.  It has been frustrating enough with this computer, I
wish I had thought more about their awful tv ads.  Laptop manufacturers 
need to inform buyers better about what is abnormal in
their products.

If you get a Thinkpad, be aware that some have problems even with 
Windows.  My brother-in-law's german thinkpad being a prime example.
You'll likely need to buy old to get that laptop that, "just works."  It 
seems the choice is: "new and powerful, but partially incompatible," 
verses,
"compatible, but old, slow, and some amount of screen wear."  The price 
for old, around $600 US, doesn't compete with new.  My laptop was
about $1100 US with a screen upgrade.  The better screen put it over 
$1000.  A web site, apparently put up by a PSU student who installed
debian on one of these, says not to go without the better screen.  I 
don't  know if Dell's are cheap because  compatibility corners are being 
cut,
or if it's just the 7 lbs of weight.  I wouldn't buy the m500, for that 
kind of money I'd seriously consider the ibook or a Toshiba laptop. 

Has Toshiba become Linux friendly with their laptops?  The companies 
that do will be rewarded.  Everybody wants a laptop that
works with the OS and software of "their" choice.

From chris at maybe.net  Sat Jun 12 01:15:03 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Sat Jun 12 01:15:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast Bouncing Outbound Mail
In-Reply-To: <87llitcj9p.fsf@ursine.ca>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406101955530.15927@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <200406102101.19639.ac7xc-lnx@wvi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406110601310.4336@pecos.madboa.com> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406110631260.19157@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <20040611184249.GP2314@maybe.net> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406111223140.20855@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <87llitcj9p.fsf@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <20040612081352.GS2314@maybe.net>

On Sat, Jun 12, 2004 at 12:44:50AM -0700, Paul Johnson wrote:
> Don't just silently drop messages on the floor, either accept them or
> reject them or you run a very real risk of losing legitimate mail that
> matched the spam filter.

Plus, in theory, it's possible that spam senders might interpret the
reject message and update their lists. Maybe.

> Except you're not saving any bandwidth doing it that way, and you're
> potentially sacrificing the reliability of your server for legit senders
> to do it.

To spell it out even more clearly for Rich:

* If you bounce, your mail server constructs a message and delivers it
to the "From:" address.

* If you reject, you send a 500-series SMTP code and the remote server
is responsible for forming a bounce message for its users. Nothing
more happens.

* If you drop, you send a 250 SMTP code and the other side thinks it
delivered the email successfully. This has the deleterious side
effects for potentially good mail that Paul mentioned, in addition to
making spam servers think they've got a live one.

Notice how between dropping and rejecting you *maybe* save 10 bytes
*during* the SMTP session by dropping -- depending on the length of
your server's human readable messages. That's it. No further server
load or network traffic whatsoever.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

Paul Johnson wrote:

>Bouncing or rejecting?  There is a difference, though I'm confused why
>any MTA would be bouncing messages to begin with instead of just
>rejecting them...
>
I can answer this...

I'm a backup mail server for another domain. My system accepts mail for 
the other domain, and then tries to deliver it to the destination.

If the destination rejects the message, then my system must bounce the 
message to the original server, to let the sender know that they didn't 
get through.

Russ

From aaron at bavariati.org  Sat Jun 12 16:31:10 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Sat Jun 12 16:31:10 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Converting old laptop to portable monitor and keyboard
In-Reply-To: <1086751902.23231.10.camel@timmy>
References: <1086751902.23231.10.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040609050349.GA9862@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Jun 08, 2004 at 08:31:42PM -0700, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> I have a very old machine here (Thinkpad 760L, type 9547, model U0A)

Cool, P-90 with 8MB standard and a 640x480 color display.
I was just thinking of making a Compaq Aero 4/25 run Linux.

> Is this even remotely possible? I don't care if it's extremely
> difficult, just as long as it's possible. This is just a project, so I'm
> not interested in things I could buy.

It is remotely possible.  And I mean *remotely*.  After figuring out the
protocol, you'd need to program a microcontroller to read the keyboard
and spit out PS/2 keycodes, then build another, high-powered
microcontroller with several hundred KB of RAM (framebuffer) and three
high-speed A/D converters to digitize the analog VGA signal and convert
it to the appropriate commands for the display.

This is, in fact, a FAQ that has been around since laptops were new.
I'd have said to STFW, but it was fun coming up with a serious answer.

> To test that the screen and keyboard are working correctly, I want to
> get into the BIOS of the laptop itself. What's the key combination for
> that?

Hold down F1 while turning the machine on.

Good luck,
  Aaron

From evanh at ant  Sat Jun 12 16:32:35 2004
From: evanh at ant (Debian User)
Date: Sat Jun 12 16:32:35 2004
Subject: [PLUG] debian discs won't mount
In-Reply-To: <409CFA05.8070509@brianquade.net>
References: <409CFA05.8070509@brianquade.net>
Message-ID: <20040508170131.GA2211@ant>

On Sat, May 08, 2004 at 08:17:25AM -0700, Brian Quade wrote:
> I downloaded all of the debian 30r2 disc images and used cdrecord to 
> burn the first image onto a disc.  I wanted to make sure that it 
> recorded correctly before I boot from it, so I tried to mount it and 
> look at what is on it.  But when I did a normal "mount /dev/scd0 
> /mnt/cdrom", I got 4 lines of output, the first said that /dev/scd0 is 
> an invalid argument, the second line said that the disc is read-only, 
> the third line was the same as the first, and the fourth said that I 
> must specify a filesystem type.  I used the Red Hat Hardware Browser and 
> verified that /dev/scd0 is the correct device for the cdrom drive.  So I 
> tried mounting again, this time giving it the command line option "-t 
> iso9660" even though that is supposed to be the default.  This time it 
> told me "wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/scd0, or too 
> many mounted file systems".  I tried a different disc image and the same 
> thing happened, so I don't think they got currupted in the download.  My 
> /etc/filesystems looks okay.  Another disc that I burned mounts fine 
> using the same mount command, so this has to be something with the 
> debian disc image.  Has anyone else downloaded and burned cd images of 
> debian 30r2?  What am I doing wrong?

You can check if there's a problem in the image without burning it with a
command like this:

# mount -t iso9660 -o loop cd-image.iso mount-point/

I have never done a CD-based install myself. I have always done network
installs. You end up downloading much smaller amounts of data and it's just
as easy as a CD install.

I also recommend the 'testing' distribution in preference to 'stable',
unless you are fanatical about security. The packages in testing are very
up-to-date but are not quite as bleeding-edge as 'unstable'. Stable packages
are often very old. Testing also has a very nice new installer:

http://www.debian.org/devel/debian-installer/

You will probably want the 50MB CD image for a network install.

Evan

On Sat, Jun 12, 2004 at 05:03:02PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   According to the man page I have for 'dump', it works with ext2. Will it
> also work with ext3 and reiserfs? Also, it's supposed to work with modern
> tape drives using hardware compression by not specifying a compression
> factor or medium capacity. Has anyone tried this?
> 
>   If I specify a 0-level backup of /, I presume that I get the entire

directly familiar). It will not work with nfs at all.

dump/restore are apparently very powerful and cool and all that, but
those of us in the "not-dump-thank-you" camp dislike it for its ties
to a specific filesystem. And that's all that needs to be said about
that flamewar, I think. (i.e., we have our sides, and we should remain
amicable.)

From ehem at m5p.com  Sat Jun 12 17:36:01 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sat Jun 12 17:36:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Zombie in my Linux box?
In-Reply-To: <20040612234802.1569.74199.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200406130034.i5D0Yxa7001139@m5p.com>

> From: "B. Thoen" <bthoen at gisnet.com>
> I noticed when I ran ps -aux this morning that the cron daemon had
> launched some root processes with the word "zombie" in them and later
> there was a ping to 216.115.108.243 followed by a "[ping <zombie>]." I
> don't like the look of this...  Then I tried to reboot. And couldn't.
> 
> Anyone know what this means when I try to reboot, and how to fix it?

This could be a number of things, bad software or bad hardware. Google
for "zombie process" would give you the story. Simply a process which has
terminated, but no one has wait()ed for/retrieved the return code. In
most cases either a shell or init is the one doing this. Zombies are
common, just most of the time they don't stick around long enough for you
to catch them with `ps` (though on machines with CS students taking an OS
courses they're *very* common  :-).

That zombie processes are hanging around long enough for you to spot them
is a bad sign. I'd tend to worry about questionable hardware first, then
a bad Linux installation, and finally some root kits cause software to
fail in this way. Start with running memtest, if you eliminate hardware,
then you'll be reloading (and reloading might be good anyway as your
installation could now be corrupt).


--

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat Jun 12 17:47:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sat Jun 12 17:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dump & restore
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406121659370.26710@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406121659370.26710@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3942-22201@sneakemail.com>

On Sat, 12 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard rshepard-at-appl-ecosys.com |PDX Linux|
wrote:

>   According to the man page I have for 'dump', it works with ext2. Will
> it also work with ext3 and reiserfs?

It works fine with ext3.  You would need a special dump designed for
reiserfs.  (I haven't used it, if it even exists.)

> Also, it's supposed to work with modern tape drives using hardware
> compression by not specifying a compression factor or medium capacity.
> Has anyone tried this?

This is only true if you have your tape devices set up "properly".  I've
never been able to get that working, so I use gzip compression.  ;-)

>   If I specify a 0-level backup of /, I presume that I get the entire
> filesystem (including nfs-mounted ones?) on one big volume on the tape. Is
> this correct?

Nope.  You tell dump the raw device to dump (e.g. /dev/Volume00/root,
/dev/hda3, /dev/md2, etc.) and it only dumps that.  If you have /, /home,
etc. you'll need a separate dump command for each one.

>   Anyone using dump & restore on linux?

Yep, every day!  ;-)

  -- Steve

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Jun 12 22:52:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat Jun 12 22:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dump & restore
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406121828180.26986@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406121659370.26710@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <20040613001246.GB3045@maybe.net>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406121828180.26986@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1087105917.11819.9.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Sat, 2004-06-12 at 18:32, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sat, 12 Jun 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> 
> > It will not work with reiserfs, and it only 'may' work with ext3 (not
> > directly familiar). It will not work with nfs at all.
> 
>   Harumph! That's no fun. So, ... what are folks to do who need to implement
> a low-cost backup strategy on a limited budget?

GNU tar support incremental backups; star is supposed to be pretty fast
and no doubt also supports incrementals.  Or, I could sell you a nice
copy of Microlite BackupEDGE for about $300, with a nice curses
interface, compression, and on-tape crypto. :)

dump was especially attractive in the days when tar couldn't do
incrementals; restore has a nice interactive interface that lets you
select specific files to restore.  dump was also rsh-aware, so it could
be used over a network.  (Naturally, GNU tar supports this also.)  I've
generally used dump, but I have some concerns over reliability, because
dump backs up at the filesystem layer and the newer Linux kernels
('newer' being 2.2 or so) have issues with buffer cache that make it
impossible to guarantee that a program like dump can read a consistent
raw filesystem.  These days, I'm personally using tar for my backups.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

On Saturday 12 June 2004 22:51, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Sat, 2004-06-12 at 18:32, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > On Sat, 12 Jun 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > > It will not work with reiserfs, and it only 'may' work with ext3
> > > (not directly familiar). It will not work with nfs at all.
> >
> >   Harumph! That's no fun. So, ... what are folks to do who need to
> > implement a low-cost backup strategy on a limited budget?
>
> [tar]
>
> [dump vs. tar]

Just to add to the fun, some filesystems like XFS have snapshot capability 
and that will give you a guaranteed non-changing view of the filesystem to 
copy out with anything from scp to rsync to tar.  Alternatively, you can 
use LVM in some cases to get snapshots.  If you have a dynamically 
changing system that needs to be all in sync for a backup to be meaningful 
(i.e. databases in general), then snapshots are very, very handy.

I like snapshots myself because (at least with some databases) you can get 
a clean database copy while it is live.  Very handy for those 4am 
emergency runs to the colo...

Best,
Kyle

It works through, as I understand it, CUPS or whatever print spooler you 
use.  Since it is being pretty heavily invested in my Mozilla.Org I'd bet 
so.  Here is the xprint page:

	http://www.mozilla.org/projects/xprint/

Though it needs a bit of grammar and spell checking (like I have room to 
criticize) it explains the goals.  Pretty loafty.

I have noticed that it doesn't support multiple copies, via Mozilla, out
of the box and I haven't taken the time to get it _really_ configured so I
can't say if this is a bug or pebkac. Still having access to both the
printers on my home network is great.  I have also noticed that multiple
printe jobs may have a pretty long pause between coming out.  I needed
eight copies of a HTML formated work sheet.  I printed it eight times 
heard the printer going.  Logged off and noticed that the printer was 
(appeared) finished and grabbed the sheets and ran.  Got to class and 
founbd I only had six copies.  Got home that evening and found the other 
two sitting on the printer.  Moral is (this far into the story) is don't 
print at the last minute and remember to count what you pick up.

Message-ID: <20040613175438.A7E5122156@john.meissen.org>

> "B. Thoen" <bthoen at gisnet.com> said:
> I noticed when I ran ps -aux this morning that the cron daemon had
> launched some root processes with the word "zombie" in them and later
> there was a ping to 216.115.108.243 followed by a "[ping <zombie>]." I
> don't like the look of this...  Then I tried to reboot. And couldn't.
> 
> Anyone know what this means when I try to reboot, and how to fix it?

A zombie process is one that has terminated but whose parent process hasn't
called wait() to clean up. It will only exist while the parent process is
still running; once the parent process terminates init inherits the process
and cleans up.

Zombie processes are the result of sloppy programming. Sometimes that's all
it is.

However, the presence of weird zombie processes was what alerted me once 
to the fact that my system had been compromised and rootkit'ed. 

john-

Then just remove it and reinstall it.  If it ain't configured, you won't
lose anything.

If you're worried about losing dependent packages by removing the apache
package, install apache-perl first (which I use instead of the vanilla
apache module and the separate mod_perl package), that way the apache
depdencies will be met and you can remove the packages giving you trouble.

If you're worried about losing the apache configuration, just backup
/etc/apache* to someplace else.

It's a kludge, but it's the easiest way I can see to do it without digging
in with my own hands or giving extremely detailed directions.

(I guess that's probably the motivation behind the retry/reboot/reinstall
method of MS Winders support -- except for the fact that many things
simply cannot be resolved without at least rebooting.)

Anyway, I would try dumping those packages and then installing them.

From ehem at m5p.com  Sun Jun 13 16:58:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sun Jun 13 16:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dump & restore
In-Reply-To: <20040613075802.17392.88021.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200406132357.i5DNvCv3015997@m5p.com>


>From: "Steve Bonds" <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com>
> 
> On Sat, 12 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard rshepard-at-appl-ecosys.com |PDX Linux|
> wrote:
> 
> >   According to the man page I have for 'dump', it works with ext2. Will
> > it also work with ext3 and reiserfs?
> 
> It works fine with ext3.  You would need a special dump designed for
> reiserfs.  (I haven't used it, if it even exists.)



On Sat, 12 Jun 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> It will not work with reiserfs, and it only 'may' work with ext3 (not
> directly familiar). It will not work with nfs at all.

I've repeatedly tried to convince them that they need a dump program for
the folks who feel tar's weaknesses are crucial, but they still haven't
written one.


>From: Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
> 
> On Sat, 2004-06-12 at 18:32, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > On Sat, 12 Jun 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > 
> > > It will not work with reiserfs, and it only 'may' work with ext3 (not
> > > directly familiar). It will not work with nfs at all.
> > 
> >   Harumph! That's no fun. So, ... what are folks to do who need to implement
> > a low-cost backup strategy on a limited budget?
> 
> GNU tar support incremental backups; star is supposed to be pretty fast
> and no doubt also supports incrementals.  Or, I could sell you a nice
> copy of Microlite BackupEDGE for about $300, with a nice curses
> interface, compression, and on-tape crypto. :)
> 
> dump was especially attractive in the days when tar couldn't do
> incrementals; restore has a nice interactive interface that lets you
> select specific files to restore.  dump was also rsh-aware, so it could
> be used over a network.  (Naturally, GNU tar supports this also.)  I've
> generally used dump, but I have some concerns over reliability, because
> dump backs up at the filesystem layer and the newer Linux kernels
> ('newer' being 2.2 or so) have issues with buffer cache that make it
> impossible to guarantee that a program like dump can read a consistent
> raw filesystem.  These days, I'm personally using tar for my backups.

The consistancy problem hits *both* tar and dump, just in different ways.
They'll simply get incomplete/incorrect backups in different ways. I note
though that the LVM snapshot capability makes dump work perfectly, but in
order for tar to work you need to mount the snapshot. The thought that
occurs is; could a journaling filesystem simply implement a journal-only
mode where all changes go to the journal, resulting in a dumpable
snapshot without needing LVM or another layer?


I have to vote for dump. The consistancy problems aren't much worse and
the completeness dump offers is *far* superior to what tar offers. GNU
tar does get it right most of the time, but it won't be anywhere near as
complete as dump.

Specifically dump guarentees that you will get *every* file once.
Hardlinks *will* be perfectly preserved (GNU tar does a very good job,
but doesn't guarentee it). Crucially, restore will also remove files, so
you don't end up with a complete history of every single file that has
ever existed, as well as correctly taking care of files that have moved
(and won't need to dump the file data if that is already backed up).
Extra filesystem information will also be preserved, such as nodump,
immutable, and append-only flags; crucial if you use those flags. Much
more crucially extra data such as extended ACLs *will* be preserved by
dump, while tar is incapable of handling extended ACLs.


It does come down to choose your form of poison. To me dump's
completeness is a crucial advantage. While dump is filesystem specific,
practically all filesystems have dump (and note that restore is *not* FS
specific); if I'm in a situation where I need ReiserFS, I imagine I'll
also have the funds to encourage the developers to produce a dump
program. I know how to induce the same sorts of consistancy problems in
tar that dump is subject to, so what advantage is left for tar?

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sun Jun 13 17:40:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sun Jun 13 17:40:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dump & restore
In-Reply-To: <200406132357.i5DNvCv3015997@m5p.com>
References: <200406132357.i5DNvCv3015997@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <19238-30045@sneakemail.com>

On Sun, 13 Jun 2004, Elliott Mitchell ehem-at-m5p.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> The thought that occurs is; could a journaling filesystem simply
> implement a journal-only mode where all changes go to the journal,
> resulting in a dumpable snapshot without needing LVM or another layer?

Keep in mind that in a journaling filesystem, only the filesystem metadata
(inode entries, data pointers, etc.) are journalled-- the actual data in
the files is not.  (There may be some exeptions for very small changes,
depending on which journaling filesystem is in use.)

The Veritas filesystem has a snapshot mode that does what you describe for
both the data and the filesystem metadata, without regard for which LVM is
in use.

  -- Steve

Or start using rcs to maintain revision control on your configuration
files.  The easiest way to start using it is to create an "RCS"
directory in the /etc/ and /etc/<whatever> directories.  Check in your
configuration files with the ci -u <configuration file>.  Check out the
file for modification by co -l <configuration file>.  You can go back to
a certain version by co -l -r <version>.  

Just don't short circuit the versioning by changing the mode of a
configuration file or by doing a :w! in vi or its equivalent in your
editor.

Ken
CAD2CAM.COM

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Jun 14 08:03:03 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Jun 14 08:03:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dump & restore

On Sat, 2004-06-12 at 18:32, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Harumph! That's no fun. So, ... what are folks to do who need to implement
> a low-cost backup strategy on a limited budget?

I feel like a skipping record, but:

Disk to disk backups.  http://www.keithl.com/linuxbackup.html .

Large disks are getting exponentially cheaper over time (occasionally
on sale for 50cents/GB) while tapes are not getting cheaper at all,
and the large format tape media often run $1/GB and require >$1K drives,
with further expenditures for good tape management software.

With an rsync-based, hard-linked backup protocol, you can safely fold
multiple backups over the same space.  Restore can be as simple as 
swapping hard drives, depending on the strategy chosen.  Individual
file recovery takes seconds, not hours.  Complete file system format
independence, and complete verifiability.  Media (generic IDE drives)
are easy to find.

I have access to daily filesystem snapshots for the last 9 months (when
I started backing up to disk with rsync).  Because I swap drives, I
sometimes have to exchange a backup drive out of the fire resistant
safe, but typically the files I need span multiple backups.

Tar and dump?  Why not use paper tape?  Granted I still keep a tape
drive around for reading these old formats, but it can take between
hours and days to locate really old data on a tape in a box in the
storage locker.  

Tape is DEAD!  Skipping record off!

Keith

PS:  Last week I was back east and visited the crypto museum at the 
NSA.  In their computer room, they had an old StorageTek tape library,
3000 100MB tapes in a big barrel shaped room with a handling robot.
It is amusing to think that I have better capability in a half-height
slot, though admittedly less fun to watch. (please change subject line
if you follow this paragraph up)

120GB drive: $91 (priced at enuinc)
Firewire case: $36 (priced at enuinc)
Firewire card: $15 (priced at enuinc)
Firewire cable: $10-$20 depending upon length (priced from memory)

I'd imagine this would qualify as a reasonable backup solution on a
budget for a mission critical system.

On Mon, 14 Jun 2004, Steve Bonds 1s7k8uhcd001-at-sneakemail.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Do these come with the PCMCIA storage cards, or is it up to us to
> provide our own?

I just searched The Pile and found none with storage.  In order to do
anything with the tablets an ATA PCMCIA card will be needed.  (There are
PCMCIA adapters that will make Compact Flash and other card memory formats
behave like an ATA disk.)

Also, there did not seem to be any power adapters aside from the metal
in-car docking station, which weighs about 8 pounds and probably takes
12VDC.  There is a power connector on the tablet itself which is reported
to be 16VDC 2.5A positive tip by this site:

http://www.oportal.com/accessories/fmwac3.asp

  -- Steve

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Jun 14 19:37:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Jun 14 19:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix wins again
Message-ID: <20040615023553.GA13878@gate.kl-ic.com>

Amusing story:

Last week I was back east in MD visiting my wife's family.  While
there, I usually get sucked into computer maintenance.  On &%#*!!
Windoze machines.  Sister-in-law Susan's Windoze 98 machine decided
it didn't want to talk to Comcast anymore.  Comcast had told her
"we don't support 98 anymore" and suggested she buy a WinXP capable
machine before they would help her.  Not likely, for a single mom
with a daughter starting college.

After an hour of fruitless poking and prodding (Windoze appeared to
not want to route packets beyond the local net), I gave up and booted
the machine from the Knoppix disk.  DHCP did its automagical thing
and she was online.  I showed her and her kids how to use Mozilla,
Konqueror, and GAIM, and indicated that there was far more on the
Knoppix disk to play with as well.  She was fascinated - "you say
this is free?"

She is still hoping that someone will come along and help her get
Windoze 98 working again, but this seems unlikely.  I am hoping
she will get used to Knoppix, and I can convince her to do a Xandros
(Debian) install.  This would be very cool.  Suggestions for a smooth
transition would be appreciated.

This matters, because she is the head of the legislation drafting
department for the Maryland state legislature.  It was her department
(before she was head of it) that helped draft the UCITA legislation, 
the Microsoft-sponsored replacement for the Uniform Commercial Code,
stripping consumers of normal contract and commercial rights in
software.  Only Maryland and Virginia have passed this legislation,
the rest of the states have said "this stinks".  Perhaps with
sister Susan in the FOSS-friendly camp, UCITA will be more likely
to get repealed in Maryland.  

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From lcisr1984 at spiretech.com  Mon Jun 14 23:17:01 2004
From: lcisr1984 at spiretech.com (Paul Johnston)
Date: Mon Jun 14 23:17:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Where Linux is today
Message-ID: <40CE9407.7020507@spiretech.com>

While making my way through the July Linux Journal, what at first seemed 
to be an unremarkable sentence suddenly jumped out at me as being very 
profound.

In Marcel Gagne's regular COOKING WITH LINUX article, the first sentence 
of the third paragraph is as follows:

'As many of you know, Microsoft Windows remains a part of the average 
business IT department.'

Think about the significance of that sentence, and especially the words 
'remains' and 'average'.  Five years ago that sentence would have been a 
partisan boast; today it is the understated truth about what is 
happening in the world because of Linux and the open-source software 
movement.

Think of yourself as one of the initial stockholders of a very special 
technology IPO (symbol LNX).  The stock price did not jump when it first 
hit the market; rather, it simply began increasing at a significant and 
steady rate.  (Analysts are amazed; the price of LNX keeps rising 
regardless of market conditions, and it always pays great dividends!)

Thanks Linus.  Welcome to Portland.

with vsftpd. The new /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers file looks pretty different from

other questions. First of all where are there docs that explain how to
confiure and manage vsftpd?

I've googled, but not really found the magic search terms for "Everything
You've Always Wanted to Know About vsftpd"; I've found
/usr/share/doc/vsftpd*, but those docs are very minimal; I've looked
through /etc/vsftpd.conf, but didn't see anything about guest users; I've
searched the distro CD ROMs for HOWTOs, and not found any, and I've
downlaoded and read the PDFs from the RedHat docs site for 8.0 (where I
found a little bit about securing vsftpd.)

So I have two questions:
1. Where do I find more in-depth docs on working with vsftpd?
2. How do I set up guest FTP users (private accounts with only FTP upload 
and download privs)?

On Tue, 15 Jun 2004, B. Thoen wrote:

> 2. How do I set up guest FTP users (private accounts with only FTP upload
> and download privs)?

Bill,

  I believe that annonymous ftp is both better supported and more widely
used than are private accounts. Most ftp servers will run in a chroot jail
so annonymous users can log in, upload and download but never see anything
on the system outside the jail.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Jun 15 22:09:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Jun 15 22:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Zombie in my Linux box?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0406151726170.12872-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0406151726170.12872-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
Message-ID: <86vfhsrsxw.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Dan" == Dan Haskell <danh at fork.com> writes:

Dan> As others said, zombies - in and of themselves - are not bad
Dan> things. Ones that speak Romanian make me nervous though.

Dan> IMHO, the best thing to do is check the system with chkrootkit:

A quick anecdote.  This very morning, my wife rolls me out of bed with
the words: "something weird is happening with the computer".  Enough
to wake me out of a sound slumber.  I grogily stumbled out into the
computer room where she'd been doing her usual pre-work email-reading,
news-surfing ritual and found an xterm with top running in it.  The
xterm title bar had the local hostname and top showed a bunch of
unfamiliar usernames.  Oh crap, thought I.  Hours of recovery
stretched out in front of me.  Disruption and unhappiness.  I went to
my other box, which has a serial console to my firewall/router and ran
tcpdump on the external interface.  Hmm.  Just a bunch of arp and DHCP
traffic, and some ssh traffic to my wife's account at work.  I down
the internal interface on the router to choke off the external
connection to the "compromised" host.  Then I go back to the
"compromised" host and "top" has frozen.  Hmm.  I open another local
xterm and run another top.  No wacky usernames.  I go back to the
router console and up the internal interface, and after a few moments
the first "top" recovers.  That "top" was running on my wife's work
box.  She had slogin'd to it and was running top there, not on the
local host.  Suddenly the wacky usernames didn't seem so wacky.  Big
sigh of relief.  I pointed out that a desktop menu will run an
ssh-tunneled xterm on her work machine directly, which would have
minimized the confusion over where top was running and crawled back
into bed.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Jun 15 22:21:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Jun 15 22:21:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Documentation for vsftpd (RH 8.0)?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406151121290.3986-100000@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406151121290.3986-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <1087363296.1200.21.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Tue, 2004-06-15 at 10:46, B. Thoen wrote:
[snip]
> 2. How do I set up guest FTP users (private accounts with only FTP upload 
> and download privs)?

All you need to do is set the shell for those users to /dev/null.  This
is done in the /etc/passwd file, the last entry for each user is the
login shell and ftp access doesn't need a real shell.  The false shell
(/bin/false) is supposed to work, but I've had better luck just setting
it to /dev/null.  Also check the privileges on all of your system
directories, to make sure that the ftp users can't write and/or browse
anywhere they are not wanted.

BTW, the ftp protocol sends passwords over the network in the clear,
which means that anyone that can sniff packets coming to your ftp server
can get the usernames and passwords for your ftp accounts.  I consider
this to be a major security problem.  Teach your users about WinSCP
instead.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Jun 16 05:55:03 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jun 16 05:55:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] pulling data from a file to a variable
In-Reply-To: <364794112.20040615235935@starband.net>
References: <364794112.20040615235935@starband.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406160548270.7763@pecos.madboa.com>

On Tue, 15 Jun 2004, Richard Kurth wrote:

> How can I get the data that is in a file into a variable at the 
> Command line. The file only has one line it it and I what to read 
> the file and add that one line to a variable. I know cat file_name 
> will show the data to the screen so I tried VAR1=[cat file_name] but 
> that does not work.

See the 'Command Substitution' section of the bash(1) man page, but in 
short...

   # the old-fashioned way
   VAR1=`cat file_name`

   # the posix way
   VAR1=$(cat file_name)

   # faster version of above
   VAR1=$(< file_name)

   # in case your file has multiple lines
   VAR1=$(head -n 1 file_name)

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Wed Jun 16 08:10:02 2004
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (B. Thoen)
Date: Wed Jun 16 08:10:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SUM: Documentation for vsftpd (RH 8.0)?
In-Reply-To: <1087363296.1200.21.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406160853440.7029-100000@gisnet.com>

Thanks for the help folks, and I think I have the answers I need now. I'm
not sure that summaries are expected here, but since there are PLUG
archives that others might search, I thought I'd pull together the answers
I got into one document for anyone else who wants more info on vsftpd.

Steve Nelson pointed out the www.vsftpd.org site, which has information on
installing and configuring vsftpd from source, FreeBSD and rpm. There I
also found links to to the official vsftpd site at
http://vsftpd.beasts.org/. Both of these sites seem to have plenty of
information about the configuration files.

What I wanted to do was to limit certain users to FTP upload/download
services only, but I couldn't find an FTP only shell in my new system (it
was called /etc/ftponly on my old machine.) Derek Loree pointed out that
instead I can use the false shell, /bin/false, but he says that /dev/null 
works better for this purpose as the shell assigned to the user record in 
/etc/passwd.

He also mentioned that FTP protocol is insecure in that usernames and
passwords are sent in the clear, and can therefore be read by anyone
using packet sniffer. (Hmm... I learn something new and unpleasant about
security every day.) Anyway, he suggests that I have my users use WinSCP
instead, which is a secure Windows client for copying files back and
forth. 

Thanks,
 - Bill Thoen

> after a system crash in 1779, and its administrator guillotined? ;-)
>

Well, sure, but bastille-linux primarily secures a system from remote
attack and the original Bastille was secured against escape, not intrusion
from outside.

Just as the Bastille could be (and was) hacked by storming peasants from
outside, bastille-linux can be compromised by, say, simple physical
access.

I guess it's what they call "suitability for a particular purpose".

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jun 17 08:50:03 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Jun 17 08:50:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] A WiFi WAP Question
Message-ID: <20040617154853.GA9700@gate.kl-ic.com>

Rich writes:
>   I have the Linksys wireless switch patched to the Linksys wired switch.
> The patch cord goes from the uplink port on the wired switch to port 1 on
> the WiFi switch.
>
>   The problem is that I cannot reach the WiFi switch from any other host. I
> can't ping it from a workstation that has the switch's IP address in
> /etc/hosts, I can no longer access the admin setup with a browser (trying to
> open the IP address results in the message 'network problems') and, of
> course, neither portable can reach it via WiFi. The cards in the portables
> have a strong, bright link light and now and then the activity light
> flickers but any attempt to ping a workstation from a portable fails.

Cannot reach == cannot admin, I assume.  First, simplify.  One laptop,
running dhcp, to one internal switch port on the WiFi switch, without
other hardware and protocols monkeying with things.  I strongly suspect
that some built-in NAT process in the wired switch is getting in there
and changing your addresses.  But it is hard to tell without more data;
Which brand/model of switches?  Is there a crossover cable where a
straight-through belongs, or vice versa?  Who supplies name service
and routing and internet connection and DHCP for your network?  Etc.

I don't think there is a tool or protocol that will solve your problem,
because I think the problem will be a configuration that works just fine
but does not match your intentions.  Fortunately, there is less than five
minutes of configuration on a typical WAP.  While that leaves plenty of
room for error, it does mean that a reset-and-start-from-scratch approach
is not too painful, assuming you have written down the sequence and the
config variables somewhere.

In my case, my Linksys BEFW11S4 WAP has a single internal port connected
through a crossover cable to an internal port of my straight-through
switches, with DHCP and NAT and routing and damned near everything
else turned off.  The admin IP address is set to a fixed internal
address that is not included in the internal DHCP address range.  Note,
this makes the transition from the default 192.168.1.1/password=admin
behavior of the WAP a little tricky, because partway through the
configuration the address range of the internal switch no longer matches
the IP address of the WAP.  

May I suggest putting loads of intended setup and procedure and
configuration data and observations into a text webpage, say
http://www.appl-ecosys.com/netproblem , and pointing us to that? 
Most of the time, just writing down everything you observe, and what
you are trying to do, will cause you to have the insight that solves
the problem.  But then, you are a scientist so you know that.

And once you do have it working, you have a nice start on a webpage to
help the rest of the world do what you have done.  The end of any open
source problem solving process is explaining, in triumph, how you made
something work.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Jeme A Brelin writes:
 > Well, sure, but bastille-linux primarily secures a system from remote
 > attack and the original Bastille was secured against escape, not intrusion
 > from outside.

It's a simple topological theorem.  All one need do is extrapolate the
Bastille into the 4th (or perhaps 5th since the "storming" is not
instantaneous), flip it inside out, then project it back down into the
original 3 (or 4) dimensions.  This preserves the integrity of the
Bastille and adapts it to protect from intrusion instead of escape.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Fri Jun 18 21:12:01 2004
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Jun 18 21:12:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] gethostbyname() is evil
Message-ID: <200406182113.29326.athlonrob@axpr.net>

Hey-

I've been hacking away and sending patches for an OSS project lately that has 
hit a Linux roadblock.  For ease-of-use, they traditionally distribute static 
binaries (rather than dynamically linked ones), but that gives them grief 
because in two lines of code they need to resolve a hostname to an IP... 
currently with gethostbyname().

If you compile something with gethostbyname() statically, you receive this 
warning from gcc (and it's true):

rob at dell rob $ g++ -static test.cpp
/tmp/ccGzAkVB.o(.text+0x49): In function `main':
: warning: Using 'gethostbyname' in statically linked applications requires at 
runtime the shared libraries from the glibc version used for linking

In other words, it isn't proper to compile something static for multiple (old 
and new) distributions which is network aware.  Nice, huh?

Surely there is a workaround.  One method attempted (and failed) was utilizing 
a system call to ping -c 1 -w 1 hostname and parsing its output.  While it 
would have worked, apparently there are linux distros floating about where 
only root is allowed to use ping.  *sigh*

What do y'all do to get around this issue?  It's stupid, if you ask me.  There 
must be some REALLY good reason for the error to pop up.  Are there other, 
more universal than ping, utilities out there that'll resolve a hostname to 
an IP address?  Or some magic library you can link to that'll do its own 
gethostbyname-like function without these funky errors?

I'm stumped, google isn't turning much up.  Surely somebody out there has 
figured a way around this issue... no sense re-inventing this wheel.  :-)

Rob

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406191047370.13699@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  The WiFi saga continues; Homer would be proud.

  Here's what's been achieved today:

	1) I can once again access the admin page for the WiFi switch from a
BUI. I suspect it was a less-than-fully-seated cable somewhere. To make a
long story short: it now works. I can now ping it by IP address or name.
Whew!

	2) I can ping other hosts on the lan from my Sony Vaio via the WiFi
card. But, I cannot get outside the lan. The interesting aspect about this
is that with the WiFi card inserted (and no wireline cable connected), both
eth0 and eth1 are apparently brought up. There are IP addresses for both.
When I explicitly invoke 'ifconfig eth0 down', 'ifconfig -a' shows it still
up with the IP address line, but it apparently is functionally shut down.
Because, now I can access the local network. PITA, but it works. Must be
something to do with net.agent, hotplug and the implementation by
EmperorLinux, Slackware-9.1 or the phase of the moon.

  Still to be achieved: testing my fiancee's laptop for wifi access both
internally and externally and gaining access to the 'Net from my notebook,
too.

  However, progress has been made! Excelsior!

From chris at maybe.net  Sat Jun 19 20:26:01 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Sat Jun 19 20:26:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Slackware swaret question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406191933200.15261@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406191933200.15261@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040620032513.GC2138@maybe.net>

On Sat, Jun 19, 2004 at 07:36:37PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Any of you Slackware users using swaret to keep the distribution current
> with security upgrades?

I don't use Slackware, but I do have two items to kibitz on.

>   I've read the manual, faq and man pages but I don't think I've properly
> set up /etc/swaret.conf or used the proper command. I know that there's a
> revised cvs now, and cvs is installed on my workstation, but swaret didn't
> upgrade it.

Maybe it's not considered a "security upgrade" and that's why it
doesn't update it?

> I'm wondering if there are secrets I need to learn before I add
> this to cron.weekly.

Even for Debian, it is very strongly discouraged that you put actual
upgrades into a cron job. Dry-runs, sure; but never the actual thing:

* The application interface may change, rendering parts of your system
broken (not so much a problem with Debian stable, which always
backports).

* A security compromise upstream would cause mass compromises
downstream.

* If something does go wrong, you're not there to fix it quickly.

* May require additional restarts of support software that's hard to
tell in an automated system.

It may well be you only intended to put in a dry-run or notification
command in your cron script, but I think this all needed to be said
anyways.


-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

Rob,

  We know it's a security fix because that was in the notice sent out via
e-mail. As far as I can recall, all Slackware patch notices are security
related.

  Regardless, the command line I used was 'swaret --upgrade -A'. As I
understand the docs, this instructs swaret to upgrade all installed packages
for which there is an available upgrade and do so without asking my
permission for each one. The first time I tried this I learned that the
'update' command had to be run to establish the list of packages (base and
extra) installed. So I did that.

  I used the list of resource sites in /etc/swaret.conf.new, the installed
example file. I tried to find a list of current sites but didn't see any on
the swaret Web site. I can forward a copy of the config file (off the list)
so that those more knowledgeable than I can see if it is correct.

   Oh, I really don't intend to put it in cron.weekly; that was a suggestion
from the docs. The patches that are issued are so infrequent that I can
manually run it whenever I get a notice of something issued.

Thanks,

> to find the name of the pipe to talk to.

Ah; mine don't require a special group because /var/run/saslauthd is
0755.  Back before the advent of saslauthd, Cyrus-SASL 1.5.24 or so, you
had to either run your application as root so it could read /etc/shadow
(for PAM or shadow authmech) or create a special group like 'shadow'
that you put postfix, cyrus, and other application-users into, and
chgrp'd and chmod'd /etc/shadow.  That's what I thought you were having
issues with, because there are still docs that refer to this.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From brent at servuhome.net  Sun Jun 20 16:44:01 2004
From: brent at servuhome.net (Brent Jones)

Subject: [PLUG] Apache apxs program
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406201515500.13431-100000@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406201515500.13431-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <1087774980.40d6210406f39@webmail.servuhome.net>

I havent been following this thread much, but it seems building a custom RPM set
with everything you need would be the easiest way to get all your stuff
running.
Theres a neat project, called Apache Toolbox. I've been using it for a while,
and for RPM based systems (redhat etc) it has the ability to compile its
binaries, and package them into RPM's for easy installation, and to add itself
to the dependency list.
http://www.apachetoolbox.com/

It works great for non-RPM systems too (slackware), compiles, and install into
very standard directorys, installs shared libraries for mysql/php/phpimap and
so on.


Brent Jones
brent at servuhome.net

From lug at phxlinux.org  Mon Jun 21 10:22:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Portables with built-in eth0
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406210951540.5087@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406210923100.5087@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406210936350.14927@neon.netpro.to>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406210951540.5087@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406211010030.14927@neon.netpro.to>

On Mon, 21 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Mon, 21 Jun 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
>
> > Portable, as in a laptop?  Yes, I have a Toshiba Satellite with built-in
> > Ethernet.  I sometimes use a wireless PCMCIA card with it.  It's running
> > Fedora Core 1.
>
> Matt,
>
>   Yes, portable as in a laptop/notebook.
>
>   I believe that Fedora uses /sbin/ifup for the interfaces. Is that called
> in a hotplug file called "net.agent"?
>
>   My problems with the Sony Vaio PCG-V505BC running Slackware-9.1 is that
> the built-in eth0 is always brought up and the default route is glued on
> that interface. So, when the pcmcia WiFi card is inserted (and there's no
> cat5 cable on the wireline port), both eth0 and eth1 come up, but there's no
> route for eth1. I'd like to see how fedora handles this.

In Fedora, there's a script, /etc/init.d/network, that reads config files
in /etc/sysconfig for setting network parameters.  /etc/sysconfig/network
config file would have global network settings such as the hostname and
usually the default gateway for all interfaces.
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts contains config files for all the network
interfaces on the system.  In these config files there are settings for
the interface name to use, the IP address, netmask, whether the interface
should start automatically at boot, etc.  So in your case if you were
running Fedora all you'd need to do is put the default route for both
interfaces in /etc/sysconfig/network.
~M

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406211059090.14927@neon.netpro.to>

On Mon, 21 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Mon, 21 Jun 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
>
> > Portable, as in a laptop?  Yes, I have a Toshiba Satellite with built-in
> > Ethernet.  I sometimes use a wireless PCMCIA card with it.  It's running
> > Fedora Core 1.
>
> Matt,
>
>   Yes, portable as in a laptop/notebook.
>
>   I believe that Fedora uses /sbin/ifup for the interfaces. Is that called
> in a hotplug file called "net.agent"?

Yes, /etc/hotplug/net.agent.

>   My problems with the Sony Vaio PCG-V505BC running Slackware-9.1 is that
> the built-in eth0 is always brought up and the default route is glued on
> that interface. So, when the pcmcia WiFi card is inserted (and there's no
> cat5 cable on the wireline port), both eth0 and eth1 come up, but there's no
> route for eth1. I'd like to see how fedora handles this.

There can be only one interface at any one time with the default route.
In your case you'll have to down eth0 (or "route del ..."), bring up eth1,
and then add the default route for eth1.  I'm assuming that you could edit
your net.agent script in Slackware to accomplish the same thing.
~M

Yup.  Mine is a debian install.  The interface configuration is
by-way-of /etc/network/interfaces and eth0 (since I nearly always
connect the laptop by wifi) is not "auto"matically brought up on
boot.  If I want it, I say: "ifup eth0" and up it comes via dhcp.

Before you ask, I have _no_ idea how in particular slackware does
this.

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406211135470.5087@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 21 Jun 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:

> In your case you'll have to down eth0 (or "route del ..."), bring up eth1,
> and then add the default route for eth1. I'm assuming that you could edit
> your net.agent script in Slackware to accomplish the same thing.

  Unfortunately, it may not be possible to modify net.agent to do this
automagically because it is non-trivial to determine if there's anything
attached to the eth0 port. Your pointer to 'route del ...' is valuable!
Thanks, Matt.

  The parsimonious solution is to do this manually when I want to use the
wifi interface rather than the wired interface. That is, when I'm away from
the office. But, you've given me the idea that I can write a script that
brings down eth0 ('ifconfig eth0 down'), deletes that route, then brings up
eth1 and attaches the route to that interface.

  It doesn't need to be automatic, any more than my connection to a dsl port
in a {h|m}otel. In this situation I su then run 'dhcpcd -d eth0' and away I
go. I'm just as willing to run a script that changes the interface and route
from eth0 to eth1 when the wifi card is in place.

Excelsior!

Rich

> > Yep - built-in eth0 since the beginning of time,
>
>   Didn't realize you were _that_ young, Rob!. As recently as a few years
> ago wired network access required a pcmcia card.

Well, since the beginning of its time, anyway.  :-)

>   Does gentoo use /sbin/ifup or /sbin/ifconfig to control network
> interfaces?

It uses ifconfig.

>   The folks at EmperorLinux offered a patch to Slackware's
> /etc/hotplug/net.agent which is intended to put the route on eth1 if the
> wifi card is inserted. It ain't working as intended so I'd like to see the
> network interface scripts of a distribution that does work and see if I can
> extract useful insight for my system.

If you can run commands manually (ifconfig and route) and things start to 
work, then we can just replace the network scripts with a few manual 
commands.

Life would probably be a lot easier if you installed a DHCP server and used 
DHCP to assign IP addresses.  DHCP just seems to work more frequently than 
static addresses for me lately.  It is very easy to install and configure a 
DHCP server, as well.

Rob

  The problem has been that both eth0 and eth1 come up when the wifi card is

  What I just tried was:

  ifconfig eth0 down

  ifconfig eth1 up # it was already up, but ...

  SIOCADDRT: Network is unreachable.

wireless connection to the network died from the other portable when it had
worked perfectly earlier that evening. Nothing shows up as out of order:
lights, route, interface. So, I think I'm temporarily stymied. Perhaps I'll
put the above in a script named 'wifi-up' and try it at a wifi hotspot

On my LAN of about nine machines, I've only moved four over to DHCP so far.

access. no tinkering necessary.

What DHCP would do in your situation is verify the default route is set 
properly when your wifi card comes online...

 <200406211253.01314.athlonrob@axpr.net> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406211302270.5887@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0406211419001.15594@neon.netpro.to>

On Mon, 21 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Mon, 21 Jun 2004, AthlonRob wrote:
>
>   The problem has been that both eth0 and eth1 come up when the wifi card is
> plugged in but there's no cable for the wired connection.
>
>   What I just tried was:
>
>   ifconfig eth0 down
>   route del eth0
>   ifconfig eth1 up # it was already up, but ...
>   route add -net 192.168.55.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 gw 192.168.55.4 eth1
>
>   The response was:
>   SIOCADDRT: Network is unreachable.


After taking down eth0, the default route for that interface should also
vanish so you don't need to delete the route manually.  After you take
down eth0, Try this:

route add default gw 192.168.55.4

That should bind the default gateway to eth1 if it's the only interface
up.  If that doesn't work then there's a problem with your configuration
of eth1 (wrong netmask, wrong subnet, etc).

What's the output from "ifconfig" and "route -n"?

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Jun 21 20:01:02 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Mon Jun 21 20:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Portables with built-in eth0
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406210923100.5087@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406210923100.5087@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1087873220.7782.10.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I have a simple solution for FC1

I have eth0 as the default.

If I am boot to wireless I waiting until I am in GNOME, then click the
icon I made for wireless which runs '/sbin/ifup wlan0'  I have already
made that interface available to the user (start/stop).

So when I boot at home (wireless) it fails to load eth0 and continues on
happily until I log in.  I then click, and I am wireless.

This is actually more secure since I have to *choose* my network (click
wireless, or click in the network cable).  I do not worry about being on
a network by accident.

When I used pcmcia I just set the wireless card to be default.  If I add
a new default route to a new interface, it *usually* blows out the old
address, especially if both use dhcp.


My beef is why do I need to wait for eth0 to be found.  It delays boot
something like 45 seconds, which can be precious, sitting the airport
retrieving the confirmation code at the kiosk.....

I think the whole boot sequence needs an overhaul.  Servers should not
need a server name from the IP to start, and yes I am thinking of X....



--

The problem is that you are trying to use the Cell phone Wireless
Application Protocol (WAP) instead of an Access Point (AP).

One is a standard for communication, the other is a thing, which
communicates.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jun 24 09:45:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Jun 24 09:45:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] LDAP authentcation in Squid
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406231447050.7010-100000@www.fnordora.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406231447050.7010-100000@www.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <1088095478.22155.254.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Wed, 2004-06-23 at 14:49, alan wrote:
> Does anyone have a working example of ldap authentication in Squid?  I 
> have been trying to get it to work and have not gotten much success.  
> (Which is not at all surprising since there is no documentation to be 
> found.)
> 
> Eric? Eric? Anyone?

Yes, I did it and found it pretty straight-forward.  I created a special
LDAP object that the authentication program could bind as, in able to be
able to search, called 'uid=squid,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com' (this is
actually just a regular posixAccount for the squid user).  Then I added
an entry like this to squid.conf:

authenticate_program /usr/lib/squid/squid_ldap_auth -b dc=example,dc=com
-D uid=squid,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com -w PASSWORD -f uid=%s ldaphost

And then an ACL like this:

acl localnet proxy_auth REQUIRED

Note that I'm using a slightly older version of Squid (2.4-STABLE6); I
think the newer versions have a slightly different way of configuring
the authentication.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Jun 24 14:35:03 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu Jun 24 14:35:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Out of space?
In-Reply-To: <20040624210326.GA17385@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040624162508.GA15995@themontagnes.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406241012460.15999-100000@www.fnordora.org> <20040624210326.GA17385@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <200406241434.03190.griffint@pobox.com>

A file is not actually deleted until all programs that have the file open get
around to closing it. The reboot forced the app to close the file. That
freed up the associated disk space. Another way to do this is to kill the 
process that is holding the file open.

Terry

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jun 24 17:49:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Jun 24 17:49:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Out of space?
In-Reply-To: <20040624210326.GA17385@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040624162508.GA15995@themontagnes.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406241012460.15999-100000@www.fnordora.org>
 <20040624210326.GA17385@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <16000-36268@sneakemail.com>

On Thu, 24 Jun 2004, Michael Montagne michael-at-themontagnes.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I deleted it already but oddly enough, lsof shows it still open it is
> .kde-errors.  I rebooted and all is well now.  Wonder what that was all
> about?  Thanks for the lsof idea.

Another old-school UNIX admin trick is to "cp /dev/null .kde-errors".
This frees the file's space even if a process has it open.

Sometimes the size in "ls" will immediately jump back to its former value
but "df"  should show the space still freed.  (I.e. the application just
re-seeked to what it thought was the end of the file and started writing,
creating a sparse file.)

  -- Steve

                        Smith Memorial Center
                               Room 298
                       On the block bounded by
   SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)

      **********************************************************
          
				 PRESENTATION

	      Greylisting and a Look at the Anti-Spam Landscape

				      by

				 Hal Pomeranz
			      <hal at deer-run.com>


       Black lists (both automated and not), white lists,
       keyword/regexp/Bayesian filters, SPF, and now "greylisting"-- where
       will the continuing anti-spam arms race take us next?  This talk
       includes an overview of current anti-spam techniques with some
       thoughts on their relative pros and cons, and a more in-depth look at
       the recently available "greylisting" technique, which is proving
       amazingly effective at blocking certain classes of spam.
    
       Hal Pomeranz is the technical lead and official spam eradicator for
       Deer Run Associates, a small consulting firm (recently relocated to
       Eugene, OR).  But this is merely his "mild-mannered secret identity"
       that hides his exploits as a Faculty Member and Senior Unix Instructor
       for the SANS Institute, Technical Advisor for the Center for Internet
       Security, and Technical Editor for Sys Admin Magazine.

address had not changed.

  All I want to do is access the WAP to change its IP address and set up
some security. Please pass me a pointer to what I've missed here. (This is
another example of memory leak that happens when one is not a full time
network admin.)

That keeps being brought up, but not close to the truth at all.  A lot of
the proof of concept virus writers do send their works to AV companies. 
The AV companies also check news groups, etc... for viruses being
released.
Do they hype the threat, yes.  But do they support people to write them, no.

From shahms at shahms.com  Fri Jun 25 09:52:02 2004
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Fri Jun 25 09:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Fonts Have Yellow/Blue Borders on Laptop LCD
In-Reply-To: <17655-37251@sneakemail.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406241637300.19711-100000@www.fnordora.org>
	 <17655-37251@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <1088182305.14000.20.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Thu, 2004-06-24 at 17:56, Steve Bonds wrote:
> On Thu, 24 Jun 2004, alan alan-at-clueserver.org |PDX Linux| wrote:
> 
> > > Which distro?
> 
> It appears on at least White Box Linux 3.0 and Fedora Core 1.
> 
> > Version of KDE?
> 
> KDE 3.1.
> 
> > What color depth?
> 
> All color depths, 8, 16, and 24.
> 
> > What video chipset?
> 
> ATI Radeon, using the stock XFree86 server installed by the above distros.
> This doesn't appear to be a problem with the X server itself or the
> display.
> 
> > What brand of laptop?
> 
> Compaq Evo N1020v, runs at 1024x768.
> 
> I gather from the questions that you have not seen the problem before.
> ;-)
> 
>   -- Steve

Try fiddling around with your Anti-Aliasing settings.  They should be in
the KDE Control Center under "Appearance & Themes" -> "Fonts". You'll
want to take a look at the "Use sub-pixel hinting".  You can either
disable it entirely (I *think* it's disabled by default, however) or try
changing the sub-pixel ordering.  RGB is the most common, but one of the
others may work better for you.

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>




From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Fri Jun 25 09:59:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Fri Jun 25 09:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Lightweight SMTP relay
Message-ID: <1088182828.16567.10.camel@timmy>

Due to a variety of circumstances, I need to forward mail through my
machine from one place to one other place. It works like this:

My Real Mail Server <- SMTP -> This Relay 
<- SMTP -> ISP Relay <- SMTP -> Final destination

Because the box at "This Relay" is very low on memory, I am looking for
a piece of software that will do this with less than 1MB of memory
usage. The volume of mail is very, very low, so running through inetd
would probably be the best way to do it.

Google turns up nothing but Windows spamming software, at least with the
searches I have tried. What is out there that will do this job?

Thanks,
Evan

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Jun 25 10:59:02 2004
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri Jun 25 10:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Resetting hostname and IP address 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 25 Jun 2004 09:08:57 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406250902510.31446@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <20040625175811.107ED8F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:

>   My WiFi access point problems were confirmed to be a bad WAP. Linksys sent
> the replacement and I need to access the admin page to configure it.
> However, I cannot connect to 192.168.1.1 from my notebook when its IP
> address is on a different subnet (192.168.55.3).
> 
>   I thought I knew how to (temporarily) change the static IP address and
> hostname on my notebook. Apparently I don't. First, I tried 'hostname' to
> set a new name for the unit, then I added the hostname and IP address to
> /etc/hosts and /etc/hosts.equiv. But, when I rebooted the hostname and IP
> address had not changed.
> 
>   All I want to do is access the WAP to change its IP address and set up
> some security. Please pass me a pointer to what I've missed here. (This is
> another example of memory leak that happens when one is not a full time
> network admin.)
> 

You should be able to reach a different subnet by setting up a virtual
interface.  My main machine uses 192.168.1.128, and I needed to access a
device that defaulted to 192.168.0.1.  Here's the command I used to
allow me to connect to the 192.168.0.0 network.  Note that this
automatically sets up the appropriate route, at least on my machine
(Redhat 9 with kernel 2.4.22).

 /sbin/ifconfig eth0:1 192.168.0.128 netmask 255.255.255.0

After executing this command, I had two IP's associated with my eth0
device, the original 192.168.1.128, and the new 192.168.0.128.  I was
then able to point my browser at 192.168.0.1 and access its config page.

galen

Rich,
There is no need to worry about setting up a gateway in the route table
since the 2 systems are on the same subnet.
Al that should be required is that the interface be set to a compatible IP
address.
This looks like it has been done below.
The default (0.0.0.0) gateway you put in shouldn't cause a problem though.
Are you sure about the IP address of the WiFi device?
-chaz

button just causes an internal reboot.

From chaz at bctonline.com  Fri Jun 25 13:04:02 2004
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Charles Sliger)
Date: Fri Jun 25 13:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Resetting hostname and IP address
In-Reply-To: <20040625194715.GD5475@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <001b01c45aef$7fc0c580$0a140a0a@sys10>

Rich,
I have not used virtual addresses on a given interface that were for
different subnets.  I would at least try setting eth0 to a 192.168.1 address
to keep things simple.

I have had replacement units arrive with non-default addresses (cisco
routers, etc).
The manual should have a procedure for forcing it to reload the factory
defaults.

Stafford is correct that you could try sniffing for any traffic it sends
out.
You probably will have to kick it with a power cycle or reset to get it to
send out an initial broadcast or something.
-chaz

From chaz at bctonline.com  Fri Jun 25 14:10:03 2004
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Charles Sliger)
Date: Fri Jun 25 14:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Resetting hostname and IP address 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406251337210.438@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <001201c45af8$9fc36af0$0a140a0a@sys10>

So we now know how to reset to factory defaults.  It's usually something
like this business of holding down the reset button for an extended period.
It means that you have to have physical access to the unit and you can't
inadvertently perform this function.

Also we know what IP address range to use (> 100).

This is real progress.

Just thought of another possible gotcha:
Do you have a DHCP server running?
It's becoming more and more common for a piece of equipment to try to
contact a DHCP server for an IP address as a part of its default behavior.

Also, did you try giving eth0 a single IP address of 192.168.1.150?
Depending on the vagaries of distribution that might be an issue.
-chaz

From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)

Subject: [PLUG] Securing a Wireless Access point...

The ap box is on two private networks.  I still want to tightly control 
access to it from
wireless hosts since I host my Internet email on the ap box.

I'm only interested in ssh access from wireless hosts.  Maybe later, 
I'll add a backup
service.  I don't know how to turn WEP on, so I'm especially 
disinterested in allowing
imap and other services from my wireless net to my existing private 
subnet.  WEP
doesn't work well, but at least it's something.

So far, I've blocked tcp access to ports 7100 and 515 for the wireless 
net, but I'm sure
there are other ports that need to be blocked.  I've been going by 
nmap's output.  Does
anyone know what the minimum open port requirements are for an ap to 
function?

I figure that the wireless network will be useful for learning and I 
want to be able to
quickly set up local wireless nets for fun too.  It would be safer to 
set up another
machine, but I'm probably going to use an extra box I have for a second 
wireless
hot point instead.  A challenge I'll likely run into is turning two 
wireless lans into a
single larger lan across an untrusted network that they both share.

One thought I've had is to add another nic to the mail server and run a 
dedicated
line to the second ap.  I should be able to run two isolated nets across 
the same box.  
I'm using Redhat 7.3 on the mail machine.  What do the iptables rules 
ned to be for
a router supporting two networks that aren't allowed to exchange 
packets?  I  want
to bridge the two wireless access points together.  Short of hooking the 
two ap boxes
up to each other directly, I figure I have to tunnel through my existing 
net.




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun 25 14:37:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Jun 25 14:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Resetting hostname and IP address 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406251412230.1047@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <001201c45af8$9fc36af0$0a140a0a@sys10>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406251412230.1047@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406251431100.1308@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 25 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> > like this business of holding down the reset button for an extended period.

chaz, Galen, Kurt and all lurkers:

  Eureka! The key is to unplug the unit after resetting it, then powering it
back up. The Linksys techie tried telling me that's on the sheet, but it
isn't. However, when I unplugged it and repowered it, lights flashed and I
could both ping 192,168.1.1 from the notebook _and_ mozilla finds the admin
page just fine. Whew! What a bloody ordeal this has been.

  The techie asked what versions of winduhs we're running. When I told him
we don't do junk OSes but run only linux he was non-plussed. I guess their
protocol is to have the user reboot the host next. Anyway, for future
generations, it takes both a reset (holding the button for more than 30
seconds) and a power cycle to allow access from a host with an IP address of
192.168.1.100 or greater.

  Thanks, all! Excelsior!

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From chris at maybe.net  Fri Jun 25 15:26:02 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Fri Jun 25 15:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Lightweight SMTP relay
In-Reply-To: <1088182828.16567.10.camel@timmy>
References: <1088182828.16567.10.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040625222438.GE3738@maybe.net>

On Fri, Jun 25, 2004 at 10:00:28AM -0700, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> Due to a variety of circumstances, I need to forward mail through my
> machine from one place to one other place. It works like this:
> 
> My Real Mail Server <- SMTP -> This Relay 
> <- SMTP -> ISP Relay <- SMTP -> Final destination
> 
> Because the box at "This Relay" is very low on memory, I am looking for
> a piece of software that will do this with less than 1MB of memory
> usage. The volume of mail is very, very low, so running through inetd
> would probably be the best way to do it.
> 
> Google turns up nothing but Windows spamming software, at least with the
> searches I have tried. What is out there that will do this job?


I'm using Qmail together with Gerritt Pape's GPL replacements for
daemontools. The daemons listening to the port run 150K resident. Each
incoming connection takes 300K, approx. The maintenance and delivery
daemons take about 400K resident, and around 500K per delivery. The
number of simultaneous connections you'll accept or attempt can be
tightly controlled to accomodate your system power. (One reason to not
use plain inetd.)

Hope this helps.


-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

On Fri, 2004-06-25 at 15:41, Galen Seitz wrote:

> Can SanDisk products be purchased at a local retail outlet, or do I
> need to place an order?  Are there different types of CF cards, or
> will a card from a camera work just as well for a linux filesystem?

I've bought them at BestBuy.  They're just regular camera cards, but the
SanDisk have better boot capabilities.  I've made Ext2 filesystems on
them.

> While I'm asking CF questions, do you know if CF cards perform any sort
> of wear leveling?

No, I think that's generally done as part of the filesystem, like with
JFFS/JFFS2.  Unfortunately, JFFS seems to require special capabilities
of the flash storage and CF doesn't support it; only MTD do.

Wil

I decided to look this up on SanDisk's site.  Here's a quote, but
don't ask me to explain what it means.  This is the only occurence 
of the word 'pooling' in the CF spec.

"Wear Leveling is an intrinsic part of the Erase Pooling functionality
of SanDisk CF using NAND memory. The CF WEAR LEVEL command is supported
as a NOP operation to maintain backward compatibility with existing
software utilities."

galen




From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jun 25 16:50:03 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Jun 25 16:50:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT, why write viruses?
In-Reply-To: <20040625164301.29979.3030.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040625164301.29979.3030.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040625234858.GA3053@gate.kl-ic.com>

Why write viruses?  Because you are are frustrated and angry,  The
world has not made you absolute ruler, and you want to get the sick
feeling of power that comes from attacking lots of people.  Mohammed
Atta and Timothy McVeigh and Jeffery Dalmer would have been virus
writers if they were bent that way.  The fellow that cuts you off
in traffic and laughs at you is another one of this legion of assholes,
as are the folks that support bombing Iraq, not for some functional
reason, but because it "teaches those ragheads a lesson".  A large
percentage of our fellow planetary residents are looking for some
ideological excuse (An "asshole license" to act like bastards,
because somehow by tormenting others it makes their own wasted lives
marginally better.

It is better to channel that frustration into attacking problems,
not people.  Neither approach changes the world a lot, an neither
approach makes you absolute ruler.  But over time, the latter 
approach leads to less soul rot, and makes for more friends.

So, if you want to point out problems in technology, develop better
technology.  That was the point in the first place, right?

Keith
