Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From allyn at well.com  Sat Jun 26 09:51:02 2004
From: allyn at well.com (Mark Allyn)
Date: Sat Jun 26 09:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Request For Comments on Email Services Install
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.58.0406260945270.16423@well.com>

Folks:

I have come up with a detailed procedure to install an entire
email infrastructure server from a bare bones knoppix load.

This procedure, I hope, would be a sort of 'email services install
and configuration for dummies'.

This facility includes postfix MTA (with tls and authentication);
Courier IMAP (with both imap and pop tls as well as plain); LDAP
for authentication as well as the virtual mailbox resoluter; and
the OpenGroupware calendaring.

This is slated to be a fully sealed server with the email and
calendar users not having regular unix accounts on the box.

I would like to get any comments or criticism that you might have
on this procedure (where did I fell short; are there any gross
omission)

In return, please feel free to use this or dissiminate at your
pleasure.

--------------------------------------------------------------

qy



From allyn at well.com  Sat Jun 26 09:53:02 2004
From: allyn at well.com (Mark Allyn)
Date: Sat Jun 26 09:53:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Request for criticism for email infrastructure install procedure
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.58.0406260950420.24157@well.com>

Folks;

For the collab project at freegeek, I have come up with a sort
of 'email infrastructure install for dummies' for a postfix
virtual email services including postfix, courier imap, ldap,
and OpenGroupware.

I am looking for any critcism or reminders of any glaring omissions.

In return, please feel free to use this or disiminate at your pleasure.

Thanks

Mark allyn


-----------------------------------------------------------------------

This procedure assumes that you are planning to set up a sealed,
server for your email and calendaring infrastructure needs.

This server is intended to provide email SMTP transport (via
postfix); IMAP/POP3 email access (via courier imapd); calendaring
(via OpenGroupware) and authentication (via ldap). This will be
structured so that email and calendar account users need not
have entries in the local system account files (/etc/passwd and
/etc/shadow).

A sealed server is a server where the email and calendar account
holders (users) do not have accounts on the machine itself and that
this machine is not someone's workstation or desktop unit; ie; that it
is secured in a server room or locked cabinet away from normal users'
physical access. All access to this server from the users is via WEB
or using clients such as evolution or outlook. Telnet, rsh, and ftp
are disabled. SSH is enabled for the system admins only.

For this installation, we are going to presume that the DHCP service
for diskless workstations (LTSP services) will be handled by another
system.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

Our baseline (starting point) is having a Knoppix 3.4 CD and a computer
on which to install it. The computer should have at least one NIC, 100 MB
of RAM, and 3 GB of disk space. Of course, the disk space requirements
vary according to how many email users you will handle with the system and
how much space each user will take up in email messages.

------------------------------------------------------------------

The first steps are to install the basic operating system and then
update it from the distribution and to do some very preliminary
system wide configuration:

First, do the Knoppix install, following instructions on the knoppix
installer. For the type of installation, you need to select Debian.

Once the Knoppix is installed, please do the following:

1. Configure the network connection information. Because this
   will be a mail / calendering server, you will need to have
   a fixed IP address as well as a DNS served domain name.
   The appropriate files to edit to configure networking are:

   a. /etc/network/interfaces
   b. /etc/hosts
   c. /etc/resolv.conf
   d. /etc/hostname

   Once you have configured the networking information, you
   will need to re-boot the machine to ensure that the networking
   has started up properly and that you can reach hosts on the
   internet from the machine.

2. Edit the /etc/apt/sources.list file and comment out entries
   associated with the experimental release. They are toward the
   end of the file.

   Add the following to the end of the /etc/apt/sources.list file:

   deb http://www.opengroupware.org/packages deb/

3. Do a dpkg -P nis (which removes the nis package)

4. Do a dpkg -P cpuburn (which removes the cpuburn package)

5. Do an apt-get update to update the package indexes

6. Do an apt-get upgrade - this will take a few hours

7. Do an apt-get dist-upgrade

8. Re-boot the system.

9. Edit the /etc/inittab file and set the default run level
   to 3, which is done by ensuring that the default runlevel
   entry looks something like: id:3:initdefault:

10. Carefuly check the /etc/rc3.d directory. Note that the
   files in that directory are symbolic links to files in
   the /etc/init.d directory and are used to start services
   that are needed for init run level 3 which is what we
   are running this server. At this point, before you have
   installed anything else, you need to ensure that you
   have the link to start up apache and ssh. On some distros,
   the link for ssh will be missing. Also, ensure that there
   are no links for xdm or kdm as those are the x window
   that you will not be using for this server. You will also
   need to add the link to start the mysql server, which is
   allready installed in a Knoppix basic install. If this system
   is to be only a mail/calendar/imap server and not to be
   a dhcp server,  you will also need to remove any symbolic
   links to dhcp; most likely this will be S20dhcp3-server.

11. Re-boot the system at this time and ensure that you have
    the basic services needed running and nothing else. Do
    a 'ps -ef' and ensure that the apache, ssh, and mysql
    are running.

12. Create a user account for the system administrator if this
    is not allready done via the Knoppix installation. This will
    allow the system administrator to log into the system via
    ssh from their workstation.

At this time, the basic system set up is completed. Now we will
do the installation of the software packages. Some of them will
require configuration during the instalation process. Most of the
configuration tasks, however, will take place after all of the
software package instalation is complete.

Here are the steps for the software package instalation:

----------
For LDAP:
-----------

apt-get install libldap2/testing  (this will downgrade the ldap
                                   libraries from unstable to testing
                                   which is necessary to install the
                                   rest of the ldap components)

  (testing may not work for this install)

At some point during the install, you will be asked some questions.
Here is suggested way to respond. You might vary this according to
the situation that you are in. You will need to write down amd remember
your responses to these questions as they will apply to setting up
other packages.

Slapd will ask for a domainname. This is the domain name for your
  organization. For this example we will use freegeek.org

Slapd will ask for Organization name. Here, you can use Free Geek
Slapd will ask for the admin password. You can use secret or whatever you
  want. Please remember this for later.
Answer no to allowing ldapv2 unless you realy need it, which you wont
  in a typical new installation


-----------------------
Postgres Database Server
-----------------------

apt-get install postgresql

This will install the postgres database. You will be prompted for
some configuration stuff. Here is how you should respond (may vary
slightly)

a. Keep the directory as the default (/var/lib/postgres/data)
b. Leave default (no) to the purge question (you have no database now)
c. Select SQL_Ascii for the charactor encoding
d. Use the default (ISO) for the date style
e. Use the US Style for the date format. Be aware that this does default
   to European. You will need to set this.
f. Leave as default (yes) for the automatic upgrades
g. Leave as default (/var/lib/postgres) for the dump file directory
   question; where to leave a dump file during upgrades.
h. Leave as default (/var/lib/postgres/preserve) for the question regarding
   where to copy the existing database during an upgrade

/etc/init.d/postgresql start

and then again do:

apt-get install postgresql

At this time, the install should go through okey. You should not have
to re-enter the configuration options as you had earlier.

Now re-boot the machine and ensure that slapd (the ldap server)
and postgresql are running.

Here is how to answer questions that are asked during the installs
of the php stuff:

1. Default (no) to libc-client use of unencrypted passwords
2. Default (yes) to install libc-client without Maildir support
3. Phpmyadmin asks which webserver to configure. De-select apache2
   and apache-perl
4. Default (no) for re-starting apache
5. Phppgadmin asks which webserver to configure. Select apache.
6. Phpldapadmin asks for whether you want session, cookie, or config
   for password handling. For best security, select session, which
   is the default.
7. Phpldapadmin asks which webserver to configure. Use only apache

8. Select no for re-starting apache.

Mailman Listserv Manager

This will ask you for languages for the email lists. Please think
carefuly of all the languages you and your organization might need.

Note the warning on creating the site list.

Immediately after the installation, run

newlist mailman

This will prompt information for the mailman mail list owner.
Use a valid email address for the owner. I used allyn at freegeek.org
Use a password and write it down. I used secret

The installer will then ask you to add several lines to the /etc/aliases
file. They are:

## mailman mailing list
mailman:              "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman post mailman"
mailman-admin:        "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman admin mailman"
mailman-bounces:      "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman bounces mailman"
mailman-confirm:      "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman confirm mailman"
mailman-join:         "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman join mailman"
mailman-leave:        "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman leave mailman"
mailman-owner:        "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman owner mailman"
mailman-request:      "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman request mailman"
mailman-subscribe:    "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman subscribe mailman"
mailman-unsubscribe:  "|/var/lib/mailman/mail/mailman unsubscribe mailman"

Once you added these to /etc/aliases, you will need to run
the newaliases command.

At this time, the package installations are complete. Now, re-boot

------------------------------------------------------------

Now it's time to do the configurations and setup. Much of these
procedures depend on your organization's personal information.
For this document, I will be using the following identifying
information, which, of course, you will replace with your own:

Country: US
State: OR
Locale: Portland
Organization: Free Geek
Organizational Unit: Collab Tech
Domain Name: freegeek.org
Server Name: collab-dev or collab-dev.freegeek.org
Admin's email address: allyn at freegeek.org
LDAP initial admin cn: "cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org"
LDAP initial admin password: secret
Mailman admin password: secret
SSL Certificate Authority pass-phrase: secret123

------------------------------------------------------------

At this time, we need to set up the keys and certificates for the
SSL (encrypted secure socket or transmission) for apache, postfix,
and courier imap/pop. We will be creating all of the required keys
at this time and then installing them later as we get to each
respective package.

These steps are to be done as the root user.

Get into the /etc/ssl directory by doing cd /etc/ssl

Edit the openssl.cnf file:
Change the following:
default_days = 10000
default_crl_days = 5000
  (we don't need to have to change each year)
countryName_default = US
stateOrProvinceName_default = OR
add: localityName_default = Portland
0.organizationName_default = Free Geek
organizationalUnitName_default  = Collab Tech
  (you will need to uncomment this one)
add: emailAddress_default = allyn at freegeek.org

For my system, I will be generating my own certificate signing
authority. Some of you may choose to have your certificates signed
by a recognized certificate authority. This will cost money, but it
will mean that popular browsers will not pop up with the warning about
an unrecognized certificate when your site is accessed. This is up to
you. If you choose to use an existing certificate signing authority,
you should disregard the steps that are related to makeing and using
our own certificate signing authority (CA).

First, we will generate the private keys.

Certificate authority (skip this if you are using another CA):

openssl genrsa -des3 -out private/cakey.pem 2048
  This will prompt for a pass phrase. Please carefuly enter and
  note/remember what you used. I used secret123

This will create a key file called cakey.pem

Apache, Postfix, Courier:

dd if=/dev/urandom of=private/imapd.rand count=1 2>/dev/null
dd if=/dev/urandom of=private/popd.rand count=1 2>/dev/null


openssl genrsa -out private/apache_key.pem 2048
openssl genrsa -out private/postfix_key.pem 2048
openssl genrsa -out private/courier_imap_key.pem 2048
openssl genrsa -out private/courier_pop_key.pem 2048

Now we will create the certificate signing requests (unsigned certficates)

openssl req -new -key private/apache_key.pem -out certs/apache_cert.csr
openssl req -new -key private/postfix_key.pem -out certs/postfix_cert.csr
openssl req -new -key private/courier_imap_key.pem -out certs/courier_imap_cert.csr
openssl req -new -key private/courier_pop_key.pem -out certs/courier_pop_cert.csr

Each of these processes will ask you some questions.
Most of them will have default answers taken from the
openssl.cnf file you filled in earlier. There will be
an entry for the Common Name that will not have a
default answer. You will need to respond to that question
with the server's name, not your own name. For my
example, I used collab-dev.

This is for the certificate authority. Skip if you are using someone else's

openssl req -days 5000 -new -x509 -key private/cakey.pem -out certs/ca_cert.pem

Now we will sign the certificates (again, skip this section if you are having
  the certificates signed by another certficate signing authority)

openssl x509 -req -in certs/apache_cert.csr -out certs/apache_cert.pem \
	-signkey private/apache_key.pem \
	-CA certs/ca_cert.pem -CAkey private/cakey.pem -CAcreateserial -days 5000

openssl x509 -req -in certs/postfix_cert.csr -out certs/postfix_cert.pem \
	-signkey private/postfix_key.pem \
	-CA certs/ca_cert.pem -CAkey private/cakey.pem -CAcreateserial -days 5000

openssl x509 -req -in certs/courier_imap_cert.csr -out certs/courier_imap_cert.pem \
	-signkey private/courier_imap_key.pem \
	-CA certs/ca_cert.pem -CAkey private/cakey.pem -CAcreateserial -days 5000

openssl x509 -req -in certs/courier_pop_cert.csr -out certs/courier_pop_cert.pem \
	-signkey private/courier_pop_key.pem \
	-CA certs/ca_cert.pem -CAkey private/cakey.pem -CAcreateserial -days 5000

Now we set up the diffi helmen stuff for the imap and pop certificates

openssl gendh -rand private/imapd.rand 512 >>certs/courier_imap_cert.pem
openssl gendh -rand private/popd.rand 512 >>certs/courier_pop_cert.pem

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Now we will configure the apache web server.

As the root user, ensure that you are in the /etc/apache directory.

Edit the httpd.conf file and ensure that the ServerName value is set
to the true server name (collab-dev) and not to localhost.

Edit the /etc/hosts file and ensure that the host collab-dev is set
with the host's real IP address and not the localhost's address of
127.0.0.1 as this may break some web based applications.

This apache installation from the Knoppix distribution does include
the ssl (secure socket capable) apache server. This does need to be
configured and supplied with the certificate.

First, we need to remove all old keys and certs. These are dummies
that were supplied by apache and are not signed or valid.

Ensure you are in the /etc/apache directory and do:

find ssl* -type f -name \*key -exec rm -f {} \;
find ssl* -type f -name \*crt -exec rm -f {} \;
find ssl* -type f -name \*csr -exec rm -f {} \;
find ssl* -type f -name \*prm -exec rm -f {} \;
find ssl* -type f -name \*pem -exec rm -f {} \;

Now copy in the newly created key and cert files by:

cp /etc/ssl/certs/apache_cert.pem ssl.crt/apache_cert.pem
cp /etc/ssl/private/apache_key.pem ssl.key/apache_key.pem

Now we need to edit the conf.d/mod-ssl-01-vhost.conf file (which is
one of the configuration files for the ssl apache server)

We will be working in the <VirtualHost _default_:443> section.

Change the DocumentRoot to /var/www (which is the same as the
main server) The point of this is that we need to have most of
the stuff that is being served by this system to be under cover
of SSL (encryption) as most users will be either entering
passwords or dealing with emails and other personal, confidential
data. In this case, it should be handy to have the default install
of the various packages to fall into /var/www as the default and
to have that document root be that of the secure server. Later, we
will change the document root of the non-secure server to something
else.

We now need to change or set the following two entries to point
to the new certificate and key files that we have just installed:

SSLCertificateFile /etc/apache/ssl.crt/apache_cert.pem
SSLCertificateKeyFile /etc/apache/ssl.key/apache_key.pem

Now you need to stop and start the apache web server. Do:

/etc/init.d/apache stop
/etc/init.d/apache start

Use a web browser and go to:

https://your-server-name (in our example, https://collab-dev

If you have used a recognized certificate authority, you will be
able to get at the apache greeting page directly. If, however, you
created your own certificate authority as I had in this example, you
will be warned that your brower has not recognized the certificate
authority. Click accept to accept it, or if you want to make sure that
what you did was valid, you can click on details to look at the
certificate information.

---------------------------------------------------------------

LDAP configuration:

First, we need to set up a virtual email user account that holds
the email boxes for all of the email users. We need to do this
at this time because the uid and the gid of this account are needed
for the procedure to set up the initial LDAP database.

As root, do:

adduser vmail

This will ask you stuff, including a password. Note / remember
the password as you may need it in the future.

When you are done, look at the /etc/passwd file and note the uid
and the gid of the vhost user. It should be 1002. Make a note
of it.

You need to set up the courier imap ldap schema. First, you
must copy the schema file into the /etc/ldap heiarchy. As root
do:

cp /usr/share/doc/courier-ldap/authldap.schema /etc/ldap/schema/courier.schema

Then add it into the /etc/ldap/slapd.conf file by adding the following line
after the other include lines:

include         /etc/ldap/schema/courier.schema

While you are editing the /etc/ldap/slapd.conf file, please ensure
that you have the following set:

allow 		bind_v2
(this may be there, but commented out. Uncomment it.)

index           default pres,eq
index           objectClass eq
index           cn,sn,uid,mail pres,eq,sub

access to attribute=userPassword
        by dn="cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org" write
        by anonymous auth
        by self write
        by * none

access to dn.base="" by * read

access to *
        by dn="cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org" write
        by * read

Also, please ensure that the rootdn and rootpw entries are not
included in this file. They will be entered directly into the new
database during the procedures below. This will help ensure that the
admin password is not visible outside the database.

Now, please now stop the ldap server by doing:
/etc/init.d/slapd stop

Do a ps -ef and make sure that there are no slapd daemons running.

At this time, we will be removing the current LDAP database
because we are not sure of its contents and access conrol lists.
We might as well start fresh with something that is known.

As root, do:

rm -rf /var/lib/ldap/*

This will remove all ldap database files.

Once this is done, you will now create a new database that has
the admin user information as well as a template mail user account.

First, you will need to establish the hash for the admin user
password. Do:

slappasswd

This will prompt you for a new password. Please enter this carefuly
and remember it. Once you have entered it and then confirmed it, you
will be given a hash. Please be aware that you cannot recover the
password if you lose it and you would have to re-set it using this
procedure. Carefuly copy the resulting hash. Please be aware that
this hash is case sensitive and it should be copied exactly as seen.
Use the mouse cut and paste if you can.

Now, you will be creating the initial database creation file. This
file will be used by the slapadd utility. Please copy and paste the
following (between, but not including  the *********** lines)
to a file; use the file name /etc/ldap/start.ldif

****************************************************************
# Organization For Free Geek
dn: dc=freegeek,dc=org
objectClass: dcObject
objectClass: organization
dc: freegeek
o: Free Geek
description: Free Geek

# Organizational Role for Directory Manager
dn: cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org
objectClass: organizationalRole
objectClass: simpleSecurityObject
cn: admin
description: Directory Manager
userPassword: <put your password hash here>

# Add a Template Email User
dn: uid=tuser at freegeek.org,dc=freegeek,dc=org
objectClass: inetOrgPerson
objectClass: posixAccount
objectClass: CourierMailAccount
uid: tuser at freegeek.org
description: Email and Calendar Account
localityName: Portland
organizationName: Free Geek
cn: Template
sn: User
userPassword: secret
mail: tuser at freegeek.org
gidNumber: 1002
uidNumber: 1002
homeDirectory: /home/vmail/domains/freegeek.org/tuser/
mailbox: /home/vmail/domains/freegeek.org/tuser/

# Add the Administrative Email User (which is used to receive mail
# for root, postmaster, and abuse at the domain)
dn: uid=email_admin at freegeek.org,dc=freegeek,dc=org
objectClass: inetOrgPerson
objectClass: posixAccount
objectClass: CourierMailAccount
uid: email_admin at freegeek.org
description: Email and Calendar Account
localityName: Portland
organizationName: Free Geek
cn: Email
sn: Administrator
userPassword: secret
mail: email_admin at freegeek.org
gidNumber: 1002
uidNumber: 1002
homeDirectory: /home/vmail/domains/freegeek.org/email_admin/
mailbox: /home/vmail/domains/freegeek.org/email_admin/
***********************************************************************

In the above file, wherever you see freegeek, Free Geek, Portland,
or any other location/organizational specific things, please
substitute the ones that you will be needing for your organization.

Also, be sure that the gidNumber and the uidNumber agree with the
vhost user's gid and uid that you have created and noted at the
beginning of this LDAP setup procedure.

And, of course, you need to copy (paste) your admin password hash
that you generated prior to this step, into the userPassword entry.

Once this file is created, you need to do:

slapadd -v < /etc/ldap/start.ldif

You should see something like:

added: "dc=freegeek,dc=org" (00000001)
added: "cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org" (00000002)
added: "uid=tuser at freegeek.org,dc=freegeek,dc=org" (00000003)

At this point, you need to start the ldap server by:

/etc/init.d/slapd start

At this time, we are going to check to see that the LDAP server is up and
running and is accessible via the phpldapadmin package which is a web based
LDAP server administration tool.

On your web browser, please go the following address (replace collab-dev
with your server name)

https://collab-dev/phpldapadmin

You should be greeted with php ldap admin banner page. On the left, please
click on Login. You will be presented with the login banner. Carefuly check
to see that your Login DN is correct for your LDAP database. For our example,
it should be: cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org

Enter your LDAP password (you did write it down, I hope). For our example, it
was secret

Once you log in, you should be greeted with the top level information to your
server in the column on the left.

Click on the + sign to the left of the top level domain (the little globe
icon). This will display a drop menu showing the objects in your
ldap database that you have so far.

We will now add an email user to the ldap database. This will be
the procedure you will use to add accounts to your email system.

Click on the uid=tuser at freegeek.org entry. Don't click on the + sign to
the left of it, just click on the entry itself.

This will open a form in the panel to the right. Click on the Copy
this entry link that is toward the upper left corner of this screen.

This will present a Copy screen. In the Destination DN, you
will need to make a change to the uid attribute. Change the
template_user value to something new. For our example, we will
change it to john_jones but be carefull not to erase or change
the 'uid=' as they are needed. Click on the copy buttun.

You will see a plain window with:

 Copy successful! Would you like to view the new entry?

Click on the view the new entry words as this is a link.

You will see an editing panel. Please be carefull while yo make
the changes as some of the values must be left alone.

Change the CN field from Template to the user's first name. In
our example, that will be John.

Change the tuser name in homeDirectory to the mail directory
name. A good system to use is a combination of the first initial
and the last name. In our example, that would be jjones but be
careful not to change anything before the last / charactor as
this path is needed by the postfix and the courier systems.

Change the mail to the user's email address. In our example, it
will be jjones at freegeek.org

Change the mailbox attribute to be the same as the homeDirectory
above.

Change the sn to the user's last name. In our case, this would
be Jones

Enter (and remember) a password for the user.

Please leave the other fields as they are.

When you are through, click on save changes. Your browser may ask
if you want to remeber the password. Click no.

You will now be in a confirmation screen where you see the old
values and the new values. Check these. If you are happy, please
click on the green Commit button.

This will result in yet another display of the user's information,
however you are through with adding this user. If you want to add
another user, to to the left side panel and click on the
uid=template_user entry and start this procedure again.

Once you have completed adding the initial email users, run
the slapindex by doing:

slapindex

This will generate the ldap indexes.

At this time, your ldap server is configured. You may exit the
phpldapadmin web utility.


========================================================================

SASL Authentication (which is needed by postfix)

At this point, we will set up the sasl authentication system which
postfix needs for providing SMTP authentication via the ldap authentication
database that we just set up in the proceeding steps above. The sasl
authentication daemon will be set up to communicate via the pam authentication
system to the password data in the ldap directory.

Edit the /etc/default/saslauthd file and uncomment "START=yes" line
so that the saslauthd will run on system boot. Also, ensure that the
line 'MECHANISMS="pam"' is there as well.

Because by default Postfix on Debian seems like it chroots, we need to
make saslauthd's socket file accessible to both the chrooted Postfix and
saslauthd. This seemed to make sense over turning off chroot, since we
need to take the path of "minimal resistance" with respect to the way
the Debian packages do their work as well as to make this system less
vulnerable to attacks via the postfix SMTP daemon (port 25).

Do:

mkdir -p /var/spool/postfix/var/run
mv /var/run/saslauthd /var/spool/postfix/var/run/saslauthd
ln -s /var/spool/postfix/var/run/saslauthd /var/run/saslauthd

Re-start the saslauthd by:

/etc/init.d/saslauthd stop
/etc/init.d/saslauthd start


Check the following log files to ensure that saslauthd started
with no errors:

/var/log/syslog
/var/log/auth.log


Create / Edit /etc/pam.d/smtp to set up the pam stuff for smtp. This
will include both ldap as well as the system accounts (root, etc).
This file should look something like:

        auth            sufficient      pam_ldap.so
        auth            required        pam_unix.so use_first_pass
        account         sufficient      pam_ldap.so
        account         required        pam_unix.so use_first_pass
        password        sufficient      pam_ldap.so
        password        required        pam_unix.so use_first_pass
        session         required        pam_unix.so


Once you have this file, you will need to put it in place in
the postfix chroot environment. Do:

mkdir /var/spool/postfix/etc/pam.d
cp /etc/pam.d/smtp /var/spool/postfix/etc/pam.d/smtp


Edit / Create the /etc/postfix/sasl/smtpd.conf file which configures
postfix to do SASL authentication.

This file (/etc/postfix/sasl/smtpd.conf) should contain the following
lines:

        mech_list: PLAIN
        minimum_layer: 0
        pwcheck_method: saslauthd
        auto_transition: no


Edit the /etc/pam_ldap.conf file to ensure that the pam password
authentication manager can get at the ldap database. You will need to
set the rootbinddn variable as well as the base variable.

The following lines should be in that file:

base dc=freegeek,dc=org
rootbinddn cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org

Edit / create a file named /etc/ldap.secret and put in the ldap
admin password. Make sure the mode of that file is 600. This file
is needed so that pam can access the ldap directory.

Now lets test the saslauthd configuration.

First, either reboot the machine or do the following to ensure
that saslauthd is running with the latest configuration:

/etc/init.d/saslauthd stop
/etc/init.d/saslauthd start

now do:

testsaslauthd -u template_user -p secret -s smtp

(This attempts to do an authentication on thet template_user
email account).

========================================================================

Email system configuration and preparation

Edit the /etc/groups file and ensure that postfix is a member
of the sasl group. This is necessary for sasl authentication.

At this time, we will be creating the initial email boxes for the
new email accounts.

To make this part of the job easier, as well as when you add accounts
later, and especially if you have to add large numbers of accounts;
you can make a script to do this part of the job. Please carefuly copy
and paste the following (between, but not including, the #############
lines:

Please note that you will have to change the systempass, the systemlogin,
and the systemtop values to reflect your organization.
########################################################################
systempass=secret
systemlogin="cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org"
systemtop="dc=freegeek,dc=org"

dirs=`ldapsearch -x -w $systempass -D "$systemlogin" -b "$systemtop" \
        mailbox | grep "^[^#]" | grep mailbox | awk '{ print $2 }'`

for ddir in $dirs

do
        if [ ! -d $ddir ]
        then
                mkdir -p $ddir
        fi
done

#######################################################################

This script needs to be run as the vmail user because these mail
directories must be owned by the vmail user

This create empty directories in the vmail user account whereupon
the email transport agent will put users' email and the courier
imap will access the email for users' access over imap and pop.


Postfix runs in a chroot environment. It will need its own
versions of some of the standard /etc directory files.
Please ensure that the following files are in the
/var/spool/postfix/etc directory and that they are similar to
those in the /etc directory:

hosts
localtime
nsswitch.conf
pam.d/*
resolv.conf
services


Now we need to configure the postfix MTA server.

Go to the /etc/postfix directory

Edit the /etc/postfix/main.cf file and add the follwing lines:

smtpd_sasl_auth_enable = yes
smtpd_sasl_security_options = noanonymous
smtpd_sasl_local_domain =
broken_sasl_auth_clients = yes
smtpd_use_tls = yes
smtpd_tls_auth_only = yes
smtpd_tls_key_file = /etc/postfix/ssl/tls_key.pem
smtpd_tls_cert_file = /etc/postfix/ssl/tls_cert.pem
smtpd_tls_CAfile = /etc/postfix/ssl/tls_ca.pem
smtpd_tls_loglevel = 3
smtpd_tls_received_header = yes
smtpd_tls_session_cache_timeout = 3600s
tls_random_source = dev:/dev/urandom
smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
	permit_sasl_authenticated,
	permit_mynetworks,
	check_relay_domains,
        reject_unknown_sender_domain,
        reject_unknown_recipient_domain,
        reject_unauth_pipelining,
        reject_non_fqdn_recipient,
        reject_unauth_destination,
        reject_rbl_client relays.ordb.org,
        reject_rbl_client opm.blitzed.org,
        reject_rbl_client list.dsbl.org,
        reject_rbl_client sbl.spamhaus.org,
        reject_rbl_client cbl.abuseat.org,
        reject_rbl_client dnsbl.sorbs.net,
        permit


local_transport = virtual
virtual_mailbox_base = /
virtual_mailbox_domains = freegeek.org
virtual_mailbox_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/virtual_mailbox, ldap:ldapvirtual
virtual_uid_maps = static:1002
virtual_gid_maps = static:1002
virtual_minimum_uid = 1002
virtual_mailbox_limit = 0
ldapvirtual_server_host = localhost
ldapvirtual_server_port = 389
ldapvirtual_bind = yes
ldapvirtual_bind_dn = cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org
ldapvirtual_bind_pw = secret
ldapvirtual_search_base = dc=freegeek,dc=org
ldapvirtual_query_filter = (mail=%s)
ldapvirtual_result_attribute = mailbox


Please note that the information in these lines will vary
according to the name, domain, password, and location
of your own organization.

Also, make sure that the mynetworks entry has the information
for your own numerical IP networks. For our example at Free Geek,
it would look something like:

mynetworks = 127.0.0.0/8,192.168.7.0/32

Also, make sure that the mydestination entry does not include
the virtual domain that you included above. The mydestination
entry is for local (those having machine accounts) only.

Create a file at /etc/postfix/virtual_mailbox and put in the
following lines:

root at freegeek.org       /home/vmail/domains/freegeek.org/admin/
postmaster at freegeek.org /home/vmail/domains/freegeek.org/admin/
abuse at freegeek.org      /home/vmail/domains/freegeek.org/admin/

(remember that the 'freegeek' name needs to be replaced with
the domainname of your organization. Also remember that you
must have the following slash at the end of each line in order
to utilize the Mailbox mail format.

After creating this file, you must run the postmap command:

postmap virtual_mailbox

Now, copy in the postfix certificate and key files for
the tls transport. Do:

mkdir /etc/postfix/ssl
cp /etc/ssl/certs/postfix_cert.pem /etc/postfix/ssl/tls_cert.pem
cp /etc/ssl/certs/ca_cert.pem /etc/postfix/ssl/tls_ca.pem
cp /etc/ssl/private/postfix_key.pem /etc/postfix/ssl/tls_key.pem

Create a file at /usr/lib/sasl2/smtpd.conf and put in it
the following line:

pwcheck_method: saslauthd


Edit the /etc/postfix/master.cf file and ensure that the
following three lines are not commented (they usualy are
in a default instalation)

tlsmgr    fifo  -       -       n       300     1       tlsmgr
smtps     inet  n       -       n       -       -       smtpd -o smtpd_tls_wrappermode=yes -o smtpd_sasl_auth_enable=yes


Now lets do some basic checks on postfix.

First, lets try to have it do a basic email. Here is a
typical ineraction upong invoking 'telnet localhost 25' on
the mail server:

telnet localhost 25
220 collab-dev ESMTP Postfix (Debian/GNU)
helo collab-dev.freegeek.org
250 collab-dev
mail from: allyn at freegeek.org
250 Ok
mail to:arosenau at freegeek.org
503 Error: nested MAIL command
rcpt to: arosenau at freegeek.org
250 Ok
data
354 End data with <CR><LF>.<CR><LF>
Hello Art!
.
250 Ok: queued as 91016FBC3A
quit
221 Bye
Connection closed by foreign host.


Now, lets check to see that the mail server can handle tls (encryption)
and authentication. For this, we will use the openssl s_client testing
facility. First, we have to encode the username and password:

printf 'user\0user\0pass' | mimencode (which in our example would be)

printf 'arosenau at freegeek.org\0arosenau at freegeek.org\0secret6' | mimencode
This outputs:
YXJ0aHVyX3Jvc2VuYXUAYXJ0aHVyX3Jvc2VuYXUAc2VjcmV0Ng==

Now you need to invoke the openssl test client facility which
will give  you an interactive session on the mail server's
tls service. Do:

openssl s_client -connect collab-dev:465 -CAfile /etc/ssl/certs/ca_cert.pem

You will get a bunch of ssl related status information and then you will
get the smtp interactive prompt:

220 collab-dev ESMTP Postfix (Debian/GNU)

at this point, you can do:

auth plain YXJ0aHVyX3Jvc2VuYXUAYXJ0aHVyX3Jvc2VuYXUAc2VjcmV0Ng==

at which point, you should get:
235 Authentication successful

Type quit and you will exit the interactive session.

This complets the basic instalation and configuration of the
postfix email system.

==============================================================

Courier Imap and Pop server configuration

The Courier Imap and Pop server must be configured to be able
to authenticate via the LDAP database.

First, go to the /etc/courier directory:

cd /etc/courier

Then edit the authldaprc file. Ensure that the following lines
are in the file (there will be others; these are the most
important)

LDAP_SERVER             localhost
LDAP_PORT               389

LDAP_BASEDN             dc=freegeek, dc=org
LDAP_BINDDN             cn=admin,dc=freegeek,dc=org
LDAP_BINDPW             secret

LDAP_TIMEOUT            5

LDAP_MAIL               mail

LDAP_DOMAIN             freegeek.org

LDAP_GLOB_UID           vmail
LDAP_GLOB_GID           vmail

LDAP_HOMEDIR            homeDirectory
LDAP_MAILDIR            mailbox

LDAP_DEFAULTDELIVERY    defaultDelivery

LDAP_FULLNAME           uid

LDAP_CLEARPW            clearPassword
LDAP_CRYPTPW            userPassword


Now edit the authdaemonrc file and change the entry for
authmodulelist="authldap" to:
authmodulelist="authldap"

Now we need to copy in the certificates that are required for
imap and pop secure layer (ssl / encryption). Please do:

cp /etc/ssl/private/courier_imap_key.pem imapd.pem
cp /etc/ssl/private/courier_pop_key.pem pop3d.pem
cat /etc/ssl/certs/courier_imap_cert.pem >>imapd.pem
cat /etc/ssl/certs/courier_pop_cert.pem >>pop3d.pem

Please note that these files are actualy concatinations of the
respective key and signed certificate files. The Courier imap/pop
servers use combinational certificate files that contain the
certificate, the key, and the diffe helmen information.


Mailman:

Go to /etc/mailman

Edit mm_cfg.py

Ensure that DEFAULT_EMAIL_HOST = 'lists.freegeek.org' is
correct for your particular organization.

Uncomment MTA='Postfix'

Add following lines:

POSTFIX_ALIAS_CMD = /usr/sbin/postalias
POSTFIX_MAP_CMD = /usr/sbin/postmap

Then do:

cd /usr/lib/mailman
bin/genaliases
chown list:list /var/lib/mailman/data/aliases*
chmod g+w aliases.db

Add these lines in you /etc/apache/httpd.conf file:

ScriptAlias /mailman/ /var/lib/mailman/cgi-bin/
Alias /pipermail/ /var/lib/mailman/archives/public/
<Directory /var/lib/mailman/archives>
    Options +FollowSymlinks
</Directory>
<Directory /var/lib/mailman/cgi-bin">
    AllowOverride None
    Options +ExecCGI
    Order allow,deny
    Allow from all
</Directory>

Now create the initial site password (this password is the one
that is necessary to create email lists)

Do:

cd /usr/lib/mailmain
bin/mmsitepass

This will prompt you to enter a new password. You will do
it twice for verification.


Mailman is now ready for you to create your first email list.
To set up email lists, please use your web browser and go to:
https://Your.host.name/mailmain/admin and follow the instructions.

Please note that email lists for the listserv are at:

list_name at lists.freegeek.org (or lists.yourdomain.org).

=================================================================

                    Final Notes on Email

This concludes the installation of the back-end email infrastructure.
>From here on, you will need to ensure that your DNS services have
established that this server is pointed to via an MX record for
the domain name that you will be using and that this server has
access to the outside internet (either being outside the firewall
or more preferably, be inside the firewall with a pin-hole in
the firewall for ports 25 (smtp) and port 465 (secure smtp).
Depending on your security policies,  you might also have pin-holes
set up for the imaps and pop3s (secure imap and pop3 ports; numbered
993 and 995 respectively). You will also need to open email accounts
by using the phpldapadmin utility as discussed earlier in this
document or by setting up input files for the slapadd utility.

Please also be aware that some imap and pop clients may have
problems with some types of certificates that may be used for
the imaps and pop3s (secure imap and pop) protocols.

Please also be aware that the smtp authentication is allowd only
for secure smtp connections. Attempts to perform authentication
via an non-secure smtp connection will be rejected. This is because
the auth plain method is the only one available due to the limitations
of the saslauthd authentication system. The auth plain method does
involved unencrypted passwords, which must be protected by the
covering of a secure smtp connection.

This email system is set up with limited spam filtering; this
namely via the blacklisting facility as furnished by the blacklist
sites that are configured in the /etc/postfix/main.cf file.
These blacklist sites are consulted by postfix as mail arrives
into the system. As configures, this means that email arriving
to the listserve (mailman) is also checked against the blacklist
sites before being allowed into the server.

=================================================================
Next, we will set up the Opengroupware calendaring and adressbook
service. Please not that at this time, the Opengroupware
service has its own authentication as it is not yet implemented to
authenticate by using the ldap database that is used by the
email back end for authentication.

First, we will need to set up the postgres database. Go to the
/var/lib/postgres/data directory.

Edit the pg_hba.conf file.

Ensure you have the following lines as they are below. They may be
separated by comment lines, which is okey.

local   all         all                                             trust
host    all         all         127.0.0.1         255.255.255.255   trust
host    all         all         0.0.0.0           255.255.255.255   reject

Close this file and edit the postgresql.conf file and ensure that the
tcpip_socket = true
line is there and not commented.

Close this file and then restart postgres by doing:

/etc/init.d/postgresql restart

su to the postgres user by doing

su - postgres

Then as postgres, do the follosing steps:

createdb ogo
createuser -a -d ogo
psql ogo ogo

This will put you in the postgres sql prompt. Do:

\i /usr/lib/opengroupware.org/Database/PostgreSQL/pg-build-schema.psql

You will get a bunch of output as the initial Opengroupware database
is being created on the database server. When this is done, do

\q

And you will be once again back at the system prompt.

Exit your session as postgres by typing 'exit'. You will now once
again be root.

Do:

chown -R opengroupware.skyrix /usr/lib/opengroupware.org

Then su to the opengroupware user by doing:

su - opengroupware

As the opengroupware user do the following:

source OpenGroupware.org.sh
Defaults write NSGlobalDomain LSConnectionDictionary '{hostName=localhost; userName=ogo; password=""; port=5432; databaseName=ogo}'

Defaults write NSGlobalDomain NGBundlePath "/usr/lib/opengroupware.org/Library/OpenGroupware.org"
Defaults write NSGlobalDomain LSAttachmentPath /usr/lib/opengroupware.org/documents
Defaults write NSGlobalDomain LSModelName OpenGroupware.org_PostgreSQL
Defaults write NSGlobalDomain LSAdaptor PostgreSQL72

Exit your session as opengroupware and become the root user.

You will need to create a symbolic link for the postgres library
file:

ln -s /usr/lib/libpq.so.3.1 libpq.so.2

Create a new file at /etc/init.d/opengroupware. Put in that file all
of the following lines that are between (but not including) the
################################ lines:

#!/bin/sh
#
# Startup script for OpenGroupware on UNIX systems.

# NOTE: This script currently needs to have an environment that
# automatically sources ~/OpenGroupware.sh. This is achievable with
# this command:
#
# echo "source ./OpenGroupware.sh" >> ~/.bash_profile

# chkconfig: 2345 75 25
# description: OpenGroupware is a groupware server

# Configuration section

OGO_DIR=/usr/lib/opengroupware.org
OGO_BIN=$OGO_DIR/WOApps/OpenGroupware.woa/ix86/linux-gnu/gnu-fd-nil/OpenGroupware
OGO_ARGS="-WOPort 20000 -WOHttpAllowHost localhost -OGoMinimumActiveSessionCount 0"
PID_FILE=/var/run/ogo.pid
ZID_PID_FILE=/var/run/zid.pid

LOG=/var/log/ogo.log

ZID_BIN=/usr/lib/opengroupware.org/WOApps/ZideStore.woa/ix86/linux-gnu/gnu-fd-nil/ZideStore
ZID_ARGS="-WOPort 23000 -WOHttpAllowHost localhost -SxExplain YES -WOCachingEnabled YES -WOHttpTransactionUseSimpleParser YES"

# end configuration section


# Source function library.
# Use the funtions provided by Red Hat or use our own
if [ -f /etc/rc.d/init.d/functions ]
then
        . /etc/rc.d/init.d/functions
else
        function action {
                echo "$1"
                shift
                $@
        }
        function success {
                echo -n "Success"
        }
        function failure {
                echo -n "Failed"
        }
fi


[ -x $OGO_BIN ] || exit 0

case "$1" in
        start)
                echo -n  "Starting OpenGroupware: "
                pushd $OGO_DIR > /dev/null

                # log separator
                echo "----------------------------------------------------------------------" >> $LOG

                # run as a user 'opengroupware':
                if [ "`uname -s`" = "Linux" ]; then
                    env -i su - opengroupware -c "$OGO_BIN $OGO_ARGS" >> $LOG 2>&1 &
                elif [ "`uname -s`" = "FreeBSD" ]; then
                    env -i su -l opengroupware -c "$OGO_BIN $OGO_ARGS" >> $LOG 2>&1 &
                fi

                echo $! > $PID_FILE
                env -i su - opengroupware -c "$ZID_BIN $ZID_ARGS" >> $LOG 2>&1 &
                echo $! > $ZID_PID_FILE
                popd > /dev/null
                success "Starting OpenGroupware"
                echo
                ;;

        stop)
                echo -n "Shutting down OpenGroupware: "
                if test -f "$PID_FILE" ; then
                        PID=`cat $PID_FILE`
                        ZID_PID=`cat $ZID_PID_FILE`
                        if kill $PID >> $LOG 2>&1 ; then
                                /bin/rm $PID_FILE
                                success "Shutting down OpenGroupware"
                        else
                                echo ""
                                echo "Could not kill process $PID named in $PID_FILE. Check tail of $LOG."
                                failure "Shutting down OpenGroupware"
                        fi
                        if kill $ZID_PID >> $LOG 2>&1 ; then
                                /bin/rm $ZID_PID_FILE
                                success "Shutting down OpenGroupware Zid Server"
                        else
                                echo ""
                                echo "Could not kill process $ZID_PID named in $ZID_PID_FILE. Check tail of $LOG."
                                failure "Shutting down OpenGroupware"
                        fi
                else
                        echo ""
                        echo "No OpenGroupware pid file found. Looked for $PID_FILE."
                        failure "No OpenGroupware pid file found. Looked for $PID_FILE."
                fi
                echo
                ;;

        restart)
                $0 stop
                $0 start
                ;;

        *)
                echo "Usage: opengroupware {start|stop|restart}"
                exit 1

esac

exit 0
####################################################################################

Please make this file executable by doing:

chmod +x /etc/init.d/opengroupware

Place a symbolic link to it in the /etc/rc3.d

ln -s /etc/init.d/opengroupware /etc/rc3.d/s60opengroupware


Now we need to download and compile the special Apache web connector
for Opengroupware; do:

wget http://www.opengroupware.org/sources/opengroupware.org-mod_ngobjweb-latest.tar.gz

tar xpzf opengroupware.org-mod_ngobjweb-latest.tar.gz
cd opengroupware.org-mod_ngobjweb

Edit the GNUMakefile file and ensure that the following lines
are in that file:

APXS   = /usr/bin/apxs
HTTPD  = /usr/sbin/apache

These variables may be set in lines similar to:

APACHE = /usr
APXS   = $(APACHE)/bin/apxs
HTTPD  = $(APACHE)/sbin/apache

This is okey as well. Sometimes you might see APXS = $(APACHE)/sbin/apxs
which needs to be corrected.

Now compile by doing:

make

Create the directory /usr/lib/opengroupware.org/WebServer by doing:

mkdir /usr/lib/opengroupware.org/WebServer

Copy the executable into place by doing:

cp ngobjweb_1.3.31.so /usr/lib/opengroupware.org/WebServer

Please note that this file's name may vary depending on the version
of the apache server.

Now change ownership to opengroupwer by doing:

chown -R opengroupware.skyrix /usr/lib/opengroupware.org/WebServer

Now you will need to set up the apache web server so that it can
access the opengroupware server.

As root, edit the /etc/apache/httpd.conf file.

Add the following line in the file; sometime after the
Include /etc/apache/modules.conf line:

LoadModule ngobjweb_module /usr/lib/opengroupware.org/WebServer/ngobjweb_1.3.31.so

(Note this may change, depending on the version of the apache web server)

Then, after this line, add the following lines:

<LocationMatch "^/OpenGroupware/*">
  SetHandler ngobjweb-adaptor
  SetAppPort 20000
</LocationMatch>

Alias /OpenGroupware.woa/WebServerResources/ \
      /usr/lib/opengroupware.org/WebServerResources/

Try starting the opengroupware by doing:

/etc/init.d/opengroupware start

It should start. You may, however get an error messages about
a missing shared object file. This is because the Zidestore
may be compiled with an earlier version of ssl. If this happens,
you can do:

ln -s /usr/lib/libssl.so.0.9.7 /usr/lib/libssl.so.0.9.6
ln -s /usr/lib/libcrypto.so.0.9.7 /usr/lib/libcrypto.so.0.9.6

Wow. Where to begin.
I'll start with my largest pet peeve.

Don't reject mail just because ONE rbl thinks its from a "bad" IP. If 
you've ever run a mail server for a large user base, you know that this 
will result in hundereds of lost emails.
Spamassassin (works great with postfix/amavisd, btw) can use these rbl's 
to add a few points to a total spam score.. a much better way to use an 
rbl.
Remember what happened when a not-so-friendly rbl quit the rbl business 
and just started sending "reject" to everyone that queried it?

Anyways.. the LAST thing we want is for "dummies" as you say; to be 
running mail servers! I could go on and on about this... but I think the 
  whole thing is a bad idea.

Cheers;
Charlie

Michael Robinson wrote:

>
> One thought I've had is to add another nic to the mail server and run 
> a dedicated
> line to the second ap.  I should be able to run two isolated nets 
> across the same box.  I'm using Redhat 7.3 on the mail machine.  What 
> do the iptables rules ned to be for
> a router supporting two networks that aren't allowed to exchange

> to bridge the two wireless access points together.  Short of hooking

> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
FWIW...When all I had was WEP available to secure my WIFI network at 
home I added a 3rd NIC to my firewall and put my access point on a 
completely separate network. I used OpenBSD's "authpf" feature to 
dynamically add rules to my firewall to allow access to my internal 
network from the WIFI side. Before anyone could get into the private 
network they had to authenticate through my firewall with a SSH session. 
Once the SSH session was setup a user could then get into the internal 
network. I also ran "arpwatch" which would notify me if MAC addresses 
changed on any of my WIFI hosts.  When the SSH shell session is 
terminated, the firewall rules are dynamically altered to remove the 
rule that allowed the WIFI user into the private network.

Now that access points and WIFI routers support WPA I can now use TKIP 
or AES encryption for better security. WinXP supports WPA and Linux does 
as well with the addition of the "wpa_supplicant" daemon.  I like to 
survey WIFI networks when I travel and so far I still see most WIFI 
networks left wide open with no WEP or WPA enabled at all since that's 
the default for WIFI access points and routers. WIFI works great when 
things are wide open but once people try to start using encryption 
things don't work as well, people become frustrated and tend to go back 
to having things wide open.

I've worked on setting WIFI networks up for the last  1 1/2 years and 
trying to get everyone's client working with WEP or WPA can be time 
consuming.  My own take is that since both WinXP and Linux have support 
for WPA and all of the newer access points and routers also support WPA 
that it should be used over WEP. I know there can be legacy support 
issues with WPA and so sometime an older system only supports WEP. I 
used to have a Win2K laptop I was issued from work and it only supported 
WEP and so I wasn't able to use WPA at home until I was issued a newer 
laptop that runs both WinXP and Linux.

Tony

Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

Greylisting is a very helpful approach.  It keeps you from working
with people who don't configure their mail servers correctly.
Even though it slows mail down, it has stopped practically all
of the junk.
  
The other thing I do is block unresolvable mail clients which probably
stops the bulk of the junk, but this will block a lot of valid sites.  I've
been trying to run relays out of ramdisk, but so far I haven't modified
the postfix scripts to make this will work well.  What I would like is
a daemon that occasionally backs up, or updates, what is backed up
on five minute intervals.  During a shutdown, the daemon should
image what's on ramdisk in entirety.  When mail is flowing, there
shouldn't be anything cached and hence no wear on my flash device.
Rejecting when you can't find the supplied hostname stops a lot of
garbage.  I wish there was a way to discourage the sources of the
junk though.  I think a lot of it is coming from worms.  I get a lot
of the same junk from supposedly different sites, so I wonder
if the orgin is the same.

I'm all for looking into why people have difficulty implementing secure
email systems.  Every insecure server with Net access increases the
amount of abuse possible.  The slow adoption of widely supported
standards also contributes to the spam epidemic.  There is a lot of narrow
minded shortsighted code in email today which is largely proprietary and
hardly tested.  If IM2000 can be implemented in such a way that it doesn't
increase the amount of email a person gets, it sounds very promising as
a tool to control what comes in and where it comes in from.  The best
content filters engage before the content is received.  There aren't safe
email formats for everything people want to do, especially when
attachments are considered.

Use of RHSBL's and IP block lists with insecure and incomplete DNS
infrastructure seems questionable in my mind.  Block lists are a
challenge to maintain, especially if the source is forged.  A clever 
attacker
that wants you to block someone they don't like could forge that someone
in a rude message to you.  I'd say everyone should turn anti forging 
features
on in their MTA, but not everyone can depending on their needs.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jun 27 11:36:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sun Jun 27 11:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] aha, you _can_ shrink an ntfs with free tools!
Message-ID: <86zn6oalx4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

A few of you may recall at the last clinic a guy who wanted to install
linux on a box with Windows XP.  Most of us, seemingly, weren't sure
about whether it was possible to repartition an ntfs installation with
free tools.  I had shrunken a w2k fat32 filesystem a few years ago
with a different tool.  Several people remembered GNU parted, and when
we looked at that, we found that it didn't support (or didn't seem to
support) ntfs.  We had punted to partition magic, which none of us
actually had, so the guy we were trying to help was more or less SOL
on the dual booting front. His windows xp software was a
"quickrestore" type of thing that restored a 40gig filesystem, mashing
flat everything in its path.  So we just nuked xp and started working
on installing debian from CDs.  Due to the late-ish start, we didn't
quite finish.

Flash forward to last Thursday evening when he calls me at home for
some help on installing Knoppix on his harddisk.  This is another
thing I'd never done before, but with me at a networked desktop, I
could at least find stuff/instructions online.  Pretty soon I realized
that Knoppix included something called "qtparted" (IIRC) and also
("gee, this looks promising!") "ntfsresize".  A little fiddling and he
is all fixed up with free tools.

So, salt that one away.  It could come in handy in the future.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

On Sun, 27 Jun 2004, Russell Senior wrote:

>
> A few of you may recall at the last clinic a guy who wanted to install
> linux on a box with Windows XP.  Most of us, seemingly, weren't sure
> about whether it was possible to repartition an ntfs installation with
> free tools.  I had shrunken a w2k fat32 filesystem a few years ago
> with a different tool.  Several people remembered GNU parted, and when
> we looked at that, we found that it didn't support (or didn't seem to
> support) ntfs.  We had punted to partition magic, which none of us
> actually had, so the guy we were trying to help was more or less SOL

I assume this is what Mandrake uses.  When I need to resize an NTFS
partition for a dual-boot computer, I boot into Windows and defrag the
NTFS partition, then boot from a Mandrake 9.2 CD and resize the NTFS
partition, then I cancel the Mandrake install and install my distro of
choice.  I've never encountered any problems.
~M






From heinlein at madboa.com  Sun Jun 27 13:59:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun Jun 27 13:59:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] New FC2 Install Fails to Recognize Ethernet Card
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406271414560.13446-100000@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406271414560.13446-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406271352450.11745@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sun, 27 Jun 2004 bthoen at gisnet.com wrote:

> What I'd like to know is what might have gone wrong, and is there a 
> way to manually configure an ethernet card if kudzu doesn't notice 
> it? Everything else seemed to load up just fine. Or is a PII machine 
> just too old for FC2?

No. I've got FC2 on a dual P-II and it runs like a champ. Does lspci 
report anything? E.g.,

   /sbin/lspci | grep -i ether

What module does it run in Red Hat 8/9? You might try searching 
through Red Hat's module configuration file, e.g.,

   [heinlein]$ grep -i eth /etc/modules.conf
   alias eth0 e100

Since Fedora Core 2 is based on the 2.6.x kernel series, while Red Hat 
8/9 run 2.4.x, the module required might have changed names.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

What kind of ethernet card is it?  Is it pci or isa?  If it is isa, you
may have to use the plug and play utilities to get it to configure
correctly.  Do you know what chipset it is?  It could also be trying to
load the wrong driver.  (That problem occurs on some older versions of
the Realtek chipset.)

Hard to say what the problem is without knowing a bit more about your
hardware.

software reduces the size of this market. Why not
apply this "logic" to hardware? Say there are 100

available then would cost $4,000. So if those
currently in service don't cost a total of $400
billion, this indicates the extent to which purchasers
are getting a free ride.

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Jun 28 13:27:01 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Mon Jun 28 13:27:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: New FC2 Install Fails to Recognize Ethernet Card 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406280822250.16556-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406281225150.32283-100000@www.fnordora.org>

On Mon, 28 Jun 2004 bthoen at gisnet.com wrote:

> Sorry I didn't get back to y'all sooner, but the PLUG server must have
> thought I was out of action and it didn't send me your responses. I guess
> you can't bounce too many message before it cuts you off. Anyway, it's
> sending me mail again, but I had to get these response off the web
> archive.
> 
> To answer Alan's query, the card I'm using is an ISA BOCAlan 2000 Plus, a
> "plug and pray" device.  From /var/log/dmesg it reports that the machine
> is a Intel Pentium II (Klamath) with 288Mb RAM running at 233.867 MHz. The
> PCI BIOS is rev 2.4, and the "PII4X: Chipset" is rev 1. Is that the info
> you need to diagnose this, or do I need to look elsewhere?

ISA devices are usually not probed for, due to the tendancy to hang the 
machine.  (This is true in Windows as well.)

There are a set of isa tools available.  I forget what they are called at 
the moment.  (pnpdump?)

I am betting that the card is an ne2000 clone.  You can try loading that 
driver by hand and see if it works.  Also look for driver called "ne".  
That seems to be the driver for that card a long time ago.

If you can, i would replace that card with a pci ethernet card.  You will 
be happy you did.  ISA is just a bad idea.

From randal.t.pluimer at intel.com  Mon Jun 28 15:07:02 2004
From: randal.t.pluimer at intel.com (Pluimer, Randal T)
Date: Mon Jun 28 15:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] BEFW11S4 WiFi Routers
Message-ID: <C925F8B43D79CC49ACD0601FB68FF50C01259DF3@orsmsx408>

Quick howto for wireless is that there are only 3 "real" channels
Because these are 802.11b they use spread spectrum. This means that 1-5,
6-1-, and 11-14 are your only real channels and have built in guard
frequencies separating them.
Yes I know they only show 11 channels. That's because the FCC can't read
or understand technical issues sometimes.
So.... A high channel is anything above 10. Moving your channel to 7
from 6 really means your now broadcasting from 7-11 and probably
overlapping the person who has his set on 11. Interference can cause
problems with these as dropped packets etc tend to cause a lot of
retries and result in processing overhead for which there is little to
give on these units.

On Mon, 28 Jun 2004, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Mon, 2004-06-28 at 03:55 -0700, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > Maybe just tha homocidal lunatics come in all different ideologies?
>
> The vast majority of gun owners... regardless of the OS they're running
> (SCO, Windows, Linux, Slowarus, OS X, whatever), never shoot at a human
> being.

Thank goodness!  If they did, we'd have many thousands more deaths every
year.

The concern, of course, wasn't with "most gun owners", but with folks who
carry weapons on their person in public.  And while most may never
_actually_ shoot at a human being, that is the intent of the weapon and
the carrying.

> Of those who do shoot at a human being, I'd have to guess most don't
> kill the person they're shooting at.  Of those who do kill who they're
> shooting at, not all would be considered 'homicidal' which is considered
> analogous with murderous.

Homicide is killing another human being in my book -- the law of the land
notwithstanding.  That hints at one of the major problems with capital
punishment -- it is permanent while the law of the land is transient --
and also one of the major problems with "vigilante justice" -- it
eliminates any notion of due process.

> I'd say calling gun owners homicidal lunatics is analogous to calling
> gay men pedophiles.

Well, nobody called gun owners homocidal and I think the stronger analogy
would be calling sexually interested people pedophiles (you'll find that
most pedophiliacs are men lusting after young women, so "gay men" doesn't
seem to apply -- unless, of course, you're hinting at the relative
proportion of homocides committed by gun versus pedophilic acts committed
by gay men, but I think that's unlikely because I don't think you consider
the homocidal weapon of choice (the automobile) to be muderous and so what
you'd call homicide is done by gun more often than anything else in this
country).

If you want argue this sanely and without specious analogy, let's take it
to plug-talk.

J.

On Mon, 28 Jun 2004, alan wrote:

> On Mon, 28 Jun 2004 bthoen at gisnet.com wrote:
> 
> > To answer Alan's query, the card I'm using is an ISA BOCAlan 2000 Plus, a
> > "plug and pray" device.  From /var/log/dmesg it reports that the machine
> > is a Intel Pentium II (Klamath) with 288Mb RAM running at 233.867 MHz. The
> > PCI BIOS is rev 2.4, and the "PII4X: Chipset" is rev 1. Is that the info
> > you need to diagnose this, or do I need to look elsewhere?
> 
> I am betting that the card is an ne2000 clone.  You can try loading that 
> driver by hand and see if it works.  Also look for driver called "ne".  
> That seems to be the driver for that card a long time ago.

I think it is an ne2000 clone. To "load the driver by hand" do you mean 
that I edit /etc/modules.conf and add a line like:
alias eth0 ne

or something like it and then reboot? Then how do I tell it what the IP,
netmask, and gateway are? Will the configuration dialogs appear now?

A module called ne.o exists in RH 9.0 in
/lib/modules/2.4.20-6/kernel/drivers/net/, but if this isn't available in
FC2 is that what would cause the ethernet card not to be recognized during
the reboot phase of a new install? Because that's the symptom. In RH 7.3,
8.0, and 9.0 the system automatically recognized the card and allowed me
to set the IP, etc., but in FC2 this step never appeared.

I've searched the mailing list archives at RedHat.com and Fedora.org, and
all I discovered was 1.) these lists are hard to search efficiently, and
2.) there is a problem with kudzu and certain 3Comm NICs to which the
solution is to turn off kudzu. I've tried searching on various
combinations of keywords like FC2, eth0, recognized, bug, NIC, ethernet,
and bocalan. I further learned that "bocalan" doesn't show up anywhere. 
Any new search strategy suggestions would be welcome here...

> If you can, i would replace that card with a pci ethernet card.  You will 
> be happy you did.  ISA is just a bad idea.

<Sigh!> ISA was a good idea until a few months ago... I mean, it works
flawlessly with all RedHat versions through 9.0. Oh well, I suppose you're
right. It just grieves me that if I want to use the latest distros, I have
to buy the latest hardware or I nearly always run into trouble bigger than
my head. I just hate throwing out perfectly good --but old-- equipment,
just because I don't know how to tweak things. 

Unless I can figure this out, I'll probably just stay with RH 9.0 if
Fedora can't handle my "legacy" (i.e. "old and in the way") equipment.

- Bill Thoen

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun 28 17:38:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jun 28 17:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: New FC2 Install Fails to Recognize Ethernet Card 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406281731150.18517-100000@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406281731150.18517-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406281730420.30445@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 28 Jun 2004, Bill Thoen wrote:

> I think it is an ne2000 clone. To "load the driver by hand" do you mean
> that I edit /etc/modules.conf and add a line like: alias eth0 ne

Bill,

  You'll do that once you are sure that's the correct driver. Before then,
after the system boots, type 'modprobe ne' to load the module, then 'lsmod'
to see if it's there.

> or something like it and then reboot? Then how do I tell it what the IP,
> netmask, and gateway are? Will the configuration dialogs appear now?

  This is just the physical connection between the cat5 cable and your
system. What you want to do is edit /etc/hosts, /etc/hosts.deny,
/etc/hosts.allow, /etc/hosts.lpd and /etc/hosts.equiv (I think that's the
set).

> A module called ne.o exists in RH 9.0 in
> /lib/modules/2.4.20-6/kernel/drivers/net/, but if this isn't available in
> FC2 is that what would cause the ethernet card not to be recognized during
> the reboot phase of a new install? Because that's the symptom. In RH 7.3,
> 8.0, and 9.0 the system automatically recognized the card and allowed me
> to set the IP, etc., but in FC2 this step never appeared.

  As Alan wrote, pick up an inexpensive pci NIC and use that. You'll be a
lot happier now and in the future.

> <Sigh!> ISA was a good idea until a few months ago... I mean, it works
> flawlessly with all RedHat versions through 9.0. Oh well, I suppose you're
> right. It just grieves me that if I want to use the latest distros, I have
> to buy the latest hardware or I nearly always run into trouble bigger than
> my head. I just hate throwing out perfectly good --but old-- equipment,
> just because I don't know how to tweak things.

  Er, ... actually, Bill, ISA cards were obsolete at least 5 years ago. That
you've had it continue to work is a testament to the linux driver folks
(hail, Greg!) who've kept it going. And, didn't you tell me only a few years
ago that every time Microsquish came out with a new version of their OS
you'd buy new hardware because upgrading in place was such a PITA?

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Mon Jun 28 19:05:03 2004
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Mon Jun 28 19:05:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: New FC2 Install Fails to Recognize Ethernet Card 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406281730420.30445@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406281859530.18788-100000@gisnet.com>

On Mon, 28 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Mon, 28 Jun 2004, Bill Thoen wrote:
> 
> > or something like it and then reboot? Then how do I tell it what the IP,
> > netmask, and gateway are? Will the configuration dialogs appear now?
> 
>   This is just the physical connection between the cat5 cable and your
> system. What you want to do is edit /etc/hosts, /etc/hosts.deny,
> /etc/hosts.allow, /etc/hosts.lpd and /etc/hosts.equiv (I think that's the
> set).

Don't think that's all there is to it. I know there's one or more other 
files that associate eth0 with IP, netmask, gateway and DNS IP addresses. 
That info is not in those files you mention. For example, how does 
resolv.conf get populated? There's another I have in my notes at my office 
(but can't remember just now) that associates eth0 with all those numbers 
and more. I just don't know what program to run or what files to modify to 
get the necesssary data in the system.

> ... And, didn't you tell me only a few years ago that every time
> Microsquish came out with a new version of their OS you'd buy new
> hardware because upgrading in place was such a PITA?

Yep. It cost about $600 to upgrade to XP. But to tell you the truth, Rich,
I'm not saving any money with Linux at this point. I've lost several days
time trying to get this server back on its feet again. Upgrading Linux is
just as big a PITA as any other OS. And patching security holes is a
constant chore and always a PITA, just like any other OS. And if you ever
try to syncronize a new OS version with the right newer versions of
software you've had to build from source (because the rpms weren't set up
to do what you needed) good luck! I'm getting really tired of trying to
trying to get MySQL and PHP working together again with the newest RedHat
I can manage to get running so I can get my damn web pages working again.

And Linux is not magically secure, either. I've been hacked nearly as many
times using Linux as I have with Windows. I can still get free automatic
updates from Microsoft, but I can't use up2date anymore (and I haven't yet
had time to learn yum.) So right now for me Linux is harder to maintain
than Windows.

In short, I'm learning that Linux exacts its price, too. And it's NOT 
cheap when you have to make a living doing something else besides fooling 
around with a cranky server and cranky software. All of this hassle is due 
to my ignorance, of course, but when I see even experts like you go 
through epics like your current wifi experience, I wonder where is the 
light at the end of this tunnel?!? I'll never be smart enough to learn 
everything I have to learn to realize the dream I hoped for.

But I'll keep trying. I still believe that sweat equity will pay off 
eventually vs. paying rent to Microsoft, but sometimes my faith is tried 
sore.

- Bill Thoen

On Mon, 28 Jun 2004, Bill Thoen wrote:

> Don't think that's all there is to it. I know there's one or more other
> files that associate eth0 with IP, netmask, gateway and DNS IP addresses.
> That info is not in those files you mention. For example, how does
> resolv.conf get populated? There's another I have in my notes at my office
> (but can't remember just now) that associates eth0 with all those numbers
> and more. I just don't know what program to run or what files to modify to
> get the necesssary data in the system.

  No. Forgot about those. Red Hat has, IIRC, 'netcfg' or something like
that. It'll set up the interfaces for you. /etc/resolv.conf has the
locations of the DNS servers to use. For example, on my RH 7,3 box it has:

#search appl-ecosys.com aracnet.com
nameserver 192.168.55.1         #a.ns.appl-ecosys.com
#nameserver 216.99.193.1        #ns.aracnet.com
#nameserver 216.99.193.19       #ns2.aracnet.com
#nameserver 216.99.193.2        #ns3.aracnet.com

  I'm running a caching name server here so only the second line is active.
Prior to this, I used my ISP's name servers.

> Yep. It cost about $600 to upgrade to XP. But to tell you the truth, Rich,
> I'm not saving any money with Linux at this point. I've lost several days
> time trying to get this server back on its feet again. Upgrading Linux is
> just as big a PITA as any other OS. And patching security holes is a
> constant chore and always a PITA, just like any other OS. And if you ever
> try to syncronize a new OS version with the right newer versions of
> software you've had to build from source (because the rpms weren't set up
> to do what you needed) good luck! I'm getting really tired of trying to
> trying to get MySQL and PHP working together again with the newest RedHat
> I can manage to get running so I can get my damn web pages working again.

  Ah, we've all had these problems. Unfortunately, I don't know a solution
that's satisfactory to everyone or on all aspects. However, once you do get
set up again, other than security patches that apply to you you can just
keep using it.

> And Linux is not magically secure, either. I've been hacked nearly as many
> times using Linux as I have with Windows.

  Firewall. Can't run naked without anticipating problems. You do lock your
front door when you leave at night, don't you? We can't complain about
getting run over if we walk down the middle of the road wearing dark clothes
on rainy nights.

> ... but when I see even experts like you go through epics like your
> current wifi experience, I wonder where is the light at the end of this
> tunnel?!? I'll never be smart enough to learn everything I have to learn
> to realize the dream I hoped for.

  The WiFi saga is OS agnostic. It's the equipment. And the more you work
with the OS the more you learn. IMO, you can never become competent at
anything without practice or continual learning. Right now you're still on
the toe of the learning curve, but you've also been forced into paying more
attention than you did before. That's paying off both immediately and in the
future.

> But I'll keep trying. I still believe that sweat equity will pay off

  Yup. It _would_ be easier with a local group offering hands-on help.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun 28 20:51:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jun 28 20:51:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: New FC2 Install Fails to Recognize Ethernet Card 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406282051390.19014-100000@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0406282051390.19014-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406282047250.31769@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 28 Jun 2004, Bill Thoen wrote:

> On Mon, 28 Jun 2004, Charles Sliger wrote:
>
> That's it! /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0. What do you use to
> populate that if on a clean install the system doesn't offer to allow you
> to set up networking? If I have to set up networking manually, what else
> do I need to do?

Bill,

  The 'netcfg' program should ask all the questions and write the answers to
the proper file. The ifcfg-eth0, tcp-wrappers in /etc/host* and
/etc/resolv.conf are all you need. Oh, you need to run
'/etc/rc.d/init.d/network start', too.

Rich

a bad thing.  It's a clear sign of monopolistic practices.
The community conscious entrepeneur looks for ways
to lower the cost of computing for consumers.  There's
tremendous room for growth in the computer services
sector.  With more broadband, we are finally reaching
a point that providing information services in a
timely manner is becoming realistic.

One area I see great potential in is helping people filter
mail and web content.  Another area is providing
assistance with online research remotely.  Someone
lets you know what they want to do with open source
tools and you figure it out for them complete with an
explanation they can follow, for a reasonable fee.
Custom programming for people with a large online
conduit to deliver a product to them through is also
an interesting area.
