I have a regular expression problem that I have not be able to solve with 
one
regular expression.  I can solve it with two but would like to use just 
one.

Problem description: A file that has multiple lines like the following 
(max ten lines):
"Detailed Test Description" testname "-d test-args more-test-args"

The problem is that the last set of args may not be there at all.
I need to match none, two or three fields and extract just the fields.
The match for the first two without the third is as follows:
^"([\s\S]*)"(?:\s+)(\S+)

The match for all three is as follows
^"([\s\S]*)"(?:\s+)(\S+)(?:\s+)"([\s\S]*)"

I would like to change the two into one search such that the
third search/match is optional and would not interfere with the first two
matches.  If necessary, I can change the format of the list since it is 
going into
one of my own programs.  (No this is not some class exercise)

This might not be the best but it is a starting point.  I hope someone can 
help me through 
this.

On Mon, Jun 28, 2004 at 10:04:30PM -0700, Michael Robinson wrote:
>
> Just out of curiosity, is there a project to stabilize legacy versions
> of Redhat and minimize interoperability issues between Redhat
> and other Linux distros?  I want to run maple 9.02 for Redhat 9
> on the current gentoo, but I'm at a loss as far as what the graphical

Fedora Legacy project, http://fedoralegacy.org/, provides security
updates for Red Hat Linux.

Running Red Hat packages on other distributions is another problem
entirely because few people care about using packages on other
distributions, especially ones with a different package management
scheme.  You will need to provide the dependencies manually.  Do a
"rpm -qp --depends package.rpm" to list the dependencies.  And then
try to get the right versions installed on your machine.

 - Ian

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Jun 29 09:05:03 2004
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue Jun 29 09:05:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Regex condition match problem
In-Reply-To: <OF56BC5747.0186B8E0-ON88256EC2.00525F76-88256EC2.00540E99@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>
References: <OF56BC5747.0186B8E0-ON88256EC2.00525F76-88256EC2.00540E99@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>
Message-ID: <20040629160342.GC14623@dalsemi.com>

On Tue, Jun 29, 2004 at 08:17:13AM -0700, lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com wrote:
> I have a regular expression problem that I have not be able to solve with 
> one
> regular expression.  I can solve it with two but would like to use just 
> one.
> 
> Problem description: A file that has multiple lines like the following 
> (max ten lines):
> "Detailed Test Description" testname "-d test-args more-test-args"
>
> The problem is that the last set of args may not be there at all.
> I need to match none, two or three fields and extract just the fields.
> The match for the first two without the third is as follows:
> ^"([\s\S]*)"(?:\s+)(\S+)
> 
> The match for all three is as follows
> ^"([\s\S]*)"(?:\s+)(\S+)(?:\s+)"([\s\S]*)"

If that's exactly the kind of input that you're looking for, then you
don't want to write your own regular expressions.  Based on that regular
expression syntax, it looks like you're using Perl, and it turns out that
perl comes with a module for parsing exactly the kind of input data that
you're working with.

It's called Text::ParseWords, and if you type:

perldoc Text::ParseWords

on the command line it will bring up the documentation for you
to read.

Good luck!

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Jun 29 09:32:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Jun 29 09:32:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] NFS rpm installation as ROOT
In-Reply-To: <20040629162014.B91E44054@joseph.doink.com>
References: <20040629162014.B91E44054@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406290926370.3451@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 29 Jun 2004, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:

> As root I can install rpms.  As root I can access files over NFS. 
> But, as root I can _not_ install rpms that reside on an NFS mounted 
> drive.  I would like to install rpms on my system when the RPM files 
> live on an NFS'd drive.  How can I do this?  Thanks....

My hunch is that the problem isn't with RPM, but with your NFS export 
environment.

If you've got the default root_squash export setting, then root on the 
NFS client looks like user nobody to the server. If nobody can't read 
the exported files, then root on the client can't read them either.

The best solution is probably to make sure that the rpm repository on 
the nfs server is world-readable, e.g.,

   cd /root/of/repos
   find . -type d -exec chmod o+rx {} \;
   find . -type f -exec chmod o+r {} \;

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Jun 29 10:50:04 2004
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue Jun 29 10:50:04 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Regex condition match problem

On Tue, Jun 29, 2004 at 09:54:26AM -0700, lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com wrote:
> >
> >If that's exactly the kind of input that you're looking for, then you
> >don't want to write your own regular expressions.  Based on that regular
> >expression syntax, it looks like you're using Perl, and it turns out that
> >perl comes with a module for parsing exactly the kind of input data that
> >you're working with.
> >
> >It's called Text::ParseWords, and if you type:
> >
> >perldoc Text::ParseWords
> 
> Actually I'm doing this with the regex functtions that is include in
> the QT 3.x library/framework.

Then why not try this:

/^("[^"]+")\s*(\S+)?\s*("[^"]+")?/

^		Beginning of line
("[^"]+")	Find a bunch of characters that aren't quotes surrounded by quotes
\s*		Optional whitespace, in case you only have 1 argument on the line
(\S+)?		Optional second argument of non-whitespace
("[^"]+")?	Quoted sequence, optional

Colin

Note to others:

    When you want help with regex, remember that ALL regex engines are
    NOT alike.  Please specify your engine and requirements.

Otherwise, we give Perl answers, pissing you off if you're not a Perl
user, and pissing us off for wasting time.

Also, PCRE is *not* Perl Compatible, in spite of the name.  So don't
confuse the two.

On Tue, Jun 29, 2004 at 01:25:55PM -0700, lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com wrote:
> >On Tue, Jun 29, 2004 at 09:54:26AM -0700, lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com wrote:
> >> 
> >> Actually I'm doing this with the regex functtions that is include in
> >> the QT 3.x library/framework.
> 
> >Then why not try this:
> 
> >/^("[^"]+")\s*(\S+)?\s*("[^"]+")?/
> 
> >^                               Beginning of line
> >("[^"]+")               Find a bunch of characters that aren't quotes 
> surrounded by quotes
> >\s*                             Optional whitespace, in case you only 
> have 1 argument on the line
> >(\S+)?                          Optional second argument of 
> non-whitespace
> >("[^"]+")?              Quoted sequence, optional
> 
> That almost got what I wanted.  Thanks, it pointed me in the direction I 
> needed.
> I didn't want the quote returned as part of the selected string.
> 
> Here is what I will be using:
> 
> /^"([^"]+)"\s*(\S+)?\s*"?([^"]+)?/
> 
> I didn't connect that the ? was to be after the expresion to make it 
> optional.

If you're going to use regular expressions, I'd recomment getting a
copy of Jeff Friedl's book, Mastering Regular Expressions.  It will
help your understanding a lot.

Also, the perlre and perlretut manpages do a good job of explaining
regular expression, but as Randal pointed out, they're perl specific.

Colin

completely "perl compatible".

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Jun 29 16:13:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue Jun 29 16:13:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] BEFW11S4 woes
Message-ID: <20040629231229.GC9755@gate.kl-ic.com>

A while back, I did a crude characterization of the power supplies on a 
Linksys BEFW11S4, and on a WRT54G.  These devices use an internal power
supply regulator that is designed to draw constant power from the external
wall wart.  In engineer-speak, such regulators have "negative differential
resistance".  

The cheap-ass wallwarts that come with these units have quite a bit of
"positive differential resistance".  The result can be instability,
where in times of high extra load (say, when the unit is doing a lot of
computing, and reading and writing the EEPROM) the power supply can sag
into failure.  The Linksys wallwarts are speced at 12V/1A, while the
idling power of my BEFW11S4 is 3 watts.  However, I can imagine some
units might draw higher power, some wallwarts might be more resistive
and less capable, and the combination might sometimes fail. 

So, an expedient fix that may keep the unit sane is to clean the contacts
on the power supply plug.  If that doesn't help,  replace the wall wart
with a higher power, lower resistance one.  Anything between 12V and 18V
with a higher current rating should work.  The 12V 3.6A IBM thinkpad
chargers work fine, and it would be an interesting experiment to loan
one to Rich and see if it makes his BEFW11S4 less balky.

At the end of the day, these devices are cheap because they use very few
parts;  that should make them reliable.  On the other hand, some of the
parts are poorly tested, or not tested at all, and monster CMOS chips
like those found in the BEFW11S4 can be devilishly hard to test.  Note
that the same chips are used by most of Linksys's competitors.

All electronics, without exception, is flawed.  Fortunately, most of
the time the flaws are too subtle to detect, or too obvious to ignore.
However, there are some flaws that are on the spectrum between these
extremes, and it is very expensive to test something at a factory more
completely than months of usage will test it.  The really surprising
thing to me is that this stuff works as well as it does, given the 
tests that can be economically run on it.  Days of burn-in with cycling
racks, with continuous diags, will probably catch about 70% of the flaws.
But this would double the price, and would you pay 2X to reduce a 10%
chance of failure to 3% - especially if the average chance of "user
failure" is close to 50% ?   Most of us here are more attentive to
documentation and are better problem solvers, so our "user failure"
rates are closer to 10%, perhaps justifying more tested hardware.

Note that "refurbishment" for many manufacturers means running returned
units through testing, and putting the "no fault detected" units back in
the queue to send out as refurbs.   If the test is incomplete, then the
same unit may torment two or three users until somebody finally gives up
in frustration.  I think this is a shitty practice, but hey, if Microsoft
can do it and get away with it, why not the hardware guys?

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

One of the things I like about the text-only interface is that it gets 
me closer to the essentials of what's going on. Like driving a jeep with a 
stick shift, a text-only interface allows me to get stuck in more remote 
places. The lessons are harder, but once you learn, you have a much deeper 
appreciation for the knowledge. And once you know what files do or hold 
what, you can do things with a text editor you couldn't even dream of 
using someone else's GUI.

It's more of an aesthetic thing with me than a practical one. 

Ands thanks for pointing out this netconfig skeleton, Wil. It looks like 
that is what writes/modifies the ifcfg-eth0 file!

- Bill Thoen

From griffint at pobox.com  Tue Jun 29 21:03:02 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Tue Jun 29 21:03:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] HPFS
In-Reply-To: <1088565988.2277.75.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
References: <1088565988.2277.75.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
Message-ID: <200406292102.47947.griffint@pobox.com>

On Tuesday 29 June 2004 8:26 pm, Marv wrote:
> HI
>
> How do I get HPFS <High Performance File System>
> zip disks to work?
>
>

Something like:

    mount -t hpfs /dev/whatever /mnt/zip

Of course you have to have the right device driver loaded first, and
directory /mnt/zip must already exist.  And your kernel had to have
been built with HPFS support enabled.

I remember there being two drivers for parallel-port zip drives, ppa and
something else depending on the generation of the product. For IDE zip
drives you need the ide-floppy module. For USB you just need USB
mass storage. The USB driver should auto-load when you plug in the
device. For the other drivers you may have to manually load them with
the "modprobe" utility.

For parallel port and USB your device node will be a SCSI device. If
it happend to be the first SCSI device then the command would be:

    mount -t hpfs /dev/sda4 /mnt/zip

For the IDE floppy driver your device node would be an IDE node. If
it happened to be the third IDE device then the command would be:

    mount -t hpfs /dev/hdc4 /mnt/zip

Normally zip drives have a single partition #4. That's why sda4
or hdc4.

Terry

      **********************************************************
          
				 PRESENTATION

	      Greylisting and a Look at the Anti-Spam Landscape

				      by

				 Hal Pomeranz
			      <hal at deer-run.com>


       Black lists (both automated and not), white lists,
       keyword/regexp/Bayesian filters, SPF, and now "greylisting"-- where
       will the continuing anti-spam arms race take us next?  This talk
       includes an overview of current anti-spam techniques with some
       thoughts on their relative pros and cons, and a more in-depth look at
       the recently available "greylisting" technique, which is proving
       amazingly effective at blocking certain classes of spam.
    
       Hal Pomeranz is the technical lead and official spam eradicator for
       Deer Run Associates, a small consulting firm (recently relocated to
       Eugene, OR).  But this is merely his "mild-mannered secret identity"
       that hides his exploits as a Faculty Member and Senior Unix Instructor
       for the SANS Institute, Technical Advisor for the Center for Internet
       Security, and Technical Editor for Sys Admin Magazine.

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Wed Jun 30 09:19:01 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Wed Jun 30 09:19:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Debian iptables firewall rule generator (like lokkit?)
In-Reply-To: <40E0921E.2080507@tercent.com>
References: <40E0921E.2080507@tercent.com>
Message-ID: <1088612444.6033.6.camel@timmy>

On Mon, 2004-06-28 at 14:48, Randall Lucas wrote:
> There are a number of packages but those I've tried seem very unfriendly 
> (see, for example, the init script with one package that claims "don't 
> use this init script, write your own" -- whaaa??).

...

> I have simple needs, like punching through ssh, http/s, and ntp.

If your needs are as simple as mine, then all you need to do is write
the rules yourself (or use one of the utilities mentioned in the initd
script) and then use that initd script that tells you not to use it.

On a server with nothing but ssh and http, this is what I do:

iptables -F INPUT
iptables -P INPUT DROP # DON'T DO THIS OVER A NETWORK CONNECTION!
iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j ACCEPT
iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT

But don't blame me if that leaves you open to attack.

Evan

From plug.9.faster at spamgourmet.com  Wed Jun 30 10:20:04 2004
From: plug.9.faster at spamgourmet.com (plug.9.faster at spamgourmet.com)
Date: Wed Jun 30 10:20:04 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Debian iptables firewall rule generator (like lokkit?)
In-Reply-To: <1088612444.6033.6.camel@timmy>
References: <40E0921E.2080507@tercent.com> <1088612444.6033.6.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040630171913.GB26338@merlot.com>

Evan Heidtmann (clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com) typed this ...
> On a server with nothing but ssh and http, this is what I do:
> 
> iptables -F INPUT
> iptables -P INPUT DROP # DON'T DO THIS OVER A NETWORK CONNECTION!
> iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j ACCEPT
> iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT
> 
> But don't blame me if that leaves you open to attack.

This is simple, but having survived a crack a few years back, I can
attest that it is CRITICAL to block outgoing connections as well. IRC is
a good start, since crackers use IRC to advertise their conquests. If
the machine isn't supposed to send email, MAKE SURE it can't! Even
though we all learned how to trick a machine into mailing its passwd
file out (back when no one used MD5 passwords in a shadow file), no one
seems willing to lock that down on a utility machine. 

If the server is web-only but has to send email (and you have another
server for email), allow email to be sent only to/through your mail
server.  The rootkits like to send email direectly to leave fewer
footprints, and this will block them.

Basically, allow only traffic you know you want. Allowing all outgoing
traffic has bitten me, and will probably bite you too.

--Kurt

    Merlot Research Group, Inc               http://www.merlot.com

From aaron at bavariati.org  Wed Jun 30 11:26:02 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Wed Jun 30 11:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive testing.
In-Reply-To: <40E2F6B9.9010800@dimstar.net>
References: <40E2F6B9.9010800@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <20040630182524.GA13961@bavariati.org>

On Wed, Jun 30, 2004 at 10:22:01AM -0700, Russ Johnson wrote:
> What do folks use for hard drive testing?
> 
> I have a drive I think might be bad, but I can't verify it.
> 
> I'm looking for something like memtest86, for hard drives.

That would be badblocks, which can do a read-only or a destructive
write-read-verify test.  It'll even do a nondestructive read-write-
read-verify-restore cycle so it puts the data back when it's done.

You can tell e2fsck to do a readonly badblocks scan with the -c option
and a nondestructive write-read test with -cc.  
Takes a loooong time, though.

And yes, the SMART tools can tell you a bit about what the drive thinks
about its own health.  But we all know how accurate self-assessments can
be...

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun 30 14:17:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jun 30 14:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Customer Service from Hell
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301314370.9174@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  The bottom line: don't buy Linksys!

  Over a 3-day period I've spoken with five different drones at Linksys
Customer Service. The first two promised to e-mail the authorization form
for me to pay the difference in product prices (from the BEFW11S4 to the
WAP54G). Nothing arrived.

  This morning I call again (I think their so-called customer service is
outsourced overseas) and voice #3 tells me she'll send it right out. I tail
the mail log and sure enough, in a couple of minutes the authorization
message is in my inbox. So, I fill it in according to the directions and
send it back to the reply address, "customerservice at linksys.com".

  Only a few seconds later I get a MAILER-DAEMON bounce message in my inbox:
from the mail server at cisco.com: "550 We ain't got no user named
'customerservice'". Nice, eh? So, I call again and get drone #4. Her name,
she tells me, is Jan. After giving her both RMA numbers, the case number, my
phone number and e-mail address (all this for the fourth time, of course), I
finally manage -- by speaking very slowly and clearly -- that I cannot
return their authorization because the username does not exist. There is no
'customerservice at linksys.com'. I think she understands. She asks me to wait
while she checks this out. After 20 minutes on hold listening to very poor
quality Muzak(R) or whatever they use, I hang up and have lunch.

  After lunch I call back and speak with 'Dale' (four female voices and one
mail voice). I ask to speak with a supervisor, manager or Vice President,
whichever is available Right Now. Wait on hold. Dale comes back on the line
and asks, "Why do you want to speak with a supervisor?"

  "Because I cannot return the authorization you sent me. There is no user
named 'customerservice' at linksys.com. The mail server at cisco.com bounced
your message to me."

  "Oh. Please wait." Some time later Dale's back on the line. "Yes. That is
not a valid username. You need to send the authorization to
rma at linksys.com."

  "Why wasn't this the return address on the authorization message you sent?
Hold on ... I'm forwarding the reply I sent to customer service. OK. I'm
tailing the mail log and it tells me that the server at cisco.com replied
with the 250 code, accepting the message for delivery. Do you have it yet?"

  Finally, he has the message and we've passed this hurdle.

  If this is what customer service is in the modern computer company, look
out! Will I ever buy another Linksys product? Not me. What a PITA!

Rich

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Jun 30 14:36:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed Jun 30 14:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Customer Service from Hell
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301314370.9174@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301314370.9174@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <40E33224.7070005@dimstar.net>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>  Only a few seconds later I get a MAILER-DAEMON bounce message in my inbox:
>from the mail server at cisco.com: "550 We ain't got no user named
>'customerservice'". Nice, eh?
>
Frustrating? Yes.

Unfortunately, many companies have done away with the user 
"customerservice" and "support" because those get spammed 
horrendously... I was reading an article in eWeek today that said that 
spam has increased to 65% of the email on the net.

Why wasn't it the return address? Because data miners will see the 
return address, and start spamming the return address.

Somewhere, either coming from the mouth of one of the people you spoke 
with, or embedded in the form, should have been instructions on where to 
send the form back.

Russ



From lug at phxlinux.org  Wed Jun 30 14:48:07 2004

I'm trying to use Perl to parse out "records" from an HTML page.  I'm able
to identify the beginning of a record with the following tag:

<TABLE border=0 width=500 class='A'>

or

<TABLE border=0 width=500 class='B'>

...but I have no obvious way to find the end of a record except by the
next starting tag.  There could be numerous additional table tags embedded
in a record so I can't do anything simple like this:

@records = /<TABLE border=0 width=500 class=.+?>(.*?)<\/TABLE>/g;

Does anyone have a suggestion for how to pull everything between each
occurance of these beginning tags?  I realize I'll end up losing the last
record, but I'll deal with that later.
Thanks,
~M

Michael,

  What, specifically, is the DRM software? Acrobat with security features
enabled?

> I think this requires more technical help than I am presently capable of
> getting, so if someone could e-mail me privately (and not condemn me for
> asking such a stupid question) I'd apprecioate it.

  This is a generic enough question it belongs to the public response
category.

  The immediate solutions are to transfer the data files to your linux box
and use a tool to run the reader you have. VMware, win4lin and Wine are all
possibilities. A long term solution is a reader that works on native linux.

> P.S. IS there a way to get any Linux distro to recongize a CD burnder
> and burn CDs with it? Last version of Linux I attempted with would
> repcognize my printer (no surprise -- USB color inkjet) but also
> wouldn;t recongize my DVD player drive as such or ym DVD Recorder drive
> as such.

  I've been burning cdroms for years; Red Hat 4.1-7.3 and now Slackware
8.1-9.1. I don't know of a distribution that won't. It's the tools, not the
distribution that matters. The two you want are 'mkisofs' and 'cdrecord'.
There are also multiple GUI front ends for them.

  If you don't have a SCSI cd writer then you have to enable SCSI emulation
in the kernel. For DVD you may need more up-to-date tools than you currently
have. Others will need to address that as I don't do DVDs. My notebook has
the drive; I don't have the desire or need.

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun 30 18:21:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

Subject: [PLUG] More on WiFi Security
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301817060.10069@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  As it turns out, this week's Linux Journal newsletter has a useful tip for
testing the security of a WAP set up to allow access only to specific MACs.
I thought I'd pass this on for those who didn't see the original.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
  Tech Tip

   If you have configured your wireless access point to allow only your own
   systems to connect, you can test your configuration without borrowing a
   forbidden card. Use the hw ether command-line argument to ifconfig to set
   your wireless card to a different MAC address. An example script using
   this technique can be seen here: http://yak.net/fqa/327.html.

   The script shows that it's important not to rely only on MAC address
   checking to secure your wireless network, because an informed attacker
   can spoof an allowed MAC address.

   More information is available on the ifconfig man page.

Creating A Dual Boot System With Knoppix Linux
2004-06-28

Ron Braithwaite
Collaborative Technologies Coordinator
Free Geek, Inc.
1731 SE 10th Street
Portland, OR 97214
503-232-9350
<ronb at freegeek.org> 

Greetings:

This file will explain exactly how to add Linux to your computer, while
leaving Windows in place, giving you what is known as a "dual boot
system". This is an easy, but time consuming process. It uses Knoppix,
which is the easiest Linux distribution (there are many different
distributions of Linux) to get running and we consider

The steps described here that are done in Windows are pretty much the
same between Windows 98, Windows 98SE, Windows ME, Windows 2000, and
Windows XP. The differences for these particular tasks are so minor, you
should be able to figure them out with no problem. I do recommend that
you read through these instructions before trying this, so you can be
clear on what steps you are going to take.


* Prerequisites:

- A minimum of 3 GBytes of hard drive space, 128 MBytes of RAM, and a
400 MHz Pentium processor.

- Backup all data you want to keep off of your Windows partition.
Although this process is almost always safe, there is still the off
chance that it will damage your Windows partition. Better safe than
sorry!

- A copy of Knoppix 3.4-2004-05-17. You can download a 640 MB ISO image
for a CD-ROM at http://www.knopper.net/knoppix/index-en.html and then
burn that to a CD-ROM. These instructions are ONLY for this specific
version - they will be updated when a new version is available.

- Two blank floppy disks (if your computer has a floppy drive).


* Preparing Your Windows Computer:

1. Put the Knoppix CD in your CD-ROM drive and reboot. It *should* start
up Knoppix and run it from the CD-ROM. It will be slow, but it should
work properly. If it doesn't then you should STOP and try to figure out
what is wrong before proceeding. Once you are satisfied that Knoppix
works correctly, click on the left-most icon on the Knoppix task bar,
select "Logout..." and then select "Restart computer" and click OK.
There will be a bunch of messages as your computer reboots, with the
final message being, "Please remove CD, close cdrom and hit return."
When you do that, the computer will restart into Windows.

2. After Windows restarts, click on "My Computer" and then right click
on the C drive and select "Properties". Next, click on the button "Disk
Cleanup..." and the "Disk Cleanup" tabbed page will appear. There are a
series of checkboxes in a frame, select everything EXCEPT "Compress old
files" and click on OK. If your files are not compressed, you will be
able to access them from within Linux. At this point, you should have at
least 3.0 GB free on your hard drive - if not, STOP now.

3. Select the "Tools" tab and click the "Check Now..." button. A dialog
box will pop up, select "Automatically fix file system errors" and
deselect "Scan for and attempt recovery of bad sectors", then click
"Start". Another dialog box will pop up that starts with something like,
"The disk check could not be performed..." Click on "Yes" and then
restart your computer.

4. After Windows restarts, click on "My Computer" and then right click
on the C drive and select "Properties" again. Select the "Tools" tab
again and this time, click the "Defragment Now..." button. The Disk
Deframenter application should start and your C drive should be
selected. Click on the "Defragment" button and the defragmentation
process will start. This will take a loooooong time. When it is done, a
dialog box will appear with the statement, "Defragmentation is complete
for: (C:)" and you should click on the "Close" button.

5. Now go back to "My Computer" and right click on the C drive and
select "Properties". Select the "Tools" tab and click on "Backup
Now...", which will open the Backup dialog. Click on the "Emergency
Repair Disk" icon. Select the checkbox to backup the registry and then
click "OK". When its done, pop out the disk and label it as the dialog
box asks and then click on "OK" and close all the various open windows.

6. Put Knoppix back into the CD-ROM drive and restart your computer.


* Installing Linux

7. Once Knoppix has started, click on the icon on the toolbar that looks
like a monitor. A command line shell will start and you should enter,
"su". This will put you into "superuser" mode (distinguished by the "#"
prompt as opposed to the normal "$" prompt). Enter "knoppix-installer"
and a dialog box will pop up - just click on "OK". Another dialog box
will appear that starts with "The installer detected that the
installation requirements are not fulfilled yet..." Click on "OK" and
the Knoppix Partition-Menu will appear.

8. Select "1. Partition Partition the hard disk" and click on OK. This
will start the Linux program qtparted. Click on the Expand button, which
is the second button from the right on the title bar. Then select
"/dev/hda" under "Disks" on the left side; this will show you how much
space is used on that drive. Right click on the first partition, which
should be /dev/hda1, and select "Resize".

9. Click on the drop down box next to the label "Free Space After:" that
says "MB" and change it to "GB" (gigabytes). Change the "0.00" value to
whatever amount you want (at least 3.00) and then click "OK". The hda1
display will change from yellow to red, to indicate that something has
changed, but has not been saved.

10. Highlight the line that starts with "02" and right click, then
select "Create". A "Create partition" dialog box will pop up and change
the "Create as:" dropdown to "Extended Partition", select the "Position"
radio group and the "End of unallocated space" radio button. Change the
"Size:" value to double the size of your RAM (for 128 MB RAM, the value
should be 256 MB) and click "OK". Select the "02" entry in the partition
table again with a right click and select "Create" again. This should
create an "ext3" type of 100% of the remaining space. Now select "04" in
the partition table and right click and select "Create" and change the
"Partition Type:" to "linux-swap" and click OK.

11. Click the Disk icon on the tool bar (or menu File|Save). When the
process complete, the Progress popup dialog will say "Operations
completed sucessfully" and you can click on the "OK" button and then
close the qtparted application with "File|Quit".

12. At this point, the Knoppix installer will appear and you can
configure your installation. Highlight the first option ("Configure
Installation") and click on "OK". A dialog box will appear with three
system types to choose from. Select "beginner" and click on "Next". The
next dialog box will ask you which partition to install Knoppix on (most
of the time this is "/dev/hda3"), select the largest partition (Windows
won't show up on this list, so don't worry) and click on "Next".

13. A dialog box now asks, "Input your whole name (name surname)". Enter
your name into the text box as you want it to appear - remember that you
will see this first each time you start Linux. Be neat and tidy or you
will get annoyed later. Click "Next". This then brings up a dialog box
that says, "Input your user name" and makes a suggestion. You should
change this to something like your standard email name (without the @
and the stuff following) and then click "Next". The next dialog asks,
"Input your user-password" with one text box and then, "Input your
user-password again". Put the same password into each text box; we
recommend a mixture of numbers and letters at least 6 chars long. Now
click "Next" again.

14. Next, a dialog box asks for your administration password. This
password should be different from your user password. This should be
definitely be longer and more obscure than your user password. Once you
have entered it twice (just like with your user password), click "Next".

15. This is where you specify your computer name. It is VERY important
that this name be different than any other computer on your local area
network (if you have a LAN). Once you have a good choice, click "Next".

16. Now you much choose where the boot loader goes. Select "mbr" (for
"Master Boot Record") and then click "Next".

17. You should now be back at the main installation window. Select "2.
Start installation" and click "OK". A summary screen describing your
configuration should appear. Check this over carefully and hit
"Previous" if you need to change something or "Next" if it all seems OK.
A progress dialog will appear and you can go get a cup of coffee, if you
like.

18. A dialog box will now ask you to put an empty floppy disk into the
drive. Put it in and click "Yes". Various messages will appear on the
console and a dialog will appear and say "Knoppix was successfully
installed to hd." Click "OK" and eject the floppy drive.

19. Click the K menu on the left of the tool bar and select "Logout...",
followed by "Restart computer" and "OK".

20. When the system restarts, a splash screen will come up with the
different boot options. Use the <DownArrow> key to highlight your
Windows entry. The splash screen will also have a kind of scary title
above the options, saying "debian GNU/Linux unstable 'Sid'". Do not be
alarmed by that, the "unstable" title refers to the release level.
"Unstable" Linux is *far* more stable than Windows. Hit the "Enter" key
to start Windows, so we can verify that everything is working right
there and to make another recovery disk.

21. When Windows restarts, it will first check your filesystem, since it
knows you have changed the size. Let this run to completion and the
system will reboot, select Windows again and restart again. Once you
have logged in, Windows will pop up another message that says, "Do you
want to restart your computer now?". Go ahead and say "Yes" and reboot
yet again.

22. Go back to step 5 and redo your Emergency Repair Disk. Put that away
in a safe place and then restart your computer, this time starting
Linux.

23. I like to have a tidy desktop on my computer, if not in real life.
To do that, right click on your desktop and select "Icons" and then
"Line Up Horizontally" and then do that again, but this time, "Line Up
Vertically". Right click again and select "Configure Desktop...". Here
you can change some of the look and feel, including the desktop
background, which is in German (most annoying if you don't speak
German). Click on "Background" on the left tool bar, then select the
Background Picture from the list (I happen to like "only_k" best, but
that's just me). Make any other changes, such as "Screen Saver" and then
click "OK".

* Updating Your Linux System

24. Just like any software, Linux needs to have updates loaded and new
software added. In order to make that easier, we have created some
script files that will do just that for you. Open a web browser (there
are two on the tool bar - I happen to like Konqueror the best, which is
the icon with the globe inside the gear) and go to
http://www.freegeek.org/??????. Download these files by clicking and
saving them: update-sources.sh, install-collab-base.sh, and
install-non-free.sh.

25. Open a terminal window and type "ls". This will show you the three
files. Type "su", which will make you the SuperUser (root), and then
enter your administration password.

26. When you get the "#" prompt, type:

	sh ./update-sources.sh

27. This will go out to the Internet to pick up all of the updates since
the Knoppix CD was created on May 17, 2004. A LOT of text will scroll by
as it downloads all of the catalogs of potential updates (but not the
updates themselves) until, finally, a prompt says "Do you want to
continue? [Y/n]". Hit <Enter> and the hundreds of updated packages will
now be downloaded and installed.

28. After all of the updates are all downloaded, there will be a series
of prompts which require your interaction. The first of these (usually)
is for cpuburn. The opening line is "cpuburn is dangerous for your
system" and goes on to describe the horrible things that can come from
running this program. This is a program for system testing of your CPU.
Click on "OK" to continue, since there is no reason for you to ever run
this program.

29. You will be prompted at least three times for different files that
will be replaced, with the default always being "No". For the files
/etc/pcmcia/config.opts and /etc/pcmcia/config, you should answer "N"
(or just hit <Enter>). For /etc/menu-methods/menu.h, you should answer
"Y". Other updated files, you will need to determine for yourself
(probably also "Y").

30. Right at the tail end, an error is encountered, "Looking for keymap
to install: NONE" and "Errors were encountered while processing: joe",
that can easily be recovered from. Just enter the command "apt-get -f
install" at the "#" prompt. This will force the install to finish and
correctly install joe. This is NOT a problem.

31. Once you are back at the "#" prompt, you need to be make sure that
YPbind and YPserv do not start. Execute the following line to disable
these services without removing that capability:

	mv /etc/defaultdomain /etc/defaultdomain.old

32. There are some important software packages missing from Knoppix and
there is a shell script provided to go out to the Internet to get and
install them. This batch is actually larger and will take *longer* than
the updates you just installed, so be patient. The most important of
these packages is Gnome, which will add many capabilities - plus a whole
new window manager - to your system. To run this, type:

	sh ./install-collab-base.sh

33. The initial determination of what files need to be loaded for this
happens fairly quickly and will present you with the message, "Do you
want to continue? [Y/n]". Hit <Enter> and hundreds of new packages will
be downloaded and installed.

34. Next, you will see a message screen asking what paper size to set as
default. Use you <UpArrow> and <DownArrow> keys to select "USletter" and
then hit <Enter>. The next message screen will ask, "Use nautilus-media
as default video thumbnailer?" and you should just hit <Enter> again.
Yet another message screen will tell you that you will need to restart
your applications after installation before things look really nice.
Again, just hit <Enter>. After a bunch more packages are loaded, a
Binary Code License Agreement from Sun Microsystems will display, asking
if you want to load Java - and yes, you do. Enter "Q" and then type in
"yes" to the question, "Do you agree to the above license terms? [yes or
no]" (assuming you do agree). At the tail end, you will see a "WARNING"
message which is not significant for this installation.

35. Once you get the "#" again, you can add packages to be able to
handle the proprietary audio and video files, such as Windows
MediaPlayer and RealPlayer. To get these programs, type in:

	sh ./install-non-free.sh

36. Hit <Enter> when you see the "Do you want to continue? [Y/n]"
prompt. The Real Player installer package will put up a message screen
with the prompt, "Would you like to run the Real Player installer now?"
Highlight the "Yes" response and hit the <Enter> key. A prompt will show
the string "Please visit
http://scopes.real.com/real/player/unix/unix.html" with some further
instructions. Follow these instructions to download the package from the
Internet and save it in the /tmp directory. When you have completed the
download, change the path requested by the prompt, "Real Player has been
downloaded to where?" from /root to /tmp and then hit <Enter>. To the
question on the next message screen, "Delete RPM file once it is
installed?", select "Yes" and hit <Enter>. Some more text will scroll by
and then the same messages screens will appear once more. Just answer
the questions the same way and you are now able to create MP3 files from
your music CDs and to listen to proprietary format multimedia files.

37. Now that everything is updated, please delete the three files with
the command (you should do this so things don't get executed twice):

	rm update-sources.sh install-collab-base.sh install-non-free.sh.


* Optional Step - Make Windows The Default

38. Although Linux is the most wonderful thing since sliced bread, some
people still want to boot into Windows as their default operating
system. To make that happen, open a terminal window (the Monitor icon on
the tool bar. Type "su" and enter your administration password. When you
get the "#" prompt enter "vim /etc/lilo.conf".

39. Vim is a very weird text editor. It can be very scary, even to an
experienced Linux user. Please follow these steps exactly. Use the
<PageDown> key to slowly scroll through the file until you see a line of
text that says:

	default="Linux"

40. Scroll down until you see the entry for Windows. It will look
something like this:

	other=/dev/hda1
		label="WinXP/2K(hda1)"

41. Write down *EXACTLY* what the quoted string says! It will be
different for different versions of Windows!

42. Use the <UpArrow> to return the cursor to the line that says
"default="Linux", position your cursor on top of the second quote mark
("), and press the "i" key. This puts vim into Insert mode. Delete the
"Linux" string (but not the quote marks) and then enter the label you
wrote down *EXACTLY* like you found it (e.g., "WinXP/2K(hda1)").

43. Hit the <ESC> key (which takes vim out of Insert mode) and then
enter ":x", which saves the file and exits.

44. Back at the # prompt, enter the command "lilo" and you now have
Windows as your default operating system.

45. Reboot your computer just to make sure. Remember that your Knoppix
startup disk (and your Windows Emergency Repair Disk) can usually get
you back if things get too bad.

46. Enjoy your new Linux system. Explore away!
